Excellent pie, lackadaisical bartender.

text:
La Calaca Feliz has a reputation as one of the better Mexican establishments in Philadelphia, and I was eager to dine here after staring at my Yelp bookmark for months. I finally came last weekend for dinner with a friend and immediately noticed a festive vibe walking in. There is a bar to your left as you step through a narrow path to the back where the restaurant opens up for full table seating. Behind the bar as you walk up a half flight of steps, you get a full view of the open kitchen on your left (I'm a big fan of open kitchen models).

Since the weather was pleasant, my buddy and I opted to sit outside on the back patio, where there are maybe 10 tables. By the time we left, all of them were full.

We both ordered a Mexican Old Fashioned cocktail to start (made with Mexican bitters). Good stuff. I later had a margarita on the rocks which was decent, but not spectacular.

We shared an order of (slightly spicy) guacamole and then I ordered the flank steak entree, served with creamed spinach with bone marrow and chimichurri. Excellent. Our sever even brought corn tortillas and white rice so that I could construct a couple of fajitas.

I left feeling quite comatose, as is not uncommon with Mexican food!
name: La Calaca Feliz

text:
Yelp is usually pretty good with the reviews so I was expecting a four star meal. So why the one star you ask?

We ate lunch there last Saturday. The restaurant was almost empty save for two other couples. We were greeted and seated immediately. Once I looked at the menu, I realized that it was not the same one as is posted online. This is the second time this has happened. How is it that some restaurants can list daily specials online and Valanni can't keep their regular menu up to date?

Our seeimingly bored waiter took our orders and then spent must of his time hunched over the bar checking messages or texting someone on his phone. 

After our food arrived he returned and announced that he would check up on us in a few minutes to see how are meals were. Good thing he never got around to it. Our kobe beef burger, ordered medium rare, was cooked well beyond well done and my grilled cheese panini was so overdone that the black marks from the grill were indistinguishable from the rest of the bread. Blackened grilled cheese anyone? At least the french fries weren't overdone but were salty as hell. Maybe the cook was too busy texting our waiter?

After we finished eating what we ate of our meals, a clumsy bus boy appears. While clearing a few plates he almost dropped one of them so he decided to make two trips. Didn't help because on the second visit he dumped a french fry on my jacket on the seat next to me and didn't apologize or bother to pick it up off the floor where it wound up. 

Then the waiter reappears. I guess his texting or whatever was done. He presented us with the check. Never asked us how our meal was or if we wanted dessert (charred oreo beignets anyone?).
name: Valanni

text: Buena Onda has some tacos deliciosos.  You'll find a variety of tacos, all equally delicious and well balanced.  The guac was not bad but the quesadillas took the queso (cheese) portion of the name a little too literally and were a bit too cheesy and thus bland.  The line can be a bit long but it goes quick and the beer samples actually make waiting in line an almost enjoyable experience.
name: Buena Onda

text:
As I write this and reflect back on my two previous reviews from 2012, I have to tip my hat at the upward performance of Mixto and the impression it has left on me between then and now!  I left the neighborhood for Rittenhouse for a couple of years and have just recently returned to my old Washington Square West stomping grounds.  I couldn't be happier to now call this place one of my top neighborhood go-to's!  

The staff is so friendly and always remember my familiar face; the servers are always quick to honor my recommendations request (and they answer HONESTLY without mentally adding up the tip amount by suggesting the priciest items); and while both the downstairs and upstairs bars are a great social scene, the downstairs square bar layout is designed in such a way that it's easy becoming fast friends with the crowd around you while taking in a sports game and sipping Margaritas.  

While Mixto is far from a "hidden gem" and overall a well known Philadelphia eatery, the amount of seating available is vast, therefore leaving it a safe bet to snag a spot quickly for Sunday brunch or an impromptu Saturday night date.  While you might not be able to locate a table, there's always room at the bar, which is set up to make eating a meal there less of a last resort and more of a preference.  

As far as outdoor dining goes, while there are only a handful of sidewalk seats, this place opens up their floor to ceiling windows in the warmer months, making the downstairs seating feel as close to an outside eating experience as it can get while staying inside.  

And now, for the finale slash best kept secret, drum roll please...

While recently dining here with a friend from Spain, I was introduced to the beef empanadas.  They are hand made daily and, according to him, the best he's ever had outside of Spain itself.  You can order them in twos, along with the chicken empanadas, and they serve as an amazing beginner dish to get the taste buds talking.  I have become accustomed to fulfilling my addiction for them by calling for takeout on my way home from work. They may just be one of the most reasonably priced ways to treat yo'self on the run.  I encourage you to partake!  

Keep up the good work, Mixto.  You're one of my favorite things about choosing Wash Sq. West as my little corner of the world.
name: Mixto

text:
I can't write a Yelp review of a brunch place without comparing it to similar places. Unfortunately, Cafe La Maude doesn't measure up to similar nearby restaurants. I had high hopes because I've heard people talking about this place and the Yelp reviews were great. I've been here a couple times and I have been underwhelmed on both visits. The first time I visited, 3 of us came on a Friday morning for brunch and had to wait around 20-30 minutes, which was particularly annoying because there were a few tables that had not been cleaned after guests had left.

They had both inside and outside seating. A table outside opened up first, so that's where we chose to sit. Outside seating is on a slanted sidewalk, which was very uncomfortable. During my second visit I sat inside, which felt tight and small, but it felt a lot nicer than sitting on a tilted, wobbly table. 

Because of the wait, I had plenty of time to look at the menu and read reviews. What surprised me was the prices, as this place is notably more expensive than similar restaurants. 
As per Yelp, I got the Parisian Za. The second time I got chicken and waffles. The food was good, but not worth the wait, nor the price, nor the uncomfortable outside seating. Overall, it just didn't live up to my expectations.
name: Cafe La Maude

text:
I was craving tacos so much especially since I'm from the West Coast. I know my tacos. namsang? After watching Ugly Delicious, I was like okay. Let me give this place a try. The restaurant is pretty small. It's packed, you will touch other people. So if you're claustrophobic, good luck! 

You stand in line towards the front to order your tacos. You eat first then pay. CASH ONLY. I believe I ordered two pork tacos and a lamb taco. The pork tacos were just okay because they felt a little under seasoned, but the lamb was amazing. I had never had lamb taco before and it was so just so delicious, juicy, tender, and delicate and packed full of flavor. In terms of price, the tacos are on the pricier side of what I am used to. I'm used to paying less than $1.50 per street taco. However, given what they stand for and given these are probably the best tacos you will get in Philly, it might be worth it!
name: South Philly Barbacoa

text: I've been here for City Sips and such before, last summer, and I haven't made it back this summer.  I liked the place.  It's cool inside, the drinks and beer selection were good, the appetizers were so-so.  I liked the openness of the place, especially if you sit upstairs.  However, it's actually pretty cramped inside b/c there aren't all that many seats (esp. upstairs).  And it was pretty hot in there.  The A/C and ceiling fans weren't cutting in.  All in all, though, this wasn't a bad place to grab a drink.
name: Devil's Alley Bar & Grille

text:
I'm a veteran of Lorenzo's from way back when I used to hang out on South Street more regularly in my youth.  I'm talking 18 years ago here.  I've made various pilgrimages here over the years since.  

I hadn't been back in many years, and certainly hadn't been back since the fire and the reopening.  Today was my first time setting foot in here in years.  It looks impressive inside now, although it doesn't have the character it used to have.  

Now, I had to confirm this by looking at pictures here from several years ago.  The slice I got today was bigger than I even remember it being,  From the looks of the pictures here several years back, and the ones I got today, I think they're definitely bigger.  

Taste wise, Lorenzo's has always been pretty basic, which is to say pretty good.  They don't try to do anything fancy.  They just give you a nice big slice that tastes good.  

I've had better pizza in Philly before, but $3 for the slice this big is the best value in the city I've seen.  If there is one better, let me know.  

I'm still a Lorenzo's fan.  I always will be.
name: Lorenzo & Sons Pizza

text:
When Max Brenner first opened, I went there with a coworker, but I was not impressed with the menu, nor what I ordered. The only thing that I liked at the time was the chocolatey smell of the place.

Fast forward a few years later, my coworkers and I decided to go for lunch. I was very reluctant, given my past experience. To my surprise, the menu had been drastically updated. 

I ordered the grilled chicken panini, which came with goat cheese and spinach. It was very delicious. I believe the bread was ciabatta, which I am a huge fan of. 

I can't see myself eating here on a regular basis considering the price. $14 for a small panini and five waffle fries isn't completely practical.
name: Max Brenner - Philadelphia

text:
A part of me feels bad writing a review based on the limited restaurant week menu but figured in the end, i paid for a good meal and unfortunately, thought this was mediocre. I got Caesar Salad. Not so appetizing appearance but wasn't too bad.  The Filet Mignon was pretty good and cooked perfectly at medium rare.  The Creme Brulee was the big disappointment.  Definitely tasted like it was siting around for awhile. 
We sat in a cozy booth and service was really good.

text: My boyfriend and I grabbed dinner here before a show at the Met philly and had a great experience. We shared the shrimp dumplings, scallion pancake, baby bok choy and pan fried pork soup dumplings. The pork soup dumplings were my favorite, though everything was very tasty.

text:
Who would have thought that Varga Bar would become my favorite Beer Week haunt - and not just because of their amazing line-up of taps during the entire week but because of the food!

I have to admit that places trying to evoke 50s "sexiness" and advertising calendar girl searches with suggestive posters are not really my thing but great beer is.  When I ordered the little beef sliders, the boston bib lettuce wraps with spice lamb, and the pot o'pickles, to accompany my pints, I had found the perfect bar food.  The little burgers, so often just hardened pucks in other places, were juicy and beautifully grilled medium-rare, resplendent on their little brioche buns.  These tasty morsels alone are worth going to Varga.  On subsequent visits, I also loved the salads and excellent cheese plates.  I want to go back to Varga and try their other dishes (everything except the "truffled" mac n' cheese - and even that if they can leave out the "truffle oil" addition).
name: Varga Bar

text: The food here is always perfect! I wasn't really hungry, hungry but i hardly ever get to come here so I stopped in for lunch. It was a great decision! We came just as they'd opened and while it was very nice and quiet at first, it definitely picked up and you could tell that people were in a good atmosphere. The waiter was very pleasant, our food was excellent. I had a pasta and shrimp dish that was seasoned just right & the crab cake was pretty good. While I feel like I've had my Maggiano's fix, if I'm in the area anytime soon, I may dip in for more.
name: Maggiano's Little Italy

text:
Watermelon margarita.  That's really all you need to know.  They are so delicious!  They have just the right amount of sweetness and at around $6 they can't be beat.  Actually, all of the margaritas I've had here have been really good; it's just that the watermelon one was the best.  My friend who came from out of town three months ago is still talking about their margaritas!  No joke.  However, the margaritas aren't the only good thing this place has going on.
   
    I've been here probably about six or seven times in total and the service has always been prompt and friendly.  Chips with red and green salsa are served right after being seated.  They will even offer to refill them, and the portion is pretty big in the first place.  Everything I've had here is super delicious.  The best thing on the regular menu in my opinion are the mahi mahi tacos, which never disappoint.  The first time I went here, the server suggested that I add the pineapple salsa, which I did and it went with the well seasoned fish.  I also like to add cheese and jalapenos.  Also the yuca fries are crazy good.  I usually can't eat those and the tacos together because it's too much food for me alone, so we get one order and share.  The veggie quesadilla is really good, especially if you like mushrooms.  My boyfriend enjoys the giant burger here.  The specials are fresh and interesting and I had lovely veggie root tacos here a few weeks ago.  The texture and the seasonings were really nice.  

    The dessert is also good.  I have only tried the Tres Leches Cake, but I enjoyed it.  Basically, you just can't go wrong here.  The prices are good for the quality and the portion size as well. I will most definitely be back.
name: Cantina Dos Segundos

text: Came here for happy hour in honor of a friend passing her oral defense. They had a selection of meats, cheeses, and pickled veggies to choose from and wines. I was most impressed with the pickled veggies. I tend to roll my eyes at places that offer bland veggies as the non-meat option but they were delish. The selection of wines was also impressive and not as expensive as I thought considering this place got three dollar signs Salads were also good and not your average caesar. Overall, I would recommend to others.
name: Osteria

text:
I went here for Sips, and had a very disappointing experience.  First, when you walked in the door the hostess asked if we were there for sips, when we said yes, we were told that we had to sit in the courtyard area.  It was like 85 degrees and 100% humidity.  I will say that being in the shade and having the fans was helpful, but I still thought it was kind of weird that we were herded to a special "sips" section.  

The beer special was Miller Lite :( and then there were some white and red wine specials, and some special cocktails.  I stuck with the cocktails, and they were good, but $4 and served in smaller plastic cups than the beer.  There were some food options as well, but those portions were also tiny.  It definitely just seemed like you were paying less and getting less, not much of a happy hour deal.

I will say that the service was quite good considering how crowded it was.
name: 1225Raw Sushi and Sake Lounge

text:
Village Whiskey brought me back from Yelp hiatus.  I'm not going to write about the burgers for two reasons:  1- everyone else did and 2- I've never actually tried them :)  

What I *can* write about is how delicious the pickled artichokes are.  Go to VW just for them.  Artichoke hearts, lemon, and truffle.. what's not to love?  Toasted sourdough and whipped ricotta turn the artichokes into nice little canapes.  Today was my second visit, and I've been delighted both times.  I heart picked artichokes.

The only down side to having lunch here was that I found some of the staff to be exceptionally loud.. granted, the place was fairly empty while I was there, but I don't need to hear your entire conversation from across the restaurant.  I heard it all- what their summer reading is, how drunk they got the other night, etc etc.  If there's no break room, just keep it down, eh?  Let a girl eat her artichokes in peace.
name: Village Whiskey

text:
This place has been on my bucket list for a while. In general I loved the well prepared but some what pricey tapas style menu. I adore Iberico ham, but a little less so at $24 for 2oz. The sangria was outstanding - a nice dry version that was easy drinking. The papa Fritas were good, as was the octopus - if somewhat tiny for the price again. If I have any real critique here it's how they handle the happy hour. I hate the practice of only offering happy hour prices at the bar, something I rarely encounter outside of Philly. When your in such a small space already, paying full price while somebody sitting on a stool within arms reach pays less just rubs me the wrong way. 

Jamonera lives up to its solid roots and heritage, but I can't say I'd be in a hurry to revisit with so many other choices on the Philly happy hour scene.
name: Jamonera

text:
Zahav completely lives up to the hype.  I went for restaurant week and we were served essentially their entire tasting menu.  Every single thing was incredible.  What I found particularly impressive was that the wait staff acted like it was a normal business day for them, completely unfazed by the fact that it was restaurant week.

Some of my favorite things: beet salad (and I usually hate beets), hummus, haloumi cheese, crispy potatoes, and the beef skewers.

They even gave each of us a $10 gift certificate for the next time we came...just for eating there during restaurant week.
name: Zahav

text: Just left This place tonight! I made a reservation for 830, and we were seated 20-25 minutes later. Street parking or Valet for $18.00 cash. This is one of those places you enjoy because of: 1. Ambiance 2. Fine Dining and 3. Food Bucket List. That being said, I wouldn't make this a recurrent spot because it's a tad pricey! It's a  BIG space with two stories of dining areas. Decor is amazing. We ordered one appetizer- Ahi Tuna Pizza (very tasty $18.00). We also ordered two dumpling orders aka Dim Sum, as add on. One crab and the other chicken. Crab was my favorite. Dumpling orders were in range of $12.00-17.00. Main courses: Cashew Chicken with white rice and Korean Beef Fried Rice. Both were good. Cashew chicken wasn't heavy, and had so much goodness in one bowl. Definitely recommend. The Korean beef fried rice had an egg on top you could break over the rice. For two people with no alcoholic beverages; $107.00 ... ouch! But we had to try it out! You should too! 4.5 stars only because of our long wait. Also costly.
name: Buddakan

text:
After multiple visits, I think it's time to write a review for Federal Donuts.  This neighborhood gem, satisfied your craving for both the sweet and the savory.  It unifies those friends and couples who just happen to have two very different tastes in brunch and lunch, or simply, just can't decide.  

I like the simplicity of the choice.  There are three main options on the menu.  There is the fried chicken sandwich, which is a fairly recent addition to the menu after proving a hit at the Spruce Street Harbor booth.  The sandwich is my personal menu favorite.  I love the savory fried chicken, the sweet buttermilk ranch, and the crunchy and tangy pickle all combined in a perfect bite (after bite).  The fried chicken, comes in a 3 piece or 6 piece and can be served dry, in a wet glaze and one of three dry rubs.  Finally, the donuts make for a delicious sweet ending.  Since seating is limited and the small space becomes quite cramped on weekends, my suggestion is grabbing your favorite choice and walking over to the park to enjoy a brunch picnic.
name: Federal Donuts

text:
Imagine a foggy walk through Reading Terminal on an early rainy Saturday afternoon. Even with dark shades the fluorescent lights are too bright. You need grease. You need coffee. You need it now. 

The Dutch Eating Place will hook you up. 

There's nothing fancy about this refreshingly simple lunch counter. They serve breakfast til 3pm. Their sticky buns are phenomenal with raisins and walnuts. A heaping pile of home fries and omelet-y goodness will arrive with lightning speed, and you will be able to hide in the openness of anonymous tourism.
name: Dutch Eating Place

text:
Been here twice - my first experience of Lebanese food. The first time I got got the Manakeesh with some meat and didn't love it. The second time, however, I got the vegetarian Combo Manakeesh and that was great. I also got chai and that was great. And then the first time I got baklava and that was very very good. 

I'm glad they put so much time and energy into making what was an old run down and abandoned building (a bank I think) into a nice restaurant and I'm sure this place will succeed (and I wonder what will go into the little empty space in the same building). The place is a cross between a restaurant and a coffee shop. They have internet, but there's an hour limit. So....one star off because although this is kind of a coffee shop it's in fact not the best local place to hang out and work (or maybe first eat, and then log on so that you don't waste any of your 1 hour limit on the internet).
name: Manakeesh Cafe Bakery & Grill

text:
Okay this place is honestly really good, and your non-vegan friends wouldn't even notice it was vegan if they just skimmed the menu and you kept your mouth shut. Their tacos are huge so don't balk like I did when seeing only 2 were included. The cauliflower ones were definitely the best, and I'm always a sucker for some good tostones.

They have cute (warm) outdoor space right on 18th st, and their staff is attentive but not intrusive. We basically ordered everything at least once on the happy hour menu (including a pitcher of margs), and it came out to like $155 for 4 people (plus we were full).
name: Bar Bombón

text:
PROS: Cute ambiance, pretty plate compositions
CONS: Pricy, mediocre flavor

The food we tried here (pan-seared salmon in green curry and honey walnut shrimp) isn't bad. It's just way too expensive for what it is, even with the artfully decorated plates. Certainly, being in the Rittenhouse area contributes to the hefty prices that I'm not used to paying for Asian food. There's certainly potential for Jane G as a classy Chinese restaurant. However, for the prices they are charging, I would expect them to step it up a notch on the food quality.
name: Dim Sum House

text: I really enjoyed my meal at V Street. We were stuffed after a couple of beers and about six small plates, we had no room left for dessert. The Cauliflower "65" and Peruvian Fries were definitely my favorites, but we also enjoyed the Piri Piri Tofu and the Dan Dan Noodles. Honestly, the only thing we weren't into was the Langos. I was super psyched to try it after reading all the rave reviews, but honestly although well-prepared, the flavors as well as the abundance of salt just didn't work for me. It's a small (and popular) place, so a reservation is necessary, but there are first-come seats in the front window as well as at the bar, so try your luck if you're in the area. A great experience overall.

text:
I had heard okay things about The Love and visiting myself, my expectations were blown out of the water. With a cute Mediterranean looking inside, the menu varies from Asian fusion to southern to everywhere in between; the objective is good quality food and a creative dish. 
While the cocktails were underwhelming, the food was completely...WOW (even didn't have the chance to document it, it was so good). 
The Parker house rolls - don't skimp out on these. They're so worth it (6 to a skillet). And the chive butter - so good. 
The Seafood cioppino was large with a flavorful red broth and good quantity of seafood. 
The Honey brined pork chop was massive; nothing over the top but great dish. 
The Plant power bowl is large and in charge. For a vegetarian dish, they crushed this with a flavorful peanut curry-ish sauce. Well done. 
The Thai salmon was probably the most surprising dish. Salmon nowadays is, well, boring. In a thick curry broth, this sizable portion of salmon was well flavored and topped on the perfect amount of crisp and crunchy vegetables. It packed a sneaky heat which was a great touch m
To round it out, we go the brownie skillet. The chocolate with graham cracker ice cream with the crunch of caramel - sweet, salty, crunchy - yes, it's worth it. 

Moral of the meal - The Love spends time on their flavor profile and it shows. They're thoughtful throughout the creation and presentation, through to the last bite. 

The Love, I will be back.
name: The Love

text: My favorite thing about manayunk brewery isn't the beer... it's not bad but I never go for it. They have a very decent menu with plenty of items to choose from AND a sushi bar. So you can say that I mostly come here for food and it doesn't hurt that they have good drinks and beer. Will always be our first choice when my girlfriend and I can't decide what to eat. We can all be happy in manayunk brewery.

text:
With 38 beers on tap and a seemingly endless bottle list, beer lovers would love BRU Craft and Wurst.

So yeah, we were *those* people that got the Boot. I mean, we had friends from out of town, we wandered into BRU, and we felt like it would be a great story. It was quite a bit of cash (around $45 including the beer), but we got an absolute delicious Hefeweizen that really hit the spot (always ask the waitresses for recommendations). It's a lot of beer, even for the four of us, but definitely a fun thing to do with friends and you get to keep the boot afterwards. The bar itself has a really nice ambiance to it, with a nice long bar space, table service, and the pour-it-yourself bar station. The waitresses were exceedingly friendly. 

I can't speak for the happy hour crowd, but for taking around out-of-towners or just hanging out for locals, BRU will satiate your German Bier cravings.
name: BRÜ Craft & Wurst

text:
To reiterate Sari A's post, what could I possibly say about Village Whiskey that you have read about in the past 1000 reviews. I can only provide you with my experience. 

The place is small. When I arrived with two of my friends, there were two seats available at the bar together, and another seat open separated by an individual who graciously moved down for my party. We managed to grab his seat upon his departure, for another friend. We were lucky that we got there when we did as the place became full of patrons waiting to get a seat. What this place lacks in size it makes up in every other aspect including the service and spirits at the bar, and the grub coming out of the kitchen. 

The bartenders were not there to just pour drinks. Whether it was the warm-up beers we ordered, to the glasses of whisky later, they provided a brief explanation of everything my compadres and I were considering. The bar is small, but I guess the upside of that is that the bartenders are more attentive. I never had to wait for drink. My bartenders were there to wait on me the minute I took my last sip. I can't remember their names, but they were two bartenders that worked last Friday (4/24/15) between 5-8pm. 

In regards to the grub coming out of the kitchen, let me start with the shrimp. The popcorn shrimp was crispy and seasoned a little more than the usual popcorn shrimp appetizers. After two glasses of Whisky, I broke down and ordered the Whisky King. I never imaged myself eating a burger with Foie gras on it, but I did, and I would probably do it again. In addition, the Applewood bacon, blue cheese, and the maple bourbon glazed cipollini onions, only enhanced the creation of flavors taking place between the buns. Despite the fancy presentation, the burger did not lose its simplicity, which is the flavor of the meat. There was only one way to close the show after this burger. That is right, an another glass of whiskey. Make it a 12 year please. 

An abundance of aged libations, creative burgers, and professional staff are the attributes that make Village Whiskey.
name: Village Whiskey

text:
More like 3.5 stars.

I am such a fan of the ladies of 13th Street, so I had to give this a try.

The waitress was super informative: she gave some recommendations, but pretty much explained the whole menu. This was good because it has only been 2 weeks since the place opened (thus not enough Yelp reviews for suggestions).

The decor is awesome, kind-of a Gothic appearance with a cool wall mural, black chandeliers, and wooden tables.

I tried the Warm Medjool Dates, Pig's Tail A La Plancha, Calamares Negras, and Setas A La Plancha.  The winner was definitely the pig's tail, followed by the dates. I would say the calamares were my least favorite, partly because I felt like a good 1/3 of the plate was just fried bits of ink without the calamari in it (unless my friends ate them while I wasn't looking..highly likely). I also thought it was a little salty. The mushrooms in the Setas were very flavorful, and the foie gras wasn't bad either, but I'm not a big fan of foie gras in general. For dessert, we tried the Bunuelos, and they were money, like more money then FedNuts.

Definitely can't wait to go back and try the other stuff on the menu.
name: Jamonera

text:
Noisy, Crowded and way way way overpriced.
My lunch today was $33 ($66 for 2 - we split it) no alcohol, no dessert.

The Shrimp salad (delish) was $18.50 and we shared a tuna tartare $10.50
She had a beet salad and a $5 Coffee.

How this adds up to $66 is beyond me.

Anyhow I will NOT be back anytime soon.
Wonderful food and people watching but just too $$rich$$ for my blood.

Left hungry and broke.

.

text:
I came to this place because I was curious what Burmese food actually was (which, i'm sure many of the Yelp readers are). Based on what we ordered, it seems to be somewhat of a mix between Malaysian, Thai, and Chinese food. 

Now, don't be fooled by the dirty shady sign outside the door - it's actually quite nice inside. Also, don't come to this place expecting giant obesity-inducing portions of food like other Chinese places. Expect a normal-small amount of food, but made with care. We ordered fish, noodles, salad, chicken, and of course, the 1,000 layer bread.

The fish and 1,000 layer bread are the only things i'd recommend. We ordered watercress salad, which sadly, was only the size of my palm. The other dishes were similar to anything you order at other thai/chinese restaurants for a larger portion at the same price. 

Overall, i'd give this place 3.5, but will bump up to a 4 because unlike other chinatown restaurants, this place is pretty clean.
name: Rangoon Burmese Restaurant

text:
I heard a lot of good things about this place which may have overhyped it. I ordered the vegan wings and a soup. 

The wings were okay but were SO hard and crunchy. The texture was definitely my favorite. The best vegan wings I have had were at Bourbon & Branch. A few blocks away, definitely worth it.

The best thing about this place was the vibe. It's warm, upbeat and friendly. Interesting concept of smashing a diner and a bar together but I liked it! 

I'll definitely need to come back and try other items...not counting this place out yet!

text:
Decent little spot. We went on a Saturday night. They did not take reservations so the 8 of us decided to give it a shot anyway. Hour wait. Lame but expected. I personally enjoyed a few Pacifico's while I waited and tried not to be in the way. I am extra large and the place is not very big so it was difficult to not be a road block. 
   Anyways, the queso fundido, the nachos, and short rib enchiladas all get an A plus. Delicious.  El Rey is very reasonably priced. (I'm not cheap like many Yelp reviewers i see) It's like El Vez's cheap dirty little brother. The bill, drinks included, came to $30 a head. I look forward to going back soon.
name: El Rey

text:
This is what I'm talkin about right here! This jawn got the best cheesesteak I've had in Philly. Better than all that South Philly stuff. Conveniently close to Broad St. right off Germantown and Erie, you can't miss it. It's plenty of parking in the back. 

The steak isn't overwhelmed by cheese. It's just perfect, the way it's cut. Put some fried onions, mayo and ketchup on that jawn and you're in the game. Grab you a brewski (OE, Colt 45, whatever you want because the selectionfor about $2-3 and sit down at the bar next door.

It's definitely a hood spot and not the most organized but that's not a bad thing. Max's is the place to go!
name: Max's Steaks

text:
This is a fantastic museum! If you don't have a car, you can take the train to 30th Street and walk down the very scenic pedestrian path that runs right by the water. 

It's nice that they will honor a student ID for a discount price and your admission ticket for the day can go towards a yearly membership fee, if you'd like.

As for the museum itself, even the building is a work of art. My boyfriend and I came here and we were very impressed. All of the exhibits are very well organized and are absolutely beautiful. I recommend visiting during a weekday if you can--there are fewer people and it's easier to take pictures. The map they give you at the entrance is very easy to follow. Give yourself a lot of time to explore! This museum is huge!

There is also a very elegant cafeteria and gift shop, both a bit pricey. 

Overall, this is a must-see if you're in Philadelphia! Get your culture on.

text:
Delicious burger and truffle fries! I was afraid it won't be as good since I ordered this for delivery - but the food was still warm and crunchy. 

I got the portobello mushroom burger (arugula, cheese, fried onions). The pairing was delicious! I added some of the truffle sauce that came separately with the fries. I do have to say the burger is very heavy with the fried onion so I could only eat half of it in one go (since I also had the fries). Good meal for a guilty day.

text:
Absolutely Fantastic.

No question this place is rustic Northern Italian from floor to ceiling & certainly including the food on the table in between the two.  I found the decor to be warm & homey if only a little industrial.  The chairs could be a little more comfortable to be sure, but that is certainly my biggest complaint about Osteria & I'll gladly sit on those hard wooden chairs again if it means I'll be filling up on more of Vetri's creations.

The menu is full of interesting combinations of food, many of which sound quite bold & possibly hard to pair following dishes with, but that was not so, at least in my case.  I found each item delicious in its own unique ways & in no way did it play upon my opinion of following dishes.  I started with mozzarella in carrozza with olive oil, poached pear tomatoes and capers.  Incredible!  Really, it was like a large bit of fried mozzarella, but certainly the most delicious fried mozzarella that has ever graced my mouth.  It was incredibly gooey & the pear tomatoes were perfect along with it.  For my primi I went with the robiola francobolli with chanterelle mushrooms and thyme which I think were my favorite dish of the evening.  The sauce was rich & the "post-stamp" ravioli absolutely delectable.  I could have easily eaten a far larger dish of these delicious little bites.  For the secondi I tried the rabbit "casalinga" with pancetta, sage, brown butter and soft polenta.  Now this was my first time with rabbit, so I can't compare it to anything I've had before.  I will say that I was pleasantly surprised (not that I was expecting to not like it, but I was expecting it to be gamier).  The way in which it had been prepared...it was half a rabbit, bone in, glazed & seared if I remember correctly...was mouth watering.  The meat was full of flavor (altho somewhat "chickenish" to me) & tender.  I even enjoyed the dark meat & I generally do not like dark meat of ANY sort!  For the contorni I tried the artichokes alla romana which were also very good.
Boyfriend tried the lobster & pasta special for his secondi which was also amazing, of course.  A whole lobster which had been shelled served with spaghetti in a red sauce which had a slightly cajun taste to me.  Not what we were expecting, but still nothing short of luscious, of course.
Finally for dolci I had something much like a crepe, which had been glazed & then topped with a streusel.  Good, but not as sweet as I was expecting (hoping?).  Also, it was VERY hot.  It took quite some time for it to cool down to a point where it was comfortable to eat.  

Service at Osteria was very good.  Our server was very helpful with any questions we had regarding the menu, nor was he overbearing.
The wine list is fairly extensive, but a bit pricey, namely if you're just buying by the glass.  While deciding on which red to go with I was even offered generous samples of a few of the reds to help me along with my decision.

I'm tempted to give Osteria only 4 stars for some reason, but my complaints are really so few & I was so very, very happy with the food & service & place in general that I think its more fair to just go with 5.  (Once again, I find myself wishing Yelp could give half stars!)
I will definitely be making a return trip to Osteria - I've got to try one of the pizze's next time!
name: Osteria

text:
It was about two bites into my Village Burger, with a blend of cheddar, ketchup, burger juices and egg running down my hands (and a significant portion of my chin), that I looked over at my sister and answered the question she'd posed earlier:

"No, I don't think I'd come here on a first date."

See, I don't do burgers terribly often. So many folks just don't get it right. The meat's overworked, the patty to bun ratio is off-kilter, the toppings feel like an afterthought. But, on those rare occasions that I hear from multiple individuals (friends, family, and strangers alike) that Village Whiskey offers "The best burger of their lives".... well, when in Rome. A Monday evening with the little sister in town, we were still told there was a 30-45 minute wait. Then, we realized the bar had about 6 seats just waiting and, as it was full service, we promptly snagged our stools. 

No time for appetizers, and missy was not of age to partake in spirits, we were mostly just eyes on the prize. Meat. And lots of it. We each ordered a Village Burger with cheddar and, while she opted for the smoked bacon, I followed the wise words of Mike B. and "put an egg on it." We split some of those duck fat fries and, since Drake's explained to all of us that you only live once, splurged with the Sly Fox cheese sauce. Neither of us were disappointed.

The wait was not long, the lighting warm and inviting, and the bartenders friendly (though, perhaps since we were only ordering sodas, nothing exceptional. I'm sure if we were in the market for some whiskey, that might be different). Upon the arrival of our burgers, we momentarily marveled at the height of the patties, wondering how on earth we would smash them down to a palatable size. Choosing the rip-and-chomp method, we divided and conquered our burgers, piece by glorious, meaty piece. Each topping was exceptionally done, from the Boston Bibb lettuce to the ripe, juicy tomato. Really, juicy is the word that comes to mind for this entire meal. It's the kind of meal that makes you wish your napkin came with two other napkins, the kind of juicy that results in finger-licking and bun-dipping. Unfortunately, unlike some reviewers, my egg wasn't particularly runny, but I'm sure that could be resolved with a simple request, and honestly.... I don't know if I needed much more dripping down my hands.

For the two of us, including two sodas, the bill ran a cool $50, but I firmly believe it was worth it for an indulgent evening with the baby sister. Would recommend adamantly to all burger babes and bros looking for a meaty meal.
name: Village Whiskey

text:
Mmm my home away from home (which used to be less than half a block from my home!), I can certainly say I've become quite the expert on their menu since I've been here so many times!

For starters, I love the bazooka limon guac, or the macho nachos with pulled chicken rather than beef or chorizo. Do yourself a favor and share these!! They're gigantic haha, but best nachos of my life! No joke.

For my meal, my true loves are the carnitas tacos (my bf loves the mahi tacos) and the chicken enchiladas, or if I'm sharing with a bunch of friends we usually do the Tacos al Carbon....now the menu says it's for 2, but if you're getting appetizers like the guac, this can certainly be enough for 4 people! It comes with enough toppings for an army too...it's amazing. 

As far as the drinks go, they're known for their blood orange frozen margarita, which is my personal fave. They have a huge list of tequilas though, as well as various margaritas and sangria! Plenty to choose from, and they have pitchers of many of their drinks as well!

Things can get pricey if you're there for dinner and drinks, but you can plan to avoid that as well by sharing because the portions are huge. My only complaint is that I completely lose my self control in there and always leave stuffed to the brim!! Not the worst thing in the world, that's for sure :)
name: El Vez

text:
Food:
Ordered rouge burger, truffle fries, and seasonal pumpkin gnocchi. The burger was cooked medium rare as requested but fell apart instantly as the buns absorbed the juice. The pattie  was really thick and juicy yet somehow the burger still ended up being dry. 

We ordered truffle fries but were given plain fries. They were replaced and on the house. The truffle fries weren't any different though. I found the fries over cooked and dry. Truffle flakes didn't make them any better. 

Gnocchi was a small but heavy dish. Full of flavor but way too much flavor. Needed something simple and clean to pair with it. Has a hint of Asian cuisine flavors.

Service:
Slow server. He got our order wrong but apologized and replaced the fries on the house.
name: Rouge

text:
Morgan's Pier is perfect for those balmy summer nights when all you want is a pretty view, nice weather, and some yummy drinks with your friends.

I didn't get to try any of their food, but I would highly recommend the Watermelon Ricky and the White Sangria if you prefer something sweet and fruity.

I loved the super low-key and laid-back vibe here. Definitely one of my new favorite spots in Philly.

text:
I love Mixto for happy hour! You can't go wrong with flavorful, strong mojitos/margaritas for only $5. And with $1 chicken empanadas, these are the ingredients to a perfect happy hour treat.

I have also been here for brunch, and everyone loved their food. The service was a bit slow, and our waiter seemed to be taking his time, but as long as you are not in a rush, this could be a great place for a good meal. I would love to try dinner here sometime.

text:
Dropped in to try the Chicken Pad Kee Mao (a.k.a. drunken noodle) and quite frankly, I didn't get any of the strong authentic bold Thai flavors I had come to expect out of this dish.  I don't think that authentic Thai is what they strive to be, so I guess my expectations were a little off.  

The service was really attentive and quick.  I was seated quickly in the front of the restaurant, next to a bar with TVs showing the evenings sports.  My food/drink and subsequent check were served quickly which was preferably given I was parked at a meter nearby.

text:
It was our anniversary so we wanted to check out somewhere with good reviews and a great ambience. Everyone we knew was raving about Morimoto so we knew we had to check it out. We never spend much unless it's a special occasion so we were expecting more bang for our buck coming here. Overall, for the portion size and price tag and flavors, none of it was worth it. There will be a break down of what we had. Mind you, maybe I just don't have a palette for the fine dining side of food, but a lot of street foods I've had in other cities and countries was so much better and at a quarter of the price!

Service was great, I will hand them that. Our server was around just enough to get orders and clean our tables, not overbearing. Although, they kept switching our plates and I kept thinking what a waste of water and time, I only had one food item on that dish, I can use it for the entire meal.

- Pork belly and porridge - it was tender and fall apart in your mouth, the porridge had a hint of seafood (potentially coming from the Thai sauce since they used that in most everything) the porridge was salty but the pork was perfect, could've been bigger

- Tempura - this was the best appetizer and there were all sorts of goodies, from carrots to shrimp to ham/bacon and cheese, to mushrooms. Each bite was different and it was fun trying to figure out what was what. The sauces were good too, favorite was the cheese sauce, next the sirarcha, and last was that Thai sauce 

- Lychee and fig drink - my favorite drink out of the 3, fresh, clean, not too sweet, and there was a lychee in it to clean the palette, good balance of flavors

- Morimoto martini - I took a sip, it just tasted like alcohol to me, my husband enjoyed it. I am by no means an alcohol connoisseur 

- Chiyu drink - same as above, even more alcoholic tasting. I always thought these drinks were suppose to either mask or blend the flavors better, but again not my area of expertise. I'll stick with the food.

- King crab - fresh, tiny portion for the price. But delicious dips. I can't remember the dips but it was nice to be able to go back and forth between them

- Morimoto ramen - by far the worst dish we had. Salty beyond belief. The portion size was a joke. And to call it "iron chef," was embarrassing. No substance at all. Literally just boiled bones and salted it and threw some noodles and chicken in it. This was so disappointing and an embarrassment to ramen. They should have not called this a ramen or just take it off the menu. To charge what they did for a tiny bowl is absurd. Again maybe I'm not meant for fine dining.

- 12 oz Australian wagyu steak - cooked the way we asked, the sauce was delicious, but again overly salted. Or maybe Americans are just eating this salty nowadays?!

3 pieces of sushi - nothing amazing about it. It just tasted like any sushi I've ever had anywhere. Not impressed.

Overall, this place is completely overrated and the price is not worth the experience. Not to mention, they have on each table the most interesting light fixture. I mean, usually you would want to keep your intimates hidden if you get my drift. (Pic attached) we will not be back. The only other fine dining experience we had was at Gordon Ramsey's steak house in Vegas and we spent a little bit more than we did here. Completely different experience, perfection food at Ramsey's so it was disappointing. I just want all the folks coming here for the hype, to beware. Happy eating.
name: Morimoto

text: Walked in and found two seats at the chefs bar. Score for a Thursday night in Philly! The Satim is excellent: six small bowls of seasoned, roasted vegetables. Our fave was the green beans in a tomato matbucha with Fresno chili. Order the small bowls for sharing and get the hummus with seasoned, hot flatbread. We shared the  branzino filet baked on the poncho with the skin on, served on a spicy tzaziki cucumber sauce. Zahav is one of the best restaurants in the country! Don't miss it.

text:
Cute place. Good food. Excellent service. Came here on a Sunday morning/afternoon for brunch and surprisingly, no wait! Right from the beginning, our service was AWESOME! Was very patient when I was trying to strap in my baby, looking at the menu, undecided on what I wanted, etc. My husband was simple and ordered just eggs and sausage. I ordered the fritata. It had tons of veggies ranging from squash to zuchini to mushrooms, onions and more. Then it was topped off with cheese. It was good but wasn't the best. It needed something else, but not sure what.

The 4 stars really comes from the great coffee. Mmm. I really enjoyed the coffee. And again, the service. Our server even brought over toys for my son to play. They def go above and beyond! :-) I do want to come back and check out the dinner menu though.
name: Winnie's Manayunk

text:
There were things that I liked about this place. It was obviously busy but we were still seated pretty quickly. It's a very simple  modern open decor  which I liked. I was really excited to order the dan Dan noodles. I think they scared me with the spice level! I was expecting it to be Han Dynasty spicy so I ordered it at a lower level 3. I had to later add more hot oil to it to get the right level of heat. They bring the noodles to you and mix them which is a nice gesture. And the portions were huge. 

My only random critique is that their plates are too small?? They have these small rectangular plates that are really cute and functional for an appetizer, but not so much for dinner. I kept making a mess on my side of the table because my noodles kept dropping from the serving bowl to my plate! 

Overall, glad I checked this place out!

text:
Has the atmosphere of a colonial-era ale house, likening itself to McSorley's Ale House in New York. On weekends, this place is packed to the gills with drunk college kids tripping over themselves to buy handled pints of beer, which they will promptly chug (and dribble down their chins onto their collegiate sportswear). It almost seems like a rite of passage here. 

Adorned by many televisions, McGillins is really more of a spectator sports venue and endears itself to this genre by having several long tables perfect for hosting large groups. My most pleasant visit was during the fall a couple of years ago when we popped in for a house ale on a Saturday afternoon. It was empty, the bartender was friendly and the college football was in peak form. This is a good place to grab a drink, but be prepared for the sloppy crowds on the weekend.
name: McGillin's Olde Ale House

text:
This place is great! The restaurant is spacious and clean. The service super quick and efficient. Being my first time at this place, I took a while to look through the menu and during that time our waiter checked up on us like 4 times. They're a little too efficient. 

I had the chance to try three dishes here, mainly recommended by fellow yelpers: the Roti Canai, Hainanese chicken and beef satay. The Roti Canai came with this flatbread that has similar texture to Dosa. It's real thin and has a crisp to it. The side of coconut curry was delicious and really complemented the flatbread. The Hainanese chicken was pretty simple, just steamed chicken in light soy sauce. The flavors worked well together and the chicken was cooked perfectly. The side of rice that came with this dish was delicious as well. It's not your regular rice. It's nicely seasoned and has a yellowish tint to it. I could probably just eat the rice by itself. The beef satay had a sweetness to it and the side of peanut dipping sauce added an extra layer of sweetness as well. I wish the satay was a tad more savory than sweet. 

Overall, I enjoyed my dinning experience at Penang and so glad that there's a delicious Malaysian place right in Philly.
name: Penang

text:
Tattooed Mom has never been my favorite spot (my last visit was probably about five years ago), but I definitely get why people dig it. On my recent visit, I discovered the upstairs for the first time. Interesting. I enjoyed finding Doggystyle in the jukebox and played almost the entire album. I also played pool (terribly) alongside Vinny P, who amazingly kept me as his partner for more than one game. Speaking of my pool partner, he graciously shared his basket of tots and I found them to be quite delicious. 

Until we meet again, T-Mom's.
name: Tattooed Mom

text:
This is your best bet for good Vietnamese food in Chinatown. They offer big portions and good quality food. The service is super fast and they let you enjoy your meal in peace for the most part. 

My favorite part about this place is that they have fresh fruit smoothies. Their durian and avocado smoothies are something I order every time I eat here! Very rarely can I say that I'm able to get a fresh durian smoothie.

I appreciate the wide variety in the menu. As much as I like Pho 20, which is probably the only other Viet restaurant I go to in Chinatown, I only go there for Pho or a rice dish whereas at Pho Xe Lua, I would be willing to order something less basic.

They have a lot of seating that stretches to a second level. Tip: the bathrooms are only 1 stall so go to the one upstairs if you're stuck waiting for one on the first floor!
name: Pho Xe Lua Viet Thai Restaurant

text:
A while back I started a burger thread on Yelp asking Philadelphians where their favorite burger in the city came from. I got a lot of answers and Kraftwork was among those mentioned; however, it slid to the back of my mind and I sorta forgot about Kraftwork for a while. Fast forward about a year and I find myself here. 

We had attended the Philly Beer Expo at the Naval Yard earlier in the day and met up with a friend who lived in Fishtown. She was nice and sober enough to drive us back to her place where we sobered up. We asked her if we could grab a bite to eat before heading back to Jersey and she suggested Kraftwork. "Oh I've heard of them!" I said, but I couldn't drum up where or when I had heard of them. 

We get to the bar, I open the menu, and then it hits me when I look at the list of burgers. "I heard that the burgers were good here" I drunkly thought to myself (or maybe I said it out loud, I can't quite say). I opted for the Kraftwork burger with cheddar (I think) and bacon red onion marmalade (that's right bacon red onion marmalade). Just typing it now has me drooling again, so you can only imagine my enthusiasm for this condiment. 

Needless to say the burger was cooked just right and the bacon red onion marmalade was absolutely delicious. Come to think of it, even if the burger was bad, I don't think I would've noticed because I was still in post-beer fest awe at the deliciousness of this creation. I did not order a beer, but word on the street is that they have a pretty nifty tap selection, so I will be sure to return for that. 

Good food with good service for a decent price has made me a fan of Kraftwork. Next time I am in Fishtown, I will not hesitate to stop on in.
name: Kraftwork

text:
I love the concept of this place - am always a fan of bringing ethnic cuisine to the fast casual sphere and executing it without sacrificing quality. I came here over the weekend, and clearly many others are in the same boat. It was packed but the line moved quickly. On top of that, our food arrived quickly and seating was still ample since the restaurant space is surprisingly large. 

As for what we actually ate there, we split:

+ Hummus w/ slow-roasted lamb - The meat & toppings mix was kind of funky and gamey tasting for some reason. Not as big of a fan as I am for Dizengoff's hummus & toppings. Suraya's hummus is also more neutral-tasting.

+ Shish taouk sandwich - stuffed with chicken, french fries, and some other stuff. Not bad, but wasn't super impressed compared to other Middle Eastern fare I've had in Philly.

+ Turmeric tea - very nice and liked the spices

The baked goods counter looked incredible, and I wanted to just sample a little of everything. In fact, I came close it and got a huge bag of pastries to go:

+ Cruller - one of the best I've had!
+ Flan patissier - this had Meyer lemon in it. Wasn't a huge fan, and comparable to other egg tarts I've had
+ Jalousie - not bad. Not as buttery or flavorful as I'd hoped
+ Chocolate pistachio (financier?) - same as above.

Again, I love the concept, the incredible design of the interior, etc. However when it came down to the food, I wasn't super impressed. In an area with tons of good restaurants, I still might take my friends to give this place another spin and because it's such an interesting space/food.
name: Suraya

text:
I came back here for a date night and to bring the pooch to the "pizza and puppies" section and it was a wonderful night. Service was great. Some were coming over and giving my pup a bunch of love and he was in doggie heaven. 

The fried chickpeas they give you were a great unique touch to start the meal and were very tasty with the pistachios in it. The burrata and kale salad was done really well but would have appreciated a little more burrata for the price. We got a pasta this time and it was one of the best pasta dishes weve ever had. We did the pork/proscuitto tagliatteli and it was so ridiculously flavorful. Happy with all our choices. We did the quattro formaggi again because that cant be skipped, ever. 

Their beer selection is a bit odd and wines are a bit pricey for what it is, but we ended up discovering some great beers we hadn't had before. I'll definitely be back with the pup again! Favorite pizza in philly!
name: In Riva

text:
I was just yelping around when I remembered I had never written about good dog and there bangin burgers!

AMAZING!!!! This is probably the best burger I have ever put in my mouth. Juicy and cheesy and oh so delicious.  The bar itself is great to excellent beers on tap and the service is always friendly.  I usually go there after a drunk Saturday with friends so its perfect to play some pool and soak up the alcohol with a burger and a mix of regular and sweet potato fries.  My mouth is watering just thinking about it.  Cant wait to go back a feed my burger craving.

i know i used just 3 stars, but overall not a bad experience! not many vegetarian options on their restaurant week menu. we had a reservation and then had to wait by the bar area for close to 20 minutes. i have been long suspicious of restaurant week reservations being consistently "10-15 minute" waits, in the hopes that we consumers will pay a visit to their bar for a cocktail pre-dinner. but that's not how i roll, baby!

our server was sweet, atmosphere on a friday was LOUD, and i really enjoyed the cheese+apple+honey dish, although i cant remember the name.

text:
Geno's, you a trap, you should start a DJ gig. Soggy roll, dry steak, no flavors. The whiz had a funny, moldy flavor. The entire cheesecake tasted weeks old. My friend from Germany was visiting Philadelphia for the 1st time, the fame of Geno's (locally notorious) raised her expectations but we were both disappointed after our visit. Not only the cashier chick made fun of her accent as "sounding Eastern European" (Ya know what she's implying) and asked me twice to order in English before I even opened my precious mouth. NAH GIRL NAH. Just because I don't look american it doesn't mean I don't speak English. Have you heard of Multilingualism??? Oh course not because you are ignorant. 
DONT GO THERE.

text:
Oh, Vietnamese food, why do you hate me?

I've given Vietnamese food a try several times, and it's always against my better judgement.  Since the day I got duped into going for Pho, only to find out that there's no such thing as vegetarian Pho, to the day that I went to Vietnam Palace for a friend's birthday, was given the wrong order (which had meat in it), and was overcharged... I feel like it's just not meant to be.

So when my boyfriend asked if I wanted to go for Vietnamese last week, I kindly declined.  It's not that I don't like the food, I just don't love it.  I'm just a vegetarian-Chinese addict that eating anything else (anything at all!) seems silly.  But given my past experiences, I never really had a desire for Vietnamese. He wanted it, though, so I gave in.  And whaddaya know... they gave me the wrong food, and by the time I got the food I ordered, my friends were already done eating.  

The problem at Nam Phuong, I think, is that it's a big place, and the waiters all seem to wait on everyone.  So when i realized they gave me the wrong thing, I didn't even know who to flag down, because one guy took our order, another guy brought drinks, another guy brought food...  

It's just one more reason for me to decline Vietnamese again.  Nothing against the food, it just hasn't ever really worked in my favor.

text: This is our local go to for breakfast- they are such a family friendly business, on weekend mornings when I've been solo with the toddler (when dining in was still an option) I never hesitated to bring him here, they always loaded him up with crayons and/or toys. He loves to eat the pats of butter, but also, I love that they have most of their pancakes as an option to get as a single, which gets some actual food into him. Their biscuits are clearly homemade and the love shows, as are their jams. Strong coffee which is very welcome in the mornings, and you can never go wrong with the frittata on the specials menu. We got take out from here for Mother's Day which held up well.

text:
This place is overrated. My steak was dry. I took one bite and the roll split on the bottom. FAIL! The sweet potato fries were pretty good, but I see how they can old after a while (I don't eat many sweets). Don't get me started on the prices! My platter came to $12.00 but I feel as though I only got $8.00 worth of food.

And when I was there some little hoodrat with a stank attitude had the nerve to hold 3 seats for her family (nowhere to be found)... as hard as seats are to come by in there. Some tourists were kind enough to offer me a seat as they were about to leave. After sitting for a couple of minutes I decided to order to go because it's just too cramped.

I wonder why this place moved from 3rd street. DOWNGRADE! This was my 1st time (and last time) going. I had to see what the hype was about. And it's about nothing. Maybe I would feel differently about a chicken steak, but I don't buy them.

text:
Fresh french press coffee + the Cyrpus breakfast = one very happy girl.

The cyprus is a delectable breakfast dish comprised of grilled lounza (ham), pan fried haloumi cheese, 2 slices of crunchy whole grain bread and a kalamata olive/green pepper mix as a refreshing touch. Each bite is perfectly salty and savory. Yum, this dish never ceases to please. 

Great brunch spot!

text: After our first experience at Audrey Claire (I'm shocked I didn't review!) we weren't eager to return. We were so disappointed because everything on the menu looked incredible, but it was just flavorless. However, we are so glad we gave it a second shot because this meal was fantastic. The food was delicious and the price very reasonable. For 3 people, we enjoyed the beets, pumpkin and goat cheese, the arugula salad, the fried haloumi, the ahi tuna, the short rib flatbread, and the mussels. The flavor of everything was terrific and it was plenty of food (the mussels are definitely the best value and super tasty...we couldn't even finish them!). The bread was really good, albeit pretty crusty, but definitely fresh. Our only complaint was the service. It was TERRIBLE. I spent 10-15 minutes trying to flag down our server for more bread (the restaurant was over half empty and the servers were all hanging around, leaning on the bar). No one once offered to open and pour our wine, which was sitting on the table. If it weren't for the terrible service, we'd give it 5 stars.

text:
I was slightly disappointed. I expected so much more of their burgers, but unfortunately my Pickleback burger was very well-done. In other words, it was dry as a rock and had no drip of fat what so ever. I wasn't blown away by the taste either. M had the pretzel cheesesteak burger (not sure if that was the exact name), and his meat was dry as well. 

Why 3 stars? It was a cool place to hang out on a Sunday afternoon, people watching on a hot day under the umbrella. I also had the cookie monster shake which was delish. They're not stingy on the booze, that's for sure. M had the mexican chocolate shake - also awesome. 

Staff was friendly and welcoming, but thinking of those dry bland burgers makes me not want to come back here.

text:
All in all I had a lovely time at Kanella.  We arrived 15 minutes late for our reservation but fortunately it wasn't a problem.  The service was good and the waiter reminded me of Alton Brown somewhat in appearance and demeanor (not a bad thing).  And I actually like that he didn't refill our wine glasses after the initial filling.  I know some of you like waiters to do that but I think waiters at BYOs don't have any idea about how the wine is being distributed at the table and sometimes people drink faster and really shouldn't have their glasses automatically refilled because then they're getting a disproportionate share of the bottle.  Here I go off on a tangent again.  I am a wine Marxist.

We ordered appetizers of a certain kind of Amazonian fish (I guess the Greeks can cook fish from anywhere) and the trio of dips.  The dips were excellent, especially the garlic one.  A sizeable morsel of said dip remained on the plate and then a waiter whisked it away before I could tell him that me doth protest.  Those waiters are awfully quick to take your plates and ask you if they can take it *while taking it away*.  Hold on to your horses, boys.  I also almost lost my last bite of my entree this way but I was quicker on the draw that time.

It wasn't till nearly the end of our dip feast that the waiter informed us that the fish appetizer had been sold out.  So that's fine, but why it took him that long to realize I'm not sure.  We ordered the octopus ragout in its place, which arrived promptly and was very pleasing.  The octopus was tender (for octopus) and all the flavors came together harmoniously.  I loved the little bits of chorizo-like sausage in it, whatever they were.

I had the goat entree, which was steaming hot upon its arrival but fortunately cooled off quickly.  The portion size was decent and the meat was amply tender.  Combined with barley, greek yogurt, breaded eggplant, etc. it was a nice homey dish.  I sampled my sister's quail, constituting my first bite ever of this fowl.  Lacking other quail experience I can't comment too much on it but the meat seemed to be cooked well.  The sauce for this dish was pretty heavy on the sherry.  My sister seemed to like this aspect; I would have been more on the fence about it.  Every course of the evening was seasoned well. ++

I don't know if I'd rush back here but would recommend it without much hesitation to anyone looking for Greek.  I'd like to give it four and a half stars.  WHY can't Yelp have a half star option?  It'd be easy to create and half stars are reflected in review averages anyway.

text:
I went here for the first time and let me tell you, when the reviews say small... they mean this place is small. Enough room to sit 20 people, maybe a few more. There is also no waiting area, so it got cramped standing around for a table since it was raining out. The place itself though was very nicely done and the open pizza kitchen with the oven was definitely cool, especially if you sit at the bar. 

Once we were seated, the service was good and the waitress helpful with the menu. The pizza was fantastic! Perfectly done. Overall, this place is a great restaurant... but falls short of 4 or 5 stars because of the price. Pizzeria Vetri was just so over priced for the amount of pizza you got that it was just absurd. Two of us ran a bill of near $50. Pizza I feel just should not run that expensive unless Marc Vetri is making it himself. I would certainly go back here... but not very often.

text:
A group of 6 of us came here recently strictly because one of us is vegan and finding someplace to accommodate this with a decent selection isn't all that easy to find.

We were seating pretty quickly and ordered some beers- the selection they have is great. I can understand why it gets so much hype.

Our server was so knowledgeable about each beer and made recommendations based on what we told him. He was also able to point out different things on the menu that were vegan for my friend and what he would recommend. 

Now for the food- I do not understand all the raving about their mussels- I have tried far better in many other local establishments (White Dog Cafe, Twenty Manning just to name a few) as I always seem to order them whenever I go out to dinner. If you are looking for a variety of types of mussels, then Monk's has far more than the usual White Broth or Red Broth variety. Were they good? Yes. Best in the city- absolutely not.  The fries were good, but I wish they came with a few more. I also ordered a burger which was ok. Once again, nothing I would come back specifically for.

Overall, good experience. Not sure if i will be rushing back though unless my friend is looking for some vegan options.
name: Monk's Cafe

text:
went more than 5 years ago but finally getting around to writing a review.  I'm sure the menu has changed since so talking about what I had, which I can't remember anyway, is probably a moot point.  However I want to relay an anecdote of our experience which should give you an idea of the lengths Zahav will go to satisfy you.

I went to dinner here while still dating my girlfriend whom I've since married and we had a fantastic meal.  All the courses were packed with flavor and we could not have been happier but for one thing.  We were still just a little hungry:-)  Our dinner was at 10PM so we were both pretty hungry when we started.  I know I know, this isn't the type of place you'd stuff your face but we wanted to get a little more.  

We asked the server to bring us a menu and ordered a portion of the fish course a la carte.  The fish course was brought to us quickly and as was with the rest of our dinner, fantastic, no surprise there.  The surprise came when we got the bill.  The server must have overheard our conversation about being still hungry and the manager had taken the fish course off our bill.  Mind you we didn't ask for them to do this but I was absolutely delighted that they would do something like this.  Suffice to say I have been singing their praises ever since.  

To me having small portions can sometimes feel like you didn't get your money's worth but in this case, the food, the level of dedication of the staff will make this an experience you will not soon forget.  This place is worth every penny and worth the wait.
name: Zahav

text:
I finally had a chance to try the infamous burger & duck fat fries at Village Whiskey. The fries were good but didn't notice any added flavor from the "duck fat."  I thoroughly enjoyed the burger & fried egg.  The burger patty is very thick and you have to really press down on the roll to fit it in your mouth.  I would prefer if they changed the construction of the patty but that's just me being picky.

If you are in the area Village Whiskey is a solid choice for a great burger.

text:
When my roommate asked me for a Sunday night date spot recommendation, I suggested Tria in a hurry. She's been excited all week for the date she was supposed to have last night. Low and behold, her date cancels 15 minutes prior to their actual meeting time. LAME! So, in good roommate form, I took her out instead. 

Tria offers a Sunday School special where they feature one wine, one cheese and one beer. The featured wine was an Australian Mataro/Shiraz made by Some Young Punks. The bottle is called "Drink'n'Stick." For only $6, we ordered glass after glass. You can't beat a Sunday night at Tria. Even if your date stands you up, find a friend and go.
name: Tria Cafe Wash West

text:
Come here for MARGARITAS.

Absolutely phenomenal margaritas and over 10 flavors. You can also get them served however you'd like or in a pitcher for the table. My favorite was the blood orange! Yum, yum ,yum!

The atmosphere is fun and typical decor of a mexican restaurant/bar. My group and I had great service and you are served complimentary chips and salsas. The salsas are delicious and spicy! Maybe too spicy for some so make sure you have your margarita in hand!

I ordered the chicken tortilla soup and have to say I was very disappointed. In no way is this a traditional tortilla soup. It was more like a chicken and green chili stew...which tasted fine but it isn't what you ordered.
name: Cantina Los Caballitos

text:
I agree with just about everything everyone else has said about the couch: it's amazing.  Definitely my favorite place to get a quick healthy meal in manayunk.  All the wrap menu items can be made as salads, or you can do my favorite, the make-your-own salad.  The ingredients are tiered by price, so it can get a little expensive for a salad if you get a lot of them, but it's well worth it.  The have some of my favorite salad toppings including artichokes, kalamata olives, and gorgonzola (though I am sad they got rid of baby corn).  The white or wheat bread served with all salads is fresh and hot... warm chewy goodness.

Their pizza is excellent as well, especially if you like thin, crispy crust and different toppings.  Try the spinach and feta, yum.  Delivery can be slow, so pick-up is a better option. The outside seating along main street is great in warm weather, and inside the high-top tables, counter seating, and big red couch are nice too.  Definitely come to couch tomato if you're in manayunk!
name: The Couch Tomato Cafe

text: Shake Shack used to just be a place to get a decent burger.  Now, its gone ahead and introduced chicken!  Seriously, this Shake Shack location is clean and welcoming. The have a few beers on tap and all the standard shack offerings in an easy to get to (if you live in the city) location. If you haven't had a shack burger, nothing I'd type would be able to describe it.  Better than 5 guys, not quite In-n-Out, check them out to judge for yourself.

text:
Service was a bit slow but the food totally made up for it. Everything we ordered was AMAZING. 

The lobster and crab mac and cheese was unbelievable. My meal was weeks ago but thoughts of this dish still put a smile on my face. The grilled octopus was the best I've ever had. Roncal cheese was perfectly paired with raw honeycomb. If you've never experienced honeycomb, you have to try it. 

Also great were the baked brie and the fried calamari.

I absolutely recommend this place for a delicious meal - the wait is totally worth it.

text:
My greatest dream for Paesano's is for a 34 year old vegetarian to walk in, order the Potato Arrosto, and then give up vegetarianism for the rest of their life. The Potato Arrosto is no ordinary side dish. It's roasted and then immersed in duck fat and then topped with really pungent Provolone cheese. The potato smells. I was once trapped with it in a car and the windows were rolled up. My gawd, it was as if that potato made an announcement, "I AM HERE!"

Funny thing is, when you get to Paesano's you will want to make your announcement. I sure did. I was excited to find out what this little dive sandwich shop was all about. The first thing I noticed was how small the place was. It was like a greasy spoon with counter seats but it was full of personality. The guys who were running the place were really friendly. One of them was wearing a shirt that said, "Putting the love in your mouth". Really, after locking your eyes on that, how could the ice not be broken? Time to get to that sandwich!

It was about 4 PM and Paesano's had run out of bread. Womp womp. They offered us wraps. And we were like wraps? Is this normal? And the Paesano's guys said when people walk in and all they have are wraps, that is what people take instead of bread. Food is so good at Paesano's that people will take it anyway, in any way and form. Luckily, Paesano's was able to steal back a few loaves from down the street. 

We got four Aristas to go. Some ate theirs that night, others indulged the next morning. I tried mine the next day. I put it in the oven to heat it up a little. The pork was still moist and the cheese melted over the broccoli rabe. The long peppers gave it so much heat that after each bite I yelled, "Wow! That is SPICY! What a kick!" It was a mean sandwich and I want another.

I'm not from Philly so this was a real eye opener to what Philly has to offer in terms of sandwiches other than cheesesteak and Dinic's. I still want Dalessandro's and Dinic's but Paesano's will definitely be another I will be adding to my Must Philly list when I visit. These sandwiches were not made for tourists but Paesano's welcomes out-of-towners with open arms regardless. In fact, they told us to bring our friends and family next time because, obviously, our little group of five was not enough.

Special thanks to Wing "The One with the Cool Hair" L for taking a wrap so the rest of us could have bread.

Special thanks to Stella D for discovering this place.
name: Paesano's Philly Style

text:
The diavalo is the best pizza i've ever had.  Everything about it is perfect - the sopresatta is sliced thin and gets nice and crispy, better than pepperoni and less greasy.  It has just a little spice, the sauce is delicious, and the dough is chewy like it should be.  The other pizzas are really great too, but they don't match the diavalo.  

The salads are always great too - I usually go with the pear or avocado.  The veggies are always fresh and dressed perfectly.  

They don't take reservations but I've never had to wait very long if it is just a party of two.  Even when I do have to wait I don't mind because I can just go grab and drink and they'll call when the table is ready.  

My only complaint is the cocktails.  I've tried several and have always been let down (most of the time they are just too sweet).  But the wines are great so now that I just stay away from the cocktails, I don't even think about it.
name: Zavino

text: awwwwesome (if not best i've ever had) bun tom thit nuong (grilled pork and shrimp with vermicelli noodles) and decent pho (combination pho). pho had a little bit too much star anise herb in it than i usually prefer but it beats the pho in berkeley, CA! and prices are really reasonable for philly. yumm, i'll be back for other things on the menu besides pho. i still like cafe pho ga thanh thanh the best in this area for pho.. though it's for chicken pho.. and i dont know if you can really compare apples and oranges. overall, i'm pretty impressed with the vietnamese food in philly :)

text:
Was here again, this time for post dinner drinks. Per my previous review, it was standing room only - this was expected, it being a Saturday night. Seriously, though, I'd love to hang out here more if it weren't so crowded all the time.

Mayhaps I should switch it to my "off night" rotation, and just never come here on weekends.
