text:
Great place to stop by for a drink! I came by with some friends for happy hour one afternoon and went down to the lower part of the restaurant. There's a dark hall and at the end of it is a door to a smaller bar and a bowling alley. The atmosphere of this place is unique and definitely worth checking out!

Food wise, the meatballs were delicious!  Chicken fried mushroom was a crispy fried mushroom (not sure how chicken fits into it). The burger was just average...

Overall, the good food with a special feel to it. I would recommend checking it out!

text:
Maybe I should have stuck to the dim sum. I tried the sesame chicken. Mistake. It tastes like fried dough drenched in ketchup. I wasn't impressed at all with this dish. I've been spoiled by China Lights in DC which has the best sesame chicken I've ever had. This is one of my favorite meals and there's a spot off City Avenue in West Philly that makes it really well too. Unfortunately, this garden needs to stick to dim sum. 
BUT the brisket and noodles was good. The flavors mended well and the noodles were perfectly cooked. The brisket was fatty but it was still tasty and hot and tender. That is a dish I'd order again and highly recommend to others.
The spring rolls were fine. I liked how much cabbage they had in them. But they are really small so get plenty if you are feeding more than 2 people. 
Ultimately, I think I'd go back for the noodles and the dim sum which they are known for. Don't try your luck on anything else on the menu.
name: Dim Sum Garden

text:
I think that A-OK perfectly describes this spot. It's a very cute, very small BYO tucked away at the northwest corner of 20th and Spruce in the Rittenhouse area. Everything about this restaurant was just right.. Nothing spectacular, but a just right neighborhood restaurant. The food wasn't dazzling, but it was certainly satisfying. The prices were a bit high, but not as high as others in the area, and within range of standard BYOs. The noise level was standard, loud enough that we couldn't hear very quiet talkers well, but not so loud it was distracting. The service was attentive if somewhat moody. 

I was there with a party of 6, and the key highlights from our orders were definitely the mussels, the brussel sprouts, and all three flatbreads. As I read the other reviews, it seems like a common complaint was that a meat dish was over- or undercooked. We ordered primarily small dishes from the antipasta and appetizer menus, no main plates. 

The big update is that they now take reservations Sun-Thurs, so it's not as difficult to get a spot any more!

text:
Great spot for groups! Hosted an event at Tequilas, and they were very friendly and accommodating. Nice atmosphere and good drinks.

Started off with family style appetizers. The empanadas and taquitos were good. The guac had avocado chunks that were a bit too large for my preference. I choose the camarones for my main, and the shrimp were juicy and cooked well. I did have buyer's remorse though. The Cochinita Pibil (pulled pork) was really good.

text: All of the reviews are definitely accurate, great drinks and plates are meant for sharing. The help was extremely knowledgeable and attentive. I would recommend getting ladies and love for cocktails made with fresh celery water + fresh ground pepper.. Extremely refreshing yet potent.  This place is known for their cocktails, so feel free to experiment. We also had the artichokes, spring rolls and olive+grape apps which were also fantastic. I could eat the olive+grape combo for the rest of my life and be perfectly content. For the entree, we had the gnocchis, sausage and wild mushroom rice and I would definitely rank them in that order. The wild mushroom rice was a bit too smokey for the average joe. The lemon cake was absolutely delicious.

text:
Suraya was an amazing experience, and I would highly recommend trying out the place. My friend and I booked a reservation for Sunday evening, and it did not disappoint. Walking into the restaurant, there is a room with a cafe that had a bunch of sandwiches and beverages. It looked like a really neat spot for lunch/brunch, but we were here for dinner. We were seated immediately and were tucked up in one of the elevated platformed seating. There was also an outdoor patio/garden that looked very nice, if it wasn't cold out. The decor was very elegant, and there was a row of seats facing the open kitchen that looked fantastic. 

On to the food. We ordered the baba ganoush to start, and the kafta kebab and karus baladi for our entrees. The place is very vegan friendly, but I will note that if you are allergic to nuts like me, beware because there are a lot of dishes with a variety of nuts. I want to make a special shout out to the pita bread there, which is incredible. They are puffed up like pillows, and baked to perfection. The baba ganoush was delicious, and I personally preferred it to the hummous. The eggplant base was the right amount of flavor with the occasional burst of sweet and tart from the pomegranate seeds. The kafta kebab and karus baladi were grilled and seasoned to perfection as well. I wil say that the kebab and fish were considerably smaller than I was expecting. Suraya can get very expensive as the dishes are small and cost adds up very quickly. Even then, I would definitely recommend this as a staple in the Philly food scene.

text:
I ate at Distrito on Saturday night for my friend's birthday party.  First of all, I love the decor because it's extra girly!  The walls are Pepto Bismol pink, the chairs are covered in a sort of gimp (also known as "boondoggle" - think 1980's summer camp and friendship bracelets) - totally funky and fun! 

Sean, our waiter, was pretty attentive.  

I ordered a Strawberry Boing, which was ok, nothing spectacular though.  Now on to the food.  The food at Distrito is *sigh* GLORIOUS!  I ordered the Queso Fundido, which is like this duck and cheese bake.  They give you these mini tortillas and you can either spoon the QF out and put it on the tortillas or just eat it directly from the baker.  Keep in mind, they serve tapas, so the portions are small.  I also ordered the Platano y Crema (sweet fried plantain with cheese), which doesn't sound all that hot, but it tastes ABSOLUTELY delicious!  My friend ordered the Esquites, which is like this sweet corn, cheese and lime parfait - again doesn't sound too appetizing, but I tasted it and it was fabulous!  We also shared the Encarnacion nachos which were also really good.

 It's rare that you go to a restaurant with a large group and EVERYONE enjoys their food.  Seriously though, I could go back to Distrito to-night!  So for glorious food and fun decor, Distrito gets 5 stars!

text: They do have a very good Belgian beer list.  Obviously.  But I wish they had great Belgian food to accompany it.  I find their menu a downer, the food completely average.  I wish I could even tell you what I ate but it was so absolutely non-memorable that I can't recall.  Admittedly, I am probably judging this place harshly against other great Belgian bars and restaurants I have been to elsewhere in the country, Hopleaf in Chicago setting the bar the highest.

text: I've been to Positano Coast once before for a Bridal Shower and was very impressed. I returned with two co-workers for lunch. I had the Positano Burger, my coworkers had the avocado burger and the gramingna bolognese.  Though our burgers were cooked a bit more than we had hoped, we were all very satisfied with our lunch. The ambiance in restaurant is cool and relaxing. Service was good and our waters were constantly filled.
name: Positano Coast by Aldo Lamberti

text: Cantina is a great spot, regardless of whether you're in the mood for just drinks or a whole meal.  I highly recommend pitchers if you're going with a group.  We've gotten quite a few flavors of the margaritas, as well as the white sangria and the red sangria.    The last time I was here, I indulged myself with some truly killer vegan nachos, but I've also tried the chicken tacos and the bean burritos.  The dishes seem reasonably priced given that we're in the city and the food doesn't usually take too long to come out.  My only beef with this place is that they absolutely refuse to sit your party unless all members are present.  I realize that they are just trying to be fair and efficient, but sometimes the wait for a table can really be quite a while!  I do feel like the food makes up for that, though, so I really can't harbor any resentment against them.
name: Cantina Los Caballitos

text:
Everything we had at this place was delicious!! We ordered the pancake appetizer, mango chicken, and a stewed beef curry dish that the waiter chose for us. The mango chicken was by far my favorite dish!! freshly cut mango perfectly grilled with chicken. The dish may seem a little pricey, but it's a pretty big plate of food.

I would have given this place five stars, but the service was a little slow. by the time our main dishes came out, our appetizers were cold. Still, the food is definitely worth the wait!
name: Penang

text:
My friends and I were seated within 5 minutes of walking into the restaurant. The setting is your typical bar/restaurant, but with wooden table tops that look like someone just cut a tree from their backyard.

I ordered Mexican corn (of course) and Seared Tuna Tacos. This was my first time trying Mexican corn and I was pretty excited. Both dishes came out pretty quickly, which was great because I was starving after watching a movie. The corn was pretty good. I really didn't know what to expect, but all of the flavors worked very well and the corn was charred nicely. The tacos, on the hand, didn't work out so well for me. First, the menu just listed 'Seared Tuna', not indicating it was a taco or burrito. I had thought it was just a seared tuna steak by itself. Second, it's supposed to be seared, the tuna pieces came out well done. They might as well have opened a can of albacore tuna and threw it in a tortilla.

I'll have to give this place another shot. I like their concept of having Mexican and BBQ in the same place, especially if you can combine the two into one dish.

text:
Last time I went to the Memphis Taproom it was Mystery Beer Weekend, I drank beers I didn't like and didn't know the names of. 

I was excited to head back and see what their regular beer list was like, but when I went back and it was German Beer Weekend. This place loves drinking games. I had great food and great service, but had to order a bottled beer, cause I'm just not that into German beer. 

I want my beer to be black. I want it to come out of a tap. Year round.

Went back again for brunch and there was finally a stout on draught! Egg in a nest with roasted mushrooms and an imperial stout make for a good morning. Hopefully they have a festive stouts weekend sometime soon!
name: Memphis Taproom

text:
I was here for brunch yesterday. We went around 1pm and waited for about half an hour. 

I had the eggs benedict, and wow. It was good. I have a few small gripes though - There was too much hollandaise sauce and it was a taad sour. I scraped a lot of it off. I also regretted adding the canadian bacon (regular one was fine). Also, there was also only spinach on one of my eggs and not the other :S But the eggs themselves were great stuff. And that really really made my day.

I also tried some of my friend's french toast, that was a little bit sweet, but not bad.

Service was good considering it was very crowded, my coffee was refilled once. It was incredibly noisy though! We were lucky to get a seat by the windows at the side, so I'd say the noise level was half of what it was inside.
name: Sabrina's Café

text: The experience is worth the trip.  As for the food, the appetizers were delicious- especially the eggplant.  Chicken was OK, but seemed to lack flavor.  The lamb was tender but overly sweet.  Couscous was average.  But I enjoyed my time here. My friend, who spent 5 weeks in Morocco, did not.

text: This is one of those places that really makes me wish there was a 3.5 star option.  They always have a wide variety of beers to choose from, and the bar tenders give great recommendations.  The prices, while not cheap, are not so expensive as to keep me from coming back.  The food I've tried here has been fine.  Not earth-shattering, but fine.  A great spot to meet up with some friends and/or watch a sporting event.

text:
Food was pretty good.  For an Italian BYOB it's pretty typical--too many people crammed into too small a room  I went here with my gf and my aunt (who is diabetic and has a gluten allergy).  We called to make sure they had availabilities and they said they did.  Upon entering the restaurant the owner yelled at me to "shut the door" as if I wasn't cold enough myself.  Then he gave us a dirty look and said "ok, I seat you now, but you have to leave in 1 hour.  We have another party coming".  The food was served quickly...actually a bit too prompt as we received our food before the two parties that arrived and ordered before us.

The entire night the owner and staff kept pointing at us and tried to get us to leave.  The gluten free pasta was very good--according to my aunt--and my food was not too bad either.  Prices were reasonable and if the service was better and the staff weren't complete asses I would come back here.

Service is everything and they bombed it on this front.
name: Giorgio On Pine

text:
I headed here for brunch last weekend with a couple friends and was very pleased with the atmosphere and food. 

We got to the restaurant around 12:30 on a Sunday and the place was pretty crowded.  The hostess told us it would be a 20-45 minute wait, but less time if we opted to sit outside.  The weather was great that day so we said that was fine.

While we waited, we ordered some iced coffee beverages from the coffee bar and sat on the couch.  The food channel was playing on the tv on the wall, which seemed to make all of us that much hungrier (nice tactic).  Within 15 minutes, a table outside was ready and we chowed down.

I got the tofu scramble, which was a tad bland.  I know it's tofu so it's not the most flavorful option, but it didn't seem to be very seasoned at all.  That's okay though, because the two pieces of soy sausage meat that comes with it was bomb.  One of my friends got the blueberry french toast which is spectacular, and another got the breakfast burrito.  It looked enormous and very saucy.  I would have tried some but it has chorizo in it and I don't eat meat.

All in all, Green Eggs Cafe is a really nice brunch experience!  I will definitely go back.
name: Green Eggs Cafe

text: Alas, the chicken was dry.  And I was disappointed since I've been wanting to try it for awhile-- thinking that there must be some magic to this place that sells only fried chicken & donuts... AND is affiliated with Michael Solomonov my hero from Zahav.  The coating was crisp and tasty and hot from the fryer.  But fried chicken's no good if it's not juicy.  I ordered the small sampler box with 4 pieces and a honey glazed donut.  The donut was ... a donut.  No magic here:(

text:
I finally come here after I only start eating little fishies? Gah

After all their burger hype that I can't seem to get away from, I had to check this place out by myself, even though I ordered a fish sandwich, and my friend got the Village Burger. I know good food when i see it, and my friends burger looked good enough to  make me tae a bite out of it, and get sick and throw up later. I resisted, sigh. My Fish Sandwich, goodness was it to die for. Its not easy to find good fish entrees everywhere, and not a big fan of burgers/sandwiches either. This was BADASS! The green chile tartar sauce was a perfect balance to everything else and the actual piece of fish was way bigger than the bun itself, just the way to my heart. What else was badass? The duck fat fries [I couldn't taste the Duck Fat though] but hell they tasted damn good and Ill stuff my face any day, you can even take my sandwich for all i care. 

Nice outdoor seating, it happened to be a lovely late afternoon and very polite and sweet servers.  Too bad was not in the mood for a drink, but absolutely going back. I, for some reason always thought they are expensive, turns out I've easily paid more at other places with less awesomeness.
name: Village Whiskey

text:
McGillin's was the second (and final) stop of the night for a birthday outing with friends last Friday.  Why was it chosen to be the final stop of the night?  Because this was the only place I could think of in which a bunch of r-e-a-l-l-y intoxicated twenty-somethings could: 1. still get in 2. continue to get served and 3. carry on like a bunch of teenagers whose parents went away for the weekend and left the liquor cabinet unlocked.  

Beer is super cheap here, and it should be.  How else could they possibly lure large groups of people into a bar that smells like a high school football team's locker room, post-game?  My sister actually had a more colorful description than that, but I'll spare those details.    

Fun times were had for sure, but I'd rather drink a six pack of Milwaukee's Best in the Bog of Eternal Stench than have to smell the inside of that bar again.
name: McGillin's Olde Ale House

text:
I went here for Sunday brunch with a couple of friends. We got there around 12:30pm. Parking around this time was really hard just because it's a residential area and there are a couple of brunch places in the area. Surprisingly, there was no wait for a table. It's an extremely small place. It's more of like a residential house turned into a café. We were seated in the back, and I asked my boyfriend to switch places with me because I was sitting directly under a fan. The waitress overheard and said she would turn down the fan. 

The menu is really small. On their website, and on yelp, I was expecting a pretty nice menu. It's a piece of paper folded in half with about 10 selections to choose from for food. I got the Genovese Omelet. My friends wanted to get some coffee, but didn't know what they wanted. The waitress asked what they were looking for. My boyfriend said he wanted something strong but not sweet. My friend said she wanted something not strong and sweet. She came back with these really cute lattes and cappuccinos. I may be mistaken about what they were, but they were pleasantly pleased with it.  

The food came out pretty quick. The Genovese omelet was huge. I was not expecting that big of a portion. It was delicious. It was a big filled omelet with avocadoes, pesto, goat cheese, chicken sausages and tomatoes. It was so good, although I'm not a fan of goat cheese, that was the only bad part of it. It came with a skewer of fruits (watermelon, pineapple, cantaloupe) and a small side salad. I was soooo full after this meal. It was huge and totally worth the money. 

The place itself is really small, but the service is fantastic. We had 2 different waiters come up to us and ask if we needed anything or if they could do anything. Our water was always filled. The table is small though, I felt like for 3 people, the table was only meant for two.  The menu is a mix of Lebanese food and French food. They do a great job bringing the two cultures together. 

I'd come back again!

MUST TRY; Coffee drinks; Genovese Omelet

text:
Nine Ting specializes in both hot pot and BBQ dining/all you can eat. Both are popular as dining formats on their own, and at most restaurants, you do one or the other....this is the first place I've been that does both. Like a traditional hot pot restaurant, each table has an induction burner in the center of the table where the hot pot goes.  They also have an infrared grill to cook the grilled foods. The menu is divided into the hot pot side, and BBQ side, and you can order from either or both (for a small upcharge).  They have a very good assortment of both hot pot and BBQ items, including meat, poultry, vegetables and seafood.  

The quality of the ingredients are average to above average. The one exception I had that was seriously deficient was the seaweed salad they bring as a table appetizer. It was obviously low quality, and dyed green. The sesame seeds were green. It was very off=tasting and I'd avoid it. 

The broth for the hot pot was very bland..I had the Chinese Herb and the Pork Bone. I was able to fix the up a bit by adding some chicken bouillon that they have at the sauce bar, which has a number of great ingredients for sauces . 

The infrared grill is ostensibly cheaper than a gas setup, but is not nearly as hot.  It took a long time to cook, and didn't sear the meet as well as I'd like.  I was able to turn up the heat all the way, and this helped somewhat. 

Overall, the place is just OK.  If you want top-notch hot pot, there are places that do it better. If you want BBQ, there are places that do it better.  If you want a place that does both, this is a decent, affordable, but not an outstanding option.
name: Nine Ting

text:
YES.

I was so worried that this place was going to turn out to be another overrated, cliche, "best-of-but-really-just-kinda-meh" place. But it did not disappoint. The Arista is a work of art in itself, dripping in juices, with flavors coming at you from all sides. Part of me feels bad for eating a baby pig that, in my imagination, was ripped mid-suckle from its mother just to be slaughtered, pulled, and made into a meal. The rest of me is telling that one part of me to just shut up and understand how to appreciate a darn good sandwich.

Very very happy right now :)

text:
We came here one night to get drinks and sat at the bar. The place is beautifully decorated and is pretty large. We sat at the bar for 10 minutes before our bartender came to take our order. I ordered some fruity drink with gin in it. It was good but nothing overly special. 

We went downstairs to check out the bowling alley area, because we were thinking about coming back another time to go bowling. It was a small area with only one bowling lane. You pretty much have to book a private party to bowl here and that's too much work, so I guess we won't be coming back.

text:
I was super stoked to try Village Whiskey. For whatever reason my travels never brought me here until the other night with a good friend. I was ecstatic! 

First of all, this place would have gotten four stars from me had our service not been lacking.

My friend and I ordered an order of Herb Cherry Tomatoes for an appetizer, an order of the Shortrib and Cheddar French Fries and two burgers. 

Here's where the problem started - for those of you who had been to Village Whiskey, the place is tiny. So instead of bringing out the tomatoes as an appetizer and then waiting a few minutes for the burger/fries, all of our food came out at once which made us feel rushed and overcrowded. I am assuming (I could be wrong) that our waitress did not go and get our tomatoes early enough because there is no way it takes the same amount of time to assemble some tomatoes and cook a few burgers and fries so that was a negative.

The food was great. I don't think I have ever seriously tasted a serving of french fries as good as the shortrib fries. They just melted in my mouth and the kind of cheddar used was still something I am trying to pinpoint. Warning though, these fries are RICH so tread lightly and share with a friend.

I really enjoyed my burger as well. HUGE and tasty but just slightly on the dry side. Nothing I wouldn't come back for as I had leftovers for the next day that everyone at work was envious of! 

Our tomatoes were yummy. I described them to my friend as a "big burst of sunshine in my mouth." Yum!

We ended our meal and were sitting there for quite some time until we asked another waiter to possibly get our waitress so we could get our check. The waiter (who had not served us before) said "Oh, I didn't know you were finished." and grabbed our check. Our waitress had apparently left and didn't let us know that another waiter would be taking over or to thank us in the slightest. 

I just felt for such a great reputation I expected a little more than just a sit down and throw some food on the table kind of experience. All in all I would come back and hopefully receive some better service...and chow down on some shortrib fries!

text:
Came here for brunch on a Saturday and of all things as a Marylander, I ordered the crab cake benedict.  I never order crab cakes outside of Maryland, but as I read over the menu, I kept coming back to it.  It was not a bad choice at all.  It was cooked properly and the cake had just enough "filling" to bind the crab together.  This is how it's supposed to be done! 

They also run a special for HH brunch with inexpensive drinks.  I had what was essentially a whiskey mimosa.  It was tasty and you could definitely taste the alcohol.  

Service was okay as it was definitely a little slow to get our order in, and the food took awhile to come out.  However, this would not deter me from returning.

text:
I came here for a team lunch and every single plate that a Pietro's waiter put down ... it was picked up 5 mins later. We weren't even done w our apps and they started clearing it out.  They did the same for our entrees ... like seriously let us at least finish our 3rd bite. I look down at my phone for one second to chk emails and my food is gone... no one even asked if I was done.  I understand you have to turn tables but can the patrons at least eat first instead of being rushed out.

Food was good here but I would have liked to have been given the opportunity to eat it.   Unfortunately, i will not return to Pietros and will no longer recommend this spot to my company.

text:
Decor and ambiance are great. This is a great place for drinks with an awesome vibe and a good mix of people. However, the reason why I'm giving this place 2 stars is because of the food. In my opinion, food is overpriced, and just not very good, at least the things that I have tried. 

I will return for drinks, but will pass on the food.
name: El Vez

text:
Yes! Another great brunch place! :) 

Came here twice already on a weekend and it was delicious both times. Of course, I got crepes both times and thank goodness I came with three other people because we were able to sample a bit of everyone's food. Everything was delicious! 

The sweet crepes were typical of what crepes normally about so I don't quite think it's worth the price. However, they are delicious (see pics)! Their hazelnut ice cream is YUM! The only problem I have with them is that they can become overly sweet after a few bites because it sure is a lot of sugar. I'd definitely split with someone if you could and get one sweet crepe and one salty one. 

As for salty crepes, the two I got to try were delicious! The ingredients were fresh and everything tasted very well balanced. On the weekends, they have a special brunch menu of crepes you can savor. Definitely try the Scrambled Eggs with Roasted Poblano Peppers, Tomatoes, Swiss Cheese,Avocado Corn Salsa & Caramelized Tomato Sauce.  The Creamed Spinach, Grilled Chicken, Tomatoes & Swiss (see pic) is one of the "House Recommended Savories" and I thought this was really yummy also (I replaced the creamed spinach with sauteed). 

Either way, definitely check this place out. There is also plenty of seating inside so it won't be too hard to get a seat (unlike Sabrina's and Morning Glory). It is also very cutely decorated  and they also have patio seating. 

The downside of this place: it's a bit pricey and service can be a bit slow on the weekend if there are a lot of patrons.
name: Creperie Beau Monde & L'Etage

text:
I am a born and raised Philly native, had a friend visiting so took him to the Reading terminal, figured it's worth a shot to try a cheesesteak from one of the best foodery's in Philly. Waited 55 mins in total to order and receive our order....
The order: Italian hoagie, they ran out of hoagie rolls only had cheesesteak rolls. 
A cheesesteak whiz with. Couldn't get a side of mayo, didn't have spicy mustard and forgot to ask for ketchup and it was no where to be found. 

Over all the hoagie was decent, however there are plenty of other places in the city that don't take 50 mins to prepare your hoagie and gives you condiment options on the side. 

The cheesesteak: if I had to put a rating on it I'd give it a 2.4 out of 50. I could get a better quality cheesesteak at the subway... not the hoagie chain. The meat tastes like hamburger helper, worse steakums. The "whiz" which is a sin to even call it whiz was fake nacho cheese you can get at your local movie theater. The "with" had a few scraps of onions. 
We had limited time to get my friend a true cheesesteak and this place sucked an hour of our time for garbage. Not worth it. Go anywhere else. 

Only giving two stars cause the Italian had decent meats. Please also note I never leave reviews like this but I'm that frustrated with the experience and the lack of quality.
name: Carmen's Famous Italian Hoagies

text:
Im too full to type.

Stopped by Sketch in Fishtown and figured I'd find out what all the burger buzz is about.  Love Canvas, -sure gotta say that the way rap singers thank Jesus on awards shows right? it's true though.

Figured, ok, might as well go for the gold.  I ordered a Kobe beef burger for $9.60 and a bottle of water to wash it down = just over $11.  

But that's not all!
no.  There's more!

I was considering the sauces to choose from and went with the first, the Harissa Aoili, which the nice girl at the register recommended and when I went looking at the cheeses, she admitted it really doesn't need it.  Im glad she was honest because she was dead on right.   So I grab my bottle of wooder and sit down for my 20 min wait.  (made fresh, whatta ya want, fast foood? well golly, no.)  Ok, so it arrives with a smile to my table and oh yeah it's surrounded by a mote of cheese balls.  Oh, I didn't need them, I ate em though.  

VERDICT: best damn burger I ever had.  Really.  I heard people say such silly things before but I knew it was just BS.  Now this damn burger turned me into one of these over dramatic exaggerators!  

The rumors of the ecstasy shake piqued my interest but my gut is happy I went with the bottle of wooder.  Next time perhaps.

I wanna go back and see what the Smashed Onion Burger is about, but doubt the Kobe will allow me to cheat on it.
name: Sketch Burger

text: This place is always packed on the weekends which is a great sign. The indoor space is beautiful and so is the outdoor section. I only had the opportunity to try an appetizer and wine. I enjoyed the atmosphere and look forward to trying dinner here.

text: Got takeout here via caviar app. Got the gnocchi per my cousins recommendation. They were very good but almost reminded me of like a sweet potato or cauliflower gluten free gnocchi. Not sure if they are or not to be honest. The truffle cream sauce was good but it was very strong and I couldn't eat a ton of it. I managed to scarf down the entire dish despite how full I was because I did enjoy the cloudy texture of the gnocchis. Wel made even tho they seemed veggie based ? Overall I wouldn't want to get this specific dish again. It was very yummy but idk. Too strong for me. Interested in different dishes here though. Great quick service food came hot and fresh.
name: Bistro Romano

text:
Such a great dinner for 2 seated outside to take in the one day break in humidity! 

I think I had the best heirloom tomato salad of my life. Honestly. I sat there and tried to figure out why it was so good...and still can't quite put a finger on it. It comes topped with basil (duh) as well as a watercress salad with lightly pickled shallots. Large portion (1 whole tomato) 5 slices total. I love it. This is the definition of summer!

My skate was also very tasty! Cooked perfectly and...butter, butter, butter. So not much can be wrong with that...unless you don't like butter...which might be a whole other set of problems for  you and I'm so sorry.
name: Parc

text:
My review for Green Eggs Cafe is purely based on the takeout experience I had awhile back, so I have no idea what the dining is like in-house.  What I will say is that when ordering something called "the Kitchen Sink" do not expect it to be light or delicate.  Personally, after waking up drooling on the floor of my office several hours later from the biggest food coma I have ever experienced, I am surprised that I wasn't left with permanent brain damage.

In all seriousness, GEC has now made the list of places for to-go work lunches, what with the ease in ordering something for pick-up and the friendly staff at the counter.  Yeah, it's an extra quarter for the takeout container charge, but I think it used to be $2 so complaining about a quarter is meh in comparison.
name: Green Eggs Café

text:
I ordered delivery via Eat24 and sadly did not have a good experience with regards to the food. I ordered the "Rittenhouse Square" roll, added avocado and requested no "bonito flakes". I don't know what was on the roll (it did look like dark flakes), and overall the roll was falling apart. Worst of all, it smelled terribly unappetizing and was very off-putting. The closest thing I can compare it to would be the dry, flaking fish food that you drop into fish tanks.

 I called Eat24 and told them I wouldn't be able to eat it. Thankfully I was issued a refund but had to throw away my order. I've seen that Bleu Sushi has good reviews and perhaps I'll give them another shot, but only in person. No more delivery for me.
name: Bleu Sushi

text: I don't think I have ever been more offended by a cheese steak in my entire life. I had high hopes stopping in here; staff seemed friendly enough, I had heard good things, and I really liked the look of the inside. However, none of that can overshadow me having the worst cheese steak ever made. Each and every bite I took had an overload of cartilage to the point that I literally started gagging. I opened it up and through the cheese, I saw about 30% of my cheese steak was fat! A few pieces here and there are understandable and even welcome, but this was just poor quality meat overall. I will never, ever enter this place again.
name: Campo's Philly Cheesesteaks

text:
Maybe its a sign that my college days really and truly are behind me. But last night at this spot - what a let down. It use to be my go-to happy hour place for half price margaritas, drafts and wings. Five of us were there at 5:50 (happy hour is until 6:30), and the waiter seemed determined not to let us order. Of the laundry list of my complaints - 

- We asked 3 different people working at the restaurant if a bean dip was vegetarian when ordering - no one ever got back to us with an answer, but brought it out anyway, and we kept asking after it was brought out. Still no answer. 

- None of the happy hour specials were discounted on our bill because our waiter waited until after 6:30 to put everything in. The very kind manager corrected it for us. 

- Same waiter put an 18% grat on our check when their menu says that's for parties of 6 or more (there were 5 of us). I'm the girl where 18% is usually the lowest I tip... but this guy just rubbed me the wrong way. 

The food was alright, the drinks were watery, and my nostalgia for time spent there as a poor college student have been distressed.
name: Mad Mex - University City

I'm taking away a star for the quality of fish. but otherwise, would recommend it for tastiness and the ambiance.

text: We went here on a Saturday night before our concert at The Mann.   Parking is extremely tight and the lot is hard to maneuver.  It was a nice night and we opted to sit outside.   We started with the whipped ricotta and the pepperonata.  Both were served in mason jars with crusty Italian bread.  Very good and would recommend.  I choose the gnocchi but substituted the lamb and olive from the gemelli dish.   It was somewhat salty and a little greasy. My friend had the bucatini which she said was delicious.  I had the pear cider which was very refreshing.   My friend had two celli cocktails.  Our waitress told us that all the pasta is homemade daily.  Decent restaurant, close to The Mann.

text:
Headed here for brunch on this rainy chilly Sunday. Got seats at the bar at 11 am, no waiting. Service was great, bartender was friendly and attentive.  Atmosphere is awesome - oldies playing, tight tables, but really wonderful energy.  Tasty bloody mary - spicy, lots of garnishes, $6!  So... why the 2 stars?  The food, unfortunately.  I ordered the smoked salmon benedict.  Salmon was good, but too little hollandaise and the poached eggs were over cooked!  As in hard yolks.  Surprised to encounter that at a place with such great brunch reviews! Side potatoes were just meh, I left most of them. 

Having said that... My companion got the reuben, and the bite I had was AWESOME. Love that they will do both fries AND a salad (a little of both) as sides for sandwiches.  And the burger list looked great.  I know my folks will like this place, so the next time they visit we will give it another shot.
name: The Sidecar Bar & Grille

text:
Dan Dan looks small and unassuming from the outside, but it's larger than it looks and houses a second floor dining area. It is tight quarters, but they can pack it in. As other Yelpers mention, it is overpriced compared to other good Chinese food options. With that said, the food was good and the service satisfactory. 

We were here for lunch and the lunch specials ranged in price from $10.45 - $12.95. Again, a bit higher than you would expect for Chinese lunch options and the portions are adequate, but not very large. 

We ordered the Dan Dan noodles as an appetizer. They were very tasty, but make sure you can bear the heat, because they are spicy. For lunch my table ordered Cumin with Chicken, Dry Pot with Chicken and Garlic Sauce with Pressed Tofu. The Cumin and Garlic sauce were both tasty. The Hot Pot was a bit of a let down, because it was the dish with the highest spiciness level, yet was bland and paled in comparison to the 1-star spice level of the Garlic Sauce dish.
name: Dan Dan

text: One Shot Coffee is a whimsical, refurbished place near the heart of NoLibs, offering delicious Stumptown Coffee and various breakfast items for purchase.  They have a myriad of interesting coffee and hot chocolate drinks which are worth scoping out, though prices are really steep and I definitely get the jitters from their coffee after a few hours.  Friendly, scatterbrained service and happy smiles all around!  Decent street parking is available in the early mornings.

text:
Soho is over-exaggerated and not even as tasty as what my friends have been raving about this entire time. The food i very expensive and the chicken wings aren't the best in Philadelphia or even 'addicting' like people say. The chicken wings are a dollar a piece and have a lot of sauce in it. The taste wasn't what I expected but overall was O.K. Not anything special in my opinion. 

Overall, the place is designed modern and cool and gets a lot of customers (very popular among young Asian people). And the waitresses and waiters are kind and down-to-earth. The place is smaller than I expected, but overall was pleasant to sit in and just talk and eat among friends. The only bad side is how expensive that is, and is the only reason why I don't like going there(also because of an incident where I asked to package my noodles to go and they packaged it for me, only to have it spill just outside the restaurant because they put it in a styrofoam container and the noodle had spicy sauce in it. Regrettably, the waiter was dumb enough to not put it in a quart container and ruined my pants that I was wearing. No I was not swinging the bag wildly from side to side. ) However, the place looks wonderfully modern and hip, but the food is overpriced, and over-exaggerated,and UN-fulfilling to be honest. I thought the 16$ noodle dish I bought was too overpriced for the amount they gave me and the chicken wings in all four sauces were just not as good as what everyone says it is.
name: Café Soho

text:
For the longest, I wanted to visit to one of the best steakhouses in the city, Del Frisco's, and Center City restaurant week made it happen. I dined in for the lunch menu for 3 courses for $20 and left satisfied! I enjoyed a creamy lobster bisque, filet mignon and a generous slice of cheesecake.

I arrived with a large group for lunch without a reservation and although it was booked, the manager was able to wrangle us up a table. The bisque had chunks, yes chunks, of delicious lobster and slight kick of flavor. Plus, I had the best piece of steak ever! The 6oz Filet Mignon was tinder and flavorful and enough to leave me stuffed. Plus, the roasted mashed potatoes was the perfect side to the dish. The only con on my visit, but not worth taking away a star, is I ordered the chocolate mousse dessert to-go. Instead, they packaged me a cheesecake. It wasn't bad since it was good but cheesecake isn't my favorite dessert. 

The decor is beautiful as well. I couldn't help but to be left in awe of this place. As if lunch couldn't be better, our waiter had the best personality and kept was laughing. I definitely recommend this place to the steak lovers but I also heard great reviews on the salmon filet and seasonal salads.
name: Del Frisco's Double Eagle Steakhouse

text:
I came for a lunch. The place is small and packed. But, the food comes out fairly quick upon order. And you do not pay until you actually get the food. 
My only complaint, they have no bathroom and I had to go very bad. 
They have a small counter to eat at or take out. 
I did a take out. 
The Cheese Steaks are made to order. They are large in size. It is flavorful and a standard cheesesteak. 
It was large enough I shared it with other people.

Nothing needed improvement. Maybe, house made rolls would make it better. 
But, it is what it is a standard Cheesesteak joint with a really high reputation.
name: Dalessandro’s Steaks & Hoagies

text:
Yum! I've been meaning to try this spot for some time now and decided that going on a little V-Day Lunch Adventure was just what I needed today. Turns out it was a great choice!

Love the space. Very casual and fun. Feels like being in a market/kitchen area. I didn't get a chance to browse the initial cheese, charcuterie, and dessert counter but I will be coming back in the near future to do so! From what I saw there was a chocolate cake with bacon peanut butter icing...MMMM yes please

I ordered the half sandwich and soup combo. The pasta fagioli was very fresh and perfectly cooked. Now, the cuban sandwich was amazing. I'm pretty picky about these and I loved mine. The bread was crispy & thin. The portion of meat was generous. Homemade pickles and mustard....plus untraditional gruyere cheese. Delish and absolutely recommend!

text: The service is excellent.  I went to the restaurant twice in one week.  The polenta is the best I have ever tasted.  Creamy, buttery, flavorful and complements the meatball that comes with the dish.  So amazing.  I also got the Sunday Gravy dish.  If you are a fan of Italian meats, this is the dish for you.  Short rib, meatball and sausage...YUM!  The only dish that was average was the Arancini.  I also got a pasta dish recommended by the waitress and it was amazing.  It was short rib with pappardelle in a light cream sauce.  I can't wait to go back!

text: The Turkish Coffee shake at Goldie is one of my favorite things to ever hit my lips. I've tried all of their shakes, the falafel salad, as well as falafel pita sandwich. Everything is fresh and delicious, and the space is adorable. The staff are friendly (and speedy) which makes this a great quick bite or a leisurely sit down spot too. This is the OG location, but the others are great as well!

text: The three stars are only for their dumpling and relatively good service comparing with other restaurants in Chinatown. Although the restaurant name includes "dim sum", this is not really a dim sum restaurant! I would say it's a typical Chinese restaurant with a few more options for dumplings. I had their beef noodle soup, my friend had their ride dish, both were just average. Although I liked their dumpling, I won't go back.

text:
Beware of the salt! 

I came here last night on a date and ordered the Caesar Salad. It looked unique and came with hush puppies instead of croutons, which sounded delicious. Darling, I took one bite of this salad and could hardly get it down it was so salty. I am a huge fan of salt, perhaps too much, but this was disgusting. I had to send it back. Our server asked if I wanted another without the "added salt" and I declined. I was so turned off. I told him I would just wait for dessert. 

My date ordered the hot chicken buns and said they were way too buttery. 

Well, when dessert came, I was equally as disappointed. I am a die hard fan of funfetti cake and was really excited to try theirs. Little did I know, their icing is cream cheese icing. Disgusting. Who in their right mind puts cream cheese icing on funfetti cake!? You monsters! 

Finally, when we were eating dessert, we were asked 6 times if we were done yet. 6! Twice by our server, once by the hostess (why was she even doing that?), and three times by other staff. I don't know if somebody had reserved this specific table for a time (it was a 2 person table by the window), or if they could tell we weren't going to spend any more money there, but we felt like we were being pushed out. There were plenty of other seats around us open, so it's not like they needed the space...The last time we were asked if we were finished, I had to ask the guy "do we need to go? Does somebody need this seat or something?" And he said no, but another person came back 2 minutes later. 

The only things I enjoyed about this experience was their rose wine (one of the best I have ever had), and their server, Dave. He was a cool cat and seemed understanding.

text:
We went here for restaurant week and I liked that the special menu was the only option at the time, as you knew they were going to put extra effort into the dishes. They had a cheese and meat board options as the first course, which was the perfect option as there were two of us. They served us bread right before and did not tell us that was the bread that was also meant for our cheese board, which would have been nice to know. They do let you try a variety of balsamic and olive oils that you can pour yourself which was fun.

We both ordered the mussels next, and the sauce was absolutely wonderful, we both wanted to scrape our bowls clean. At least four of the shells weren't open, so I do wish that the kitchen staff had been more thorough in checking. 

I ordered the carbonara, which was mouth-watering delicious. I'm not a huge pasta person and the sauce was addicting. I ended up eating the leftovers first thing the next morning. The chocolate mousse was disappointing, as it was not as rich as I hoped, and the pistachio on top did not taste like anything. 

Four stars is the perfect overall rating for this place. Our server was wonderful, but he was very busy and running around the whole time. The food was very good, but it was not very unique or earth shattering for the reputation of the chef. The beers are at least $10 and the wine selection lacks variety.

text:
Great brunch spot. 

Very close to Honey's so we checked the wait time for both. They both said 20 minutes but Cafe La Maude only took 5 minutes so they were the winner!

We were greeted by a guy who I think was the owner and he was very friendly and welcoming. 

The menu at first glance looks amazing. Great mix of classic, innovative and Middle Eastern brunch dishes. We had a pretty hard time deciding but the Parisian Za and Tiramisu pancakes (say what?!) won out. Very happy with the choices. Parisian za was styled like a croissant pizza with caramelized onions, goat cheese, and truffle. With potatoes and eggs on the side. Worked really well and looked and tasted great.

Tiramisu pancakes - just Wow. Pancakes had lady fingers and coffee flavor baked into them, covered in delicious tiramisu mascarpone, strawberries, cream, and chocolate chips, as well as a few fruit purées on the side. I think the best pancakes I've ever had.

text: Just went to Morimotos with family to celebrate my brother-in-laws birthday. The atmosphere is very cool and chic which we all enjoyed. They have a pretty extensive drink menu, but we stuck with the Morimoto beers which were really good (my favorite was the hazelnut flavored beer).  For appetizers, we shared an assortment of sushi rolls which were excellent - our favorites were the shrimp tempura roll and soft shell crab roll. We also tried the seared scallops which were rather delicious, but I must admit - I've had better. Finally for dinner, I had the soba carbonara which is Morimotos take on Italian. It was absolutely amazing...soooo delicious! Our party also had the Japanese kobe beef steak (which was a special for the evening). It was very tasty but not worth the price. We shared some of the wasabi fried rice which was a nice variation than typical fried rice, but not as good as the seasonal veggie which was brussel sprouts. Those brussel sprouts were the best any of us have ever had. Since the waitress knew that it was my brother-in-laws birthday, they brought out complimentary chocolate sorbet with a candle in it. It was a great finale to the meal! Overall, our dinner was rather good, but I'm not sure it was 100% worth what we paid. It's an experience to go to Morimotos the food was definitely good, and the service was prompt and friendly but I can't justify giving them 5 stars when I think they're overpriced.

text:
Good choice for a casual brunch/lunch, especially when meeting up with friends.

Mac and cheese appetizer is a large portion great for sharing, or to order while you're waiting for the rest of the food.

Turkey club sandwich is too tall to properly eat.  Turkey is dry (although fresh), so be sure to order extra mayo on the side.

Caesar salad has a very weak and slightly acidic dressing, it's not really a traditional version, but it's good.

Omelette's are huge and cooked great.  Feel free to order off menu and make your own special requests.

Pancakes are also huge, we usually order a plate with brunch for the table to share.

The green shake sounds kinda gross (spinach and yogurt...) but it's actually really, really good.  If you're not starting off brunch with this, you should be ordering the bloody mary or mimosa.

The staff is really attentive, the busboys almost too much so as they'll be there to clear your plates as each person finishes.  You almost get the impression that they're rising to get you out the door so they can turn the table, and then you look-up and see the 4 groups of friends and 2 small families pushing strollers waiting for one of the tables to free up.

Come early or come late, but "just after church" is by far their busiest time so be prepared to wait.

text:
I have been to Buddakan twice now- once for restaurant week about 2 years ago (great deal) and most recently in July of this year for my husband's birthday. I planned to get a group of 10 people together to surprise my husband and we ended up having an AMAZING dinner.

we sampled a ton of appetizers from the tuna tartare spring rolls to the rock shrimp bao buns to the pork belly to ALL sorts of dumplings (edamame, crab & lobster, shrimp and chicken & ginger). Everything was phenomenal. We all had our own entrees so I can't speak for everyone but I had the wasabi tuna tataki and it was delicious. 

Our service was great, our server handled the large group VERY well. We were seated a little bit after our reservation time but were not much bothered by it as we were enjoying a drink at the bar anyway. In general, I love the decor and the whole space, but was just a little disappointed by our table which was the closest to the kitchen and didn't have an excellent view of the room (although I had my back to the room and was facing the kitchen). Regardless, both of my visits have been full of good drinks, even better food, and excellent service so I would not hesitate to come back! My two cents: if you want an asian-fusion Starr restuarant, I prefer Buddakan to Morimoto :)

text:
Interesting. 

I came to this place last night because it fulfilled all of my requirements: relatively close to my location, had mojitos, and the only thing that really matters: nachos.

This place has pretty regal stairs at its entrance, although I'm not difficult to impress. The ambiance is dark with a dimly lit interior and very unique decor. Reminds me of an old-school library actually. 

We slid ourselves onto two corner bar seats and were presented immediately with menus. 

I, being the rebellious bitch that I am, ordered two things I could not find on the menu however insisted on consuming anyway. They were kindly able to accommodate my request for a michelada AND nachos (even though the interwebz menu contained nachos). Despite the fact that I don't really care that much about the details regarding nachos, I inquired and the bartender stated the toppings included cheese, beans, lettuce, tomatoes, onions, and chicken or beef. I, obviously, requested no onions and no meat. A-$ was craving a mojito. 

The drinks came first. I haven't had a michelada in a while so it was quite a pleasure to reunite that shit with my tongue. mmmm, those spices! I am particularly partial to a beverage with a nice kick. 

As a side note, the menu contains a shitload of margaritas and tequila options (DUH). In retrospect, I feel silly having not ordered this but the heart wants what the heart wants. 

One of the bartenders slid a plate of tortilla chips in front of us with the side of guac I ordered with the nachos and a smoky, chipotle-flavored salsa. Thankfully, the salsa didn't have giant chunks of a bunch of shit I don't like and was instead, nice and smooth. The bartender sneakily slipped a bowl of some shit resembling pico de gallo next to the salsa. 

The tortilla chips were delicious. Not a stale, knock-off version of tostitos provided by some other places. The salsa was smoky and the guac flavorful. Some time passed. I began to panic this was the nachos I ordered. I marched up to the other end of the bar with the bartender and aggressively inquired about what we had been served, assuming this was the nachos. He kindly informed me that the nachos were coming, and not to worry. PHEW.

The nachos did arrive. They were a medium-sized plate of a bunch of fucking delicious tortilla chips completely covered in cheese with a bean-paste underneath. Two tomato slices were gently placed on top. 

While this wasn't quite what I had in mind, who can complain about a plate of delicious chips covered in a thick and juicy layer of melted cheese? I may be full of shit here being a white american girl from westchester, ny but I feel like this is more authentic and what one might expect from nachos in the motherland (mexico). 

Ultimately I was very satisfied. I did notice that the menu was on the steep side. This is a cool spot with a great and unique ambiance. I would definitely check it out if you're in the mood to break away from the generic restaurant mold.

PS-A we both placed our cards in the little glass that contained our check but the people only charged Addie's (thank god). He's such a gentleman that he declined my offer to venmo him. In any case, this is actually pretty annoying. I'm not an expert in the hospitality industry but it shouldn't be hard to charge both cards when they're clearly both present in the bowl.

text:
The wait for a ramen place in Philly is over, thank heaven.  Though Terakawa doesn't compare to other ramen places in NYC (sorry, folks), this Chinatown hideout is a wonderful alternative if you suddenly get the craving for a hot, tasty bowl of Japanese noodles.

Aside from the brief spurt of annoyance at being charged for hot green tea, I was pleasantly happy with the miso ramen.  Cha siu was plenty flavourful and the poached egg was perfectly marinated and set to the right consistency.

Service was incredibly friendly, no doubt because we were one of the few customers around on a late Friday night, and our server doted on us to make sure we were plenty happy with our meal.  Considering how cheap our total was at the end of the night, you bet we'll be back for more.

text:
I liked the deco of this place - Not the average Chinese restaurant deco. The place is clean, servers are friendly. I just ordered some appetizers go with my drinks, they are all tasty and flavorful beside the Sichuan bean noodle(I think this is what it's called). The drink "chengdu" is very good, I had 3, couldn't get enough. Somehow, the "tiger lily" tastes like dish cleaner or something, kinda weird. 

The only reason I'm taking one star off is because I don't think the dishes are truly authentic, although I do think they did a good job on food. I will go back again for sure.

text:
I like the chips and guacamole and liked the cheese sprinkles on top. My friend and I ordered the $35 set menu of chips/guac/salsa, shrimp cerviche (a little on the sweet side), arugala salad (spicy and yummy, but again a little on the sweet side), mushroom flatbread that was a little too mushroom-y for my taste, and sirloin steak that came with a pretty good cheesy risotto and baked black beans and rice. For dessert we had a mini flan which was very very sticky (pieces actually stuck to the spoon).

Overall the experience was nice, but the food was just okay, and the service, depending on the person, was inconsistent. The guy we had didn't want to explain each item, was vague about how many plates we should order (since it was our first time there), and out of a bit of frustration we jumped at ordering the set menu. The woman who brought out the food was clear, detailed and nice. The decor is cute and fun - just be prepared for PINK.
name: Distrito

text:
Little Fish has been on my list of "must trys" for quite some time now. More specifically, the Sunday Tasting Menu. Thanks to having MLK Day off, we were able to take advantage of the BYO restaurant without worrying about going to work the next day with a slight wine headache.

We opted for the 8pm reservation and arrived promptly at 8pm to be seated without any delay. Our waitress quickly took our bottle of wine to be chilled. The first course was brought out, which was a salad with a blood orange vinaigrette. Following the salad was a Tuna tartar which was amazing. The tuna was fresh, the jalapenos added some heat, and the garlic sauce really brought the dish perfectly together.

Following this second course, out came a potato puree soup with a perfectly cooked scallop with leeks and a dried mustard. I couldn't get enough of this soup.  I do wish there was a little bit more of a sear to the scallop, but it was still as close to perfect as a scallop can come. 

During this dish, my husband and I looked at each other, somewhat disapointed, wondering if this was the 3rd course and was this supposed to be an entree? does that make dessert next? We were still hungry and wondering if we made a mistake to our dinner choice. Much to our surprise, out came a 4th course, much more of the entree we were looking for. They came out with cobia? Which I had never heard of previously, and it was amazing! It reminded me of a swordfish, but so much better!

The dessert was good- not amazing. But I dont think someplace like "Little Fish" should be known for desserts.

Overall, an amazing meal, especially for the price point of $33 for this 4/5 course tasting menu.

I will warn future visitors- the table next to us let the waitress know he had a nut allergy- and he seemed to have to miss out on a few elements of each course. If you have an allergy, I would recommend calling ahead to let them  know or ask what the tasting menu consists of- it might not be worth it to you if you have this kind of allergy, as everyone is served the exact same meal throughout the courses!
name: Little Fish

text: One of the best in Philadelphia. The kofta kebab is amazing with rice and a side salad, and the LEMONADE HERE IS AMAZING. The ambiance is perfect for a date, for a group of friends, for families with little kids, it clearly is a favorite among both college students and residents of the West Philly community, as well as the surrounding Muslim population. They also have a great little side area for the bakery where people often just come and sit with laptops and order tea or smoothies or baklava and it is a great, quiet ambiance. I absolutely love this place.

text:
If you're craving soup dumplings or Xiaolongbao (XLB) in Philly, the one place you have to check out is Dim Sum Garden. Highly praised by Iron Chef Jose Garces, DSG offers cheap, and most importantly, delicious bites. How good is it? Iron Chef Garces sources his soup dumplings from DSG for his new Revel Casino restaurant, Yuboka. The one caveat associated with DSG? It used to be in a dumpy location behind Reading Terminal Market.

But all that's changed now - DSG has moved to a better location on Race Street, replete with a sleek interior design. So before heading to Hop Sing Laundromat for some drinks, the GF and I met up with some friends for good eats in Chinatown.

The Da family came to Philly in 2008 to represent Shanghai's style of dim sum. The head chef, Shizhou Da, is the fifth generation of the original four chefs who created the first soup dumping. With the assistance of her daughter, who runs the front of the house, they've created a restaurant that's becoming a popular spot for Philadelphians to grab a delicious bite.

DSG does take reservations, though it seems as though this simply gets you a table quicker, rather than providing you with a seat at a designated time. Still, without one, you'll be waiting in line for a bit. On a Saturday night around 7:30PM, the line was about half an hour deep, though the turn around was relatively quick.

Pro tip? DSG is BYO! So bring on some bubbly or some wine to pair with your dim sum and start your night off right.

Pan Fried Beef Dumplings [$5.75]

But on to the food. Dishes here come as they're prepared so don't expect any sort of coursing. But no matter. We started off with deliciously gluttonous pan fried dumplings, with a meaty exterior that was nicely crisp. And inside? Sweet and savory pork. These gorgeous bites are meant to dipped in the vinegar and chili oil provided at the table.

Vegetable Fried Rice [$7.50]

The veggie fried rice was really good as well. Though a bit salty, you could taste each individual grain of rice, which was the main component for this melange of scallions, eggs, and carrots. This was a larger portion than it looks and was quickly devoured.

Double Shredded Pork with Garlic Sauce over Noodles [$6.95]

The pork with garlic sauce was available to come atop rice or noodles. The noodles were clearly hand-crafted and simply amazing. It's a bit cumbersome to eat for date night, so I'd advise you not to wear a crisp white shirt. But the noodles are definitely worth it - the texture and the way it holds the garlic sauce is simply superb. And the tender pork combined with baby bok choy and celery? Savory, sweet, and texture abounds.

Shanghai Wonton Noodle Soup [$6.95] 

This isn't your Americanized Chinese food joint's won ton soup. The broth is clear and deep. The wontons are well-crafted and large, filled with abundant portions of pork. Not overly salty, this soup will fill you up for under $7.

Stewed Chicken Over Rice [$5.95]

For the stewed chicken, we went with the rice. The moist and tender chicken came with a gravy that was rich. With baby bok choy on the side, this definitely eats like a meal - for under $6.

Pan Fried Beef Potato Cake [$3.80]

And if anything is a must order (other than the soup dumplings), it's these pan fried potato cakes. A gluttonous form of Chinese latkes, there was richly seasoned beef and potato bits within. And the crispy exterior offered great texture.

Shanghai Pork Soup Dumplings [$5.75]

But what are we really here for? The infamous XLB. For everyone other than myself, this was the first adventure into soup dumplings. So naturally, some instruction was needed so the night didn't end with peoples' mouths being scalded.  

Simply grab your dumpling with your chopsticks and place them on your soup spoon. Then, pierce the skin to allow some of the hot broth to seep out. Slurp and then take a big bite of the dumpling. Sweet, savory, and then sweet again. All filled within a gossamer thin fresh dumpling wrapper. I could easily eat three orders of these in one sitting. 

Crab & Pork Soup Dumplings [$6.25]

But on this occasion, we had to try the crab and pork iteration as well. The scent and taste of the crab comes on the forefront, with the pork taking over on the end. I prefer the regular pork soup dumplings, but this offers a nice change of pace for those inclined for surf and turf. 

So at Dim Sum Garden, for under $60, a party of 4 can get their fill of great food to start off the night. But really, I'd pay twice as much for these Iron Chef-endorsed soup dumplings. They're just that good. And don't forget - add an order of those delicious pan fried beef potato cakes!
name: Dim Sum Garden

text:
Happy Hour at Khyber is great. Drafts are $2 off and $1.5 domestics. The drafts include some heavy hitters like Great Divide Hibernation, Port Brewing's Santa's Little Helper, and Founder's Breakfast Stout. I had a great time and spent about $20 so its a win in my book. 

I also love the interior. Its old and dark with an eclectic collection of beer signage, but I love drinking in places like that. The ornate wood carving around the mirrors give it s nice touch. It is narrow so it gets a bit crowded so get there early.

text:
My friend and I went to brunch here on Sunday and had a lovely experience.  We were looking to sit outside, but once we entered the restaurant and saw the beautiful décor and gigantic open windows, we were happy to take up residence at a table indoors.  The restaurant was surprisingly empty for 1 p.m., but this only made for more attentive service and a fantastic table by one of the aforementioned windows, across from The Academy of Music.  

Fresh crusty bread and hummus was promptly placed on our table, and a complimentary cocktail was offered with our brunch order.  I asked for a bellini, praying that a classy place like Estia would get it right and use fresh peach juice instead of schnapps or some other imitation of the real thing.  The bellini was dropped at my table and was perfection; so much so that my friend made the switch to a bellini for her second round.   

My "avga spanakia," which I requested with egg whites, was unique and very good.  It was supposed to include spinach, leeks, feta, scallions and tomato, but there was not any tomato in my dish.  It was served in an iron skillet and was very hot and bubbly, which I loved.  The side of sausage that I ordered never made it to the table; our server said they had run out.  Not a big deal, as the omelet came with a side of pita wedges and a small dish of chive-seasoned potatoes, which was more than enough. My friend had a smoked fish platter, which she seemed pleased with as well.

I would love to make it back sometime for dinner and sit in one of the semi-private banquette/booth type areas along the wall with a small group.

text: Talula's is one of our favorite restaurants in Philly. It is our special date night place. We always make a reservation because it gets busy, especially on the weekends. The experience here is what really stands out. The staff is lovely and the dining experience is top notch. Their dinner rolls that they bring you before your meal are SO GOOD. The cheese plates are phenomenal and they change their menu based on the ingredients that they can get and everything is always so fresh and tasty. The restaurant is also beautiful and well decorated. The tables are intimate but it still feels lively and classy. I can't wait to eat here again.

text:
All you can eat sushi. For $26.

That's as many maki rolls, nigiri pieces, dumplings, tiny salads with ginger dressing and fancy plates full of goodness as you can possibly fit inside your stomach.

For just $26.

I'm sure when I have come to Aki, I've eaten at least half my weight in sushi, which comes out to approximately $2,014 in US dollars.

Honestly, I would understand their pricing here more if the sushi was mediocre. Or if the service sucked. Or if the drinks were crappy and overpriced.

But no....nope. None of that.

Sushi is on point. Fish is fresh, all of it is made right before your eyes on the elevated sushi bar in the back.

Service is stellar. I've been with groups large and small, and they have always been accommodating, speedy and friendly.

And the drinks are moderately priced, of a varied selection and expertly crafted cocktails have been tasty.

So what are you waiting for? Maybe to get hungry enough to eat all of the sushi? Yes, wait for that. And when you are hungry enough, get to 1210 Walnut Street and make your sushi dreams come true.
name: Aki Nom Nom Sushi & Ramen

text: This anecdote well summarizes my experience.  A friend and I had lunch here.  When the waiter came over to the table midway through our meal and asked perfunctorily "How's everything?" both of us replied, "Frankly, everything is very salty!"  "A lot of people have told me that," our waiter replied.  "Well," I said, "Did you ever manage to go back to the kitchen and tell THEM?!"

text:
El Rey has some happy hour steals, I believe it was $3 coronas, $1 tecates? Correct me if I'm wrong. Anyway, I met my friends here last week and I was excited to finally get the opportunity to go here as I walk past it frequently and duhhhh I like Mexican food because who doesn't!

We sat up at the bar and were mid way through our conversations and beverages when BAM my friend to my lefts water glass goes flying through the air drenching us and her phone/my purse in luckily, just water. Totally get accidents happen (the bartender knocked the drink shaker into our waters) but we were soaked, like it was in my hair and mascara.  

No harm was done my friends phone somehow made it out alive and my purse was nylon so it's all good. However we didn't get one round of our drinks comped or anything, just a meek apology. It's not like we were sippin on patron here I'm talking $1 tecates. It was just sort of...odd.

Anyway I definitely want to try this place again as I don't think lightning strikes twice aka I probably won't get doused in water next time. The food looked great though and those happy hour specials c'mon!
name: El Rey

text:
Gluten free heaven!

If you are gluten intolerant this is the place to come and check out. I was amazed with the meal I had. I got a pita bread dish with feta cheese, tomatoes, olives, etc. on the sides. 
My wife is not gluten intolerant and ordered a normal pizza and was totally impressed. 
There is a large variety of food to pick from and they also offer amazing sodas that are free of high fructose corn syrup. 
The workers are friendly and they have a very laid back atmosphere
name: The Couch Tomato Cafe

text:
I've hear so many good things about this place, I finally came here during happy hour. 

It's a dive bar ambiance, everyone looked so laidback. I had to waited about 10 mins to get a table, but the server would take your name and your phone #, so when you table is ready, you will get noticed through text. 

Yes, their margarita $4 and nachos $5 are the best deal for happy hour. Very good margarita, huge yet delicious nachos for just $5! You can't beat this deal! 

My friend and I ordered some tacos, unfortunately, tacos are just mediocre.

I will definitely come back for their happy hour (M-F 4pm-7pm), they also have happy hour on weekends 1pm-3pm, I think. 

Highly recommended for their happy hour, not the food though.
name: Loco Pez

text:
I have been wanting to try Honest Tom's for the longest. When I heard about their taco truck, I could sadly never get a long enough lunch away from the office. Then they gave their truck away and made a new home in Univ. City... Way too far for me to visit on a lunch break.

Until ---!!! Friends of ours suggested Honest Tom's on our way up to the Mann for a concert. Whoo hoo, better late than never!

I had the Pretty Ricky's Fish Tacos. A pinch too salty for my taste buds but not a deal breaker. My belly was pretty happy. The mister had the pork tacos and he devoured it. Our party shared chips with guac and salsa. Guac was good, definitely for the avocado lovers. Salsa was decent too but the guac totally stole the show, sorry. Best part? The chips! They have got to be the chips from Tortilleria San Roman. I definitely eat them way too much that I know this. Kudos, Tom - You have great taste in chips. 

Indoor seating is minimal, but outdoor seating in the summer makes for a lovely evening.
name: Honest Tom's Plant Based Taco Shop

text: Oh Lorenzos. How I miss your giant, foldable cheese pizza. If you want toppings on your pizza, this is not the place for you. If you want a giant New York style slice of pizza this is the place for you. The crust is thin and crispy just how I like it. Burns the roof of my mouth every time; that's probably because I'm too impatient and can't wait for it to cool down but nonetheless it's hot and delicious. I have eaten this pizza with franks red hot, crushed red pepper flakes, and sriracha. Delicious no matter what hot sauce I put on it. They're open until 1 or 2 am and have a long line late at night. Perfectly located on south street in the middle of all the bars. One slice was more than enough for me.
name: Lorenzo & Sons Pizza

text:
We LOVE Brauhaus Schmidt. We come here all the time and enjoy at least a few Boots of beer. My favorite beer is ALWAYS on tap (Lindeman's Framboise for those keeping track!) and I have been known to put back a 1L boot by myself.

The staff are great and the food is, too. I love the "stew" and of course the "sausage". (obviously not the German terms). The fries are tasty but make note--they're the only vegetarian friendly item on the menu other than beer! 

I've had several large parties here and it's always been great. The lederhosen and German music take it to the next level. Love it!
name: Brauhaus Schmitz

text:
Dim Sum Garden is a Philly Chinatown staple and has the lines to reflect it. The busy and curt waiters do a good job moving people along in a staggered inside-outside system. The inside is pretty chaotic and loud and you're going to be elbow to elbow with strangers but that won't matter once the food is in front of your face.

They have a large and varied menu and everything I've had has been really great. Great enough for me to overlook the general grunge-stickyness of the restaurant as well as the occasional lack of actual dishware. It's byob (for now) and we were provided with solo cups for our sparkling wine which might have been an aesthetic choice or a clever ploy to make us go through the bottle that much faster.

All of their dumplings are solid options and rise to greatness with liberal use of their dumpling sauce. I would actually recommend getting some of the more basic dishes here like chicken skewers which arrive hot enough to scald all the skin off your mouth and fried rice which comes untainted by soy sauce and therefore becomes a perfect carrier for any other sauces from all the other dishes you've already ordered.

They also have a non-spicy version of dan dan noodles (pork with sauce noodles) for those who always wanted to try Han Dynasty's signature dish but afraid of the spice level.
name: Dim Sum Garden

text:
Sabrina's Cafe has become one of my favorite spots to go to in Center City. A friend showed me this place when we were looking for a brunch spot after a long night of shenanigans and spoke so highly of Sabrina's. So off we went and man were we not disappointed. 

The restaurant is set up as a super cute and trendy little hipster diner that still has some old flare touches to it. The staff are always so hipster and nice which really adds to the atmosphere. 

Now the menu is large and in charge. They offer an amazing variety of breakfast and lunch items that have a different twist to them. Their French Toast is to die for, but don't also skip out on trying their Huevos Rancheros! Also, I always recommend if you go with a group to have someone get at least 1 plate off their specials menu as they change it frequently and the dishes are also so superb! 

I absolutely love coming here, overall a true MUST if you ever visit Philadelphia!
name: Sabrina's Café

text:
Glorious !!  That is all I want to say about this outstanding "Gem" of an establishment.  What can I say that 300+ reviewers hasn't already been said.  

I have been to Johns countless times, well before my yelp days, so why not give these guys their props. Without a doubt this is by far the best spot in South Philly to get a Roast Pork sandwich. Everyone comes here because it is nothing but pure bliss waiting to be devoured. Sorry DiNics, as much as I do enjoy your roast pork  you're ranked second in my opinion when it comes to roast pork, John's has this won. 

This corner joint is always busy with a mob of people trying to get their hands on a delicious , full flavored , mouth watering, juicy sandwich. These guys will always be here, nobody can perfect a sandwich like them. They accommodate all from the suits to the contractors, everybody comes here. 

I was in the area and why not treat myself to a fantastic lunch , and why not stop here.  Now I will say this , as many times I have been here I have never tried their cheesesteak. Something about that pork that just makes you forget what you originally intended to get . I have no issues of going back and try to make another attempt in perusing the cheesesteak scene, trust me it is a challenge I must accomplish . 

My perfect roast pork starts with a great seeded roll holding in all the juices as best as it can. Its all in the type of bread that one uses that can  make or break a sandwich. Places like John's stand out the most because of the type of roll, they use.  While my sandwich is getting its proper treatment I follow it up with sharp Provolone ,with long hots. This is the perfect combination, a perfect way to compliment one to another. The ingredients they use to make that pork , simply put delicious. Heaven on a seeded roll waiting for you to sit and enjoy.   

These guys have it down, where there is no confusion , no long wait for sandwich what so ever. Once you come in you order , slide to the right, pay the lovely lady and get your eat on.  

Cash only, so if you bring plastic you might here some "Booos" from the crowd. I will be back again, this time I will be getting a cheesesteak.  ( Hopefully )
name: John's Roast Pork

text: Some of the best falafel i've had here I tried it yesterday after leaving a meeting and realizing I  was up the block and also because of all the yelpers who spoke highly of the place. The food was good and since it was my first time there I got a free falafel ball which is how I made my choice as to what to get .. I hear regular bread is tastier but I love whole wheat so i chose that and I don't feel robbed of taste one bit! Thanks yelpers for pointing me this way I'll def be back again
