text:
Let me jut put it out there. This is my favorite restaurant in Philadelphia - it's weird decor, great service, awesome drinks and consistently delicious food.

I have been coming here semi-regularly since 2007. It is always awesome. It's a great restaurant for everything. Date night - perfect. Brunch after visiting the farmers market- awesome. Need to take your mom out to dinner and she's kind of picky - BOOM! you found your place.

The service is always on point and the servers are all very cool and knowledgeable. The walls have the strangest array of christmas lights, weird masks, pictures, and other random things. I still don't think I have found all the hidden decor oddities here! It's actually kind of a fun game because every time I go, I find another item that I have never seen before.

I have tried almost everything on the menu. The absolutely only thing I would recommend switching out is the bread on the chicken sandwich. It's boring and kind of hard to eat the sandwich. Other than that I can say the wings, ribs, pulled pork, fries, tomato soup, bibb salad and burger are all really great! Oh and I forgot to mention that you should check out the specials also. The one dish that I force myself to order every time I go there are the spring rolls. I just love the sauce, slaw and rolls. I mop them up.

In all seriousness, you need to be eating here.
name: North Third

text:
I used to wonder what happy feelings tasted like until i had food at zahav. I dont even know where to begin so i will start with the award winning 36 hour roasted lamb cooked in what i call beyond perfection. 

Let's start with the preparation: marinated in a pomegranate molasses for 12 hours....I could end this whole review there. Ok...after marinating its slow cooked for another 12 hours, marinated in more herbs and spices, THEN seared to a nice crispness on top and hit with the pomegranate sauce again. 
Words can't describe what raced through my mind when i took that first tender bite into the lamb..That bite made me want ro succeed more in life so i could eat like that more often.
The portion sizes were just right, but as a heads up, if you order the Taste of Zahav witg the wine pairing, make sure you have a big appetite that day. Also get there early for the lamb before 8pm because once it runs out for the night you're outta luck and its a popular dish. Cant wait to go back!
name: Zahav

text:
I have been to Amis for brunch twice now, and it is the best! Fantastic food, service, and atmosphere. Here are some highlights:

FOOD:
BAKED PECORINO is a plate of gooey, cheesy goodness with a bit of a sharper taste. RICOTTA is a pretty standard ricotta dish but delicious nonetheless. BELGIAN WAFFLE WITH SEMIFREDDO is so delicious! I have never had semifreddo before and it is basically a stickier, creamier version of ice cream. The one that comes with the waffle is butter flavored, so if you spread it out, it is as if the waffle has butter and ice cream on it at the same time. If you are in the mood for something sweet, I definitely recommend this. If you are in more of a lunch mood, definitely go for one of the PASTAS - they are all hand-cut and very tasty (at least one person tried each one in my party). 

SERVICE:
This is probably the best service I have had at a restaurant ever. The waitresses were so nice and friendly and were great about explaining everything on the menus and giving recommendations. The first time I went, the baked pecorino was taking a bit longer than usual to come out so she just gave it to us on the house. Then when we were looking at the dessert menu, we mentioned to each other that we had wanted to try the olive oil cake but were too full to get it. Five minutes later, out comes the cake, also on the house! The second time I went, they gave us ricotta on the house as well. So considerate, and it made the dining experience all the better!

ATMOSPHERE:
Amis has a well-lit, airy, bright atmosphere. There are beautiful lamps made of little red bottles of cordial. My favorite part is the bakery counter, filled with scones and bread and open toward the restaurant. Behind the counter you can see into the kitchen, a nice touch.

If you are looking for a nice place to go to brunch, I definitely recommend Amis!
name: Amis Trattoria

text:
The 5 courses on the prefix Sunday menu left all 22 seats in the restuarant filled with 22 happy customers. I was blown away by Little Fish upon dining this weekend. I brought my parents who were in from out of town and love to take advance of Philly's BYOB scene. Each course was better than the last, taking the diner through an experience of the best ways to prepare fish. 

With a name like Little Fish, you better be good at seafood and this place more than exceeded expectations. The menu was unique (included a special variety of salmon for New Zealand no one had ever heard of) and prepared something you see all the time (yellowtail) in a creative raw preparation. 

The experience differs from the ususal seafood joint as the entire restaurant dines at the same time. There are two timeslots on Sunday, 5 and 8. If you arrive 10 minutes late you will miss the first course. When I saw this on the website I thought maybe this was just a bluff but every customer arrived on time and ready to time. The waitstaff was knowledgeable although had limited interaction with the table. Since they serve the entire restaurant at the exact same time and the few servers help all tables. 

Overall, the experience was excellent and I cannot wait to return.
name: Little Fish

text:
Vegan Latin food for the win!

This place adds a new twist to established dishes - keeping things fresh and your senses satiated!

It's located on one edge of Rittenhouse Park, so the location is great for any occasion - given the backdrop of the park, creates a great ambiance. Inside, it's got a Cuban motif, with small ceiling fans circling throughout, low lighting, open concept, and lots of wood fixtures. The main bar meets you as you step inside, and then the dining space is towards the right.

I had made a reservation using OpenTable, and when I arrived, our table was primed for seating - just the way I like to start a dinner!

We were seated squarely in the middle - so on the bright side, we had great visuals of people watching, but also found ourselves getting in the way if we shifted too much in one direction. You feel how close the quarters are when everyone is walking around you!

Once seated, the waitress offered us some drink options - I chose their latte drink with some almond milk. While our drinks arrived, we reviewed the menu options and settled on the buffalo cauliflower tacos and the ranchero bean dip (with chimichurri!)

The dishes were perfect for two and really well made! Great use of ingredients, and well developed flavors! It shows they really went to great lengths to build the dishes, not just replace meat elements with a vegetable. The dishes were hearty, satiable, and at the same time not heavy on the belly. 

Our waitress was great with our questions and came around plenty to check in on us. The staff was generally friendly and accommodating. 

Overall - really enjoyed my experience here, and I'm looking forward to the next visit!
name: Bar Bombón

text:
I think Distrito is my new favorite place for lunch. My friend, Dan, got me to try it one day and I was really impressed. They have a lunch special ("The Blue Demon Express" [?]) which is a pretty good value for an upscale lunch: $15 for a drink (non-alcoholic), appetizer, and main course. 

Here is my advice on selecting your courses: the nachos are monstrous, the tacos are smallish, the torta (sandwich) is pretty substantial. Therefore, choose your courses carefully - if you get the nachos as a starter, you should probably go with the tacos for your second. Otherwise, you risk the dreaded post-lunch, I-don't-wanna-do-any-work, food coma. It is highly recommended that you not get the nachos AND the torta. I would refer to that pairing as the "Death Wish."
 
Anyway, I love the tortilla soup. It is unbelievably good. The torta is a great choice, as are the pulled pork tacos. 

I would highly recommend checking out Distrito for a nice lunch.
name: Distrito

text:
I love this place for traditional korean food. It has a wide array of options besides the bbq. I haven't had the bbq here because I usually just stop in by myself to eat and the meat options start pretty expensive, way too much for a party of 1.

The banchan, complementary appetizers, are tasty. Sometimes they end the meal with another small free bowl of sweet soup. 

I usually end up getting some beef soup with noodles. I can't remember the name, but it's light and filling. It's especially great when it's cold out.
name: Seorabol Korean Restaurant

text:
This place is super cute, everything is a la carte. So it's $10 for just the burger not including other toppings or fries. There is an entire vegan menu which is real neat (not for me). We had 3 burgers we each created our own. One of them came out wrong but they corrected the best they could. 

I think for 3 people and $60 there are other neat places to try before this one.
name: Bareburger - Midtown Village

text: Awesome neighborhood bar with great beers and REALLY good bar food. The wings are awesome. The seitan wings are awesome too and I'm not a big seitan type of guy. The burger is one of the best I've had in Philly. The specials are usually good enough to pull you away from the menu too. Cool and nice staff too.

text: Great dive bar in Olde City when you need to get away from the "trendy" spots in the neighborhood.  The food is good (except the nachos) and there's a wide array of reasonably priced beer.  It has a really great pub feel which is hard to find in the city and is always packed on a Friday or Saturday night.

text:
On its opening weekend, Nomad Pizza made a pretty good impression, but there is room for improvements in the future. We were seated on the second floor, and it was pretty evident that they'll be doing movie nights, with a projector faced towards a large white-walled canvas. Nice!

Our server was great, and helped us order the appropriate amount of food for three people. We started with a round of drinks: the house white for me and Victory root beer for the guys. The root beer came out in frosty mugs and I was a little jealous, despite my nice glass of white. That root beer is worth every delicious calorie. 

We shared the blue cheese salad, with mixed greens and sweet pecans. It was nice! Personally, I think it would have really took off with some pears or even halved grapes in lieu of grape tomatoes. But either way, I'd definitely order it again. 

Three pizzas were delivered one after the other to our table. The margherita arrived first. When it was dropped off, I asked the runner if they had forgotten to cut the pie, and he said something about how they are serving pizzas in the authentic Italian style, meaning we are meant to cut our own. We each took to cutting up a pie with the knives that we had used for our salads. Hopefully, Nomad reconsiders this decision at some point. 

Out of the three pies, the margherita was surprisingly our least favorite. It was okay, but I think the basic concept of this pizza showed the flaws more than our fancier versions. The crust became soggy quickly and was exhaustively chewy. This was true for all of the pies, but the spicy sausage and the tartufo had so many great flavors in the toppings that it was less noticeable. 

Desserts were limited to a couple sorbets and a banana nutella pizza, which none of us were interested in at that point. I think some gelato or ice cream would be awesome. 

Again, this review was written on the third day of opening weekend. Nomad is a really nice spot for a first date, casual night out or cool place to grab a seat at the bar. I'm looking forward to seeing how they develop.
name: Nomad Pizza Company

text:
Recently went here for brunch, and thoroughly enjoyed it.  I ordered the mixed griddle with a friend, and we split the french toast, pancake, eggs, and other yummy treats they brought me. I am a BIG FAN.  SO yummy! I can't wait to go back and try more of their brunch menu. 

Aside - the pancakes are cornbread pancakes, really unique and really yummy.

text:
(Take this one with a grain of salt. As a native Texan, our Mexican food standards are unreasonably high.)

The atmosphere is a good one, especially on the patio, if the weather is nice. Fun, laid back, casual. 
However, the service was a like slow at times. 

We started off with a couple of margs, which were ok but kind of weak and sweet.

Our app, a tlayuda, was by far the highlight of the meal. It's basically a Mexican pizza. It has a delicious cornmeal-based crust that's crispy and crunchy on the edges but still tender under the toppings. We got the one with duck and sweet potato. Really, really good. 

The one other dish that stood out was the sweet plantains. Simple, but tasty AF. The crema and cojita give them an almost cheesecakey vibe. 

The rest of the meal (steak, nopales salad, sunchokes, tres leches) was fine, but kind of forgettable. 

The steak was an odd, thick rectangular shape that led to the center being almost raw. Plus, the chimichurri was sour and sharp with garlic and lime. The salad & 'chokes, fine, meh...
 
La Calaca Feliz is fun and definitely worth checking out, but the food, unfortunately, disappointed my high expectin' Texan tastebuds. The great Philly mexi-food hunt continues. Yee haw!
name: La Calaca Feliz

text:
A mixed bag of a restaurant with some really bright spots and a couple of far misses. Let's get to the not so exciting pieces first and save the good news for later. The wings we were served today were forgettable at best. Very much on the dry side and flavorless. The papas chorreadas came a close second with undercooked potatoes. Service was slow but we can overlook that as the restaurant was busy.

Crossing to the brighter side, the patio at the back is a sweet space to sit on a sunny day. The vegetarian quesadillas have a pleasant surprise hidden in them in the form of Huitlacoche. Corn Smut (Huitlacoche) is a problem for US crop producers but a delicacy among their Latin-American counterparts. Thankfully it is featured on menus across the United States lately. The fungus has a mellow, earthy flavor profile like the truffle mushroom. 

The Tequila and Mezcal selection is huge. Our knowledge in this area is limited but the list sure looks impressive.

A middle of the line 3-stars based on the overall experience.
name: Cantina Dos Segundos

text:
Fantastic pizza and fun place to hang out. The "Pizza Museum" theme is great. 

The pizza itself is thin crust, with really high quality sauce and cheese. There is nothing to compare it to, really - it tastes like Pizza Brian. 

It is, without a doubt, my favorite pizza in Philadelphia.

text:
Looks like this a place whose decor you either love or hate, judging by previous Yelpers' reviews!
Well this Yelper was a fan of the decor.  I found it to be eclectic & cozy & a good match for the yummilicious dishes being served up.

I really liked everything about Farmicia to be honest.  The service was friendly & efficient, the food fabulous & the drinks amazing.
Everything was fresh, nicely presented & full of wonderful flavor.  I was particularly impressed with my boyfriend's pork chop & sweet mashed potatoes - two things I really don't much care for but thought were deliciously prepared at Farmicia.
I can't wait to make a return trip!

& I'm definitely down for trying brunch here one day - hopefully sooner rather than later!

text:
I kept deciding between a 4 and 5 star... but .. I can't even.. justify a 4 star. They are THAT good!

And the new location is goddamn BEAUTIFUL. That's what pushes it to the 5 star. It is just.. MILES AWAY from the old place. This place is huge!! You walk in: it's clean, modern, chique and actually quite large. You can walk alllll the way down the long skinny hallway. I also LOVE the open kitchen set up. It's beautiful, you gotta go see it.

With the beautiful renovation I was worried their prices would skyrocket! Nooo way. Still the good old prices we always knew. Maybe a quarter increase, MAYBE. 

Needless to say, SHANGHAI SOUP DUMPLINGS aka xialongbao. To die for. Don't burn your tongue when you bite the dumplings. You have to take a small bite, like the juice run out in your spoon.. and slurp it all up. What a comforting thought...

Scallion pancakes: done very well. wouldn't change a thing
Shrimp dumplings are good as well

A lot of people just get the XLB. I've ordered seaweed and egg soup, the items I described above and more. They've never disappointed me. Service is always quick, friendly and efficient. Goddamnit I want one now...

text: Have been meaning to try this place since I've heard good things. We came here for lunch on a Sunday and the place was pretty empty so we were sat right away. We both started out with a soda, but when we got them they tasted weird. Not like they were flat, but just really off. We just decided to stick with water and then proceeded to order some queso, shrimp tempura tacos, and chicken Tinga tacos. The queso dip came first and it was pretty good, it had a nice spicy kick to it which we liked. The tacos came next and were just so so. The shrimp tempura tacos seemed to be overwhelmingly too much tempura which overpowered any other flavor in the taco. The chicken Tinga was okay but the chicken seemed like a weird consistency to me and I wasn't the biggest fan. After all of this we were still a little hungry and got an order of the rice and beans and were pleasantly surprised that the portion was huge. We had to box most of it up and take it home. All in all, this place is just okay. With all the other taco places popping up in center city, I'm not sure if we'll be back anytime soon.
name: Jose Pistola's

text:
I am so embarrassed that I haven't written a review for Suraya yet. I would easily argue that this restaurant is one of the absolute crown jewels of Philly, and I luckily have been here once in person before COVID and then recently got takeout from here. I couldn't find my pictures from my in person experience so I'm taking advantage of my recent takeout experience to just sing my praises. Both times I ordered the tasting menu, and this time I ordered the tasting menu for two for delivery. The tasting menu comes with hummus, baba ganoush, and labneh with two huge pitas. For dessert, there's a blueberry ashta (milk pudding) and a ma'amoul, and chocolate and almond financier (both are soft crumbly delicious cookies). I also added on the kanafeh.

The main dishes I selected for the dinner for two was the lamb kebab (halabi) and the branzino (samke harra). Every single item was cooked and spiced to perfection and it really held up in the drive to my apartment. The heating instructions for the kanafeh were easy to follow and tasted great at home too, almost as good as being served it right at the restaurant. Suraya puts in extra love to their takeout experience by not only labeling everything, but also putting on small description stickers of what's in the dish you're having.

I absolutely love this restaurant, please do show them some love during these hard times and trust you'll have a great experience. And absolutely you must come in person once the pandemic is over, the interior of the restaurant is gorgeous. Suraya's menu is delicious from top to bottom, can't go wrong with a single dish.
name: Suraya

text:
Lunch: choice of carb + choice of protein for $7 offered 10-3; casually pay upfront at the cashier, take a peek at their daily pastries and baked goods, and grab a seat. Can say that steak with rice noodles and meatballs with rice (and a runny fried egg) are tangy-sweet and yummy. 

Happy hour: 4-7pm, cheap cocktails and food, a hybrid menu between Sampan and Double Knot. I always order the kimchi fried rice. Other things I've liked: pork bahn mi, pork bao, short rib chow fun. 

Next time: dinner, for the robatayaki and sushi/sashimi.

text:
There is something about breweries that make me feel all warm and fuzzy inside... I'm sure the alcohol content of the beer is helping.

Yards Brewing Company is no exception. The people who work here really seem to love what they do and have a great time doing it. The tour is fun and informative, and you get a free tasting while walking through the brewery! Note: It is a bit chilly in here. Assume if it's cold outside, it will be cold inside. This is only true of the tour, not of the tasting room. 

Being the lush that I am, I felt the need to try both flights offered. The Signature Ale flight is laid out from Malty to Hoppy (which is coincidentally in order of my favorite to least favorite -- hoppy beer and I are not friends) and the Revolution flight is their 3 presidential ales and the love stout. 

If you aren't feeling a full tasting, the staff is super knowledgeable and would be able to help you choose the perfect beer for you.

Now that I am aware how close this is to me, I have a bad feeling the staff is going to get sick of me!
name: Yards Brewing Company

text:
Ah. The original Continental is exactly what I am craving whenever I end up at Continental Midtown instead: it's got character, ambiance, and tasty food. Unless you're in desperate need of a roof deck, I suggest heading over to this Continental in Old City instead of it's Midtown counterpart.

For some reason, I don't know if its the setting or what, but I like the food here better than Midtown. I love the diner feel -- sitting on bar stools or in booths and being able to actually (sort of) see the cooks through the pass through.

This is a great people watching location if you can snag an outdoor seat on a warm day. Who doesn't love staring at the eclectic group of people that end up at the corner of 2nd and Market?

I have yet to come here for brunch, but hear good things. I tend to overlook this place for brunch because the prices really do seem too high.

The beer selection isn't too shabby, but the real reason you'd go here is for the cocktails. The Dean Martini cracks me up whenever someone orders it (I'm easily amused). They give you a book of matches and 1 lucky cigarette with your martini. Kitchy, but I love it. If martinis aren't your thing, the drink selection is extensive, I'm sure you'll find something to make you happy.

They also have a solid happy hour: $3 Drafts, $4 Wines, $5 Specialty Cocktails, and $1-$2 Tapas Bites (they are tiny, but super tasty).
name: The Continental Restaurant and Martini Bar

text:
I had breakfast there yesterday.  I won't go into much detail on this since I don't think I tried anything that's really indicative of their menu. But I'll say this.

The Bourbon Street Breakfast is a great deal at $5.95. The cornbread they serve with it is out of this world. The rice and beans they serve will please anyone that enjoys Cajun food. 

On top of that, the staff is very friendly. They offered me a sample of the bread pudding, and it tasted like I was getting a shot of bourbon. Not a bad thing. 

And even on top of that, they serve a pretty bold coffee.  They don't just throw you that Ellis restaurant coffee. No, they give you coffee with a bite. The server even offered me a free refill to go without me asking. 

Very good experience overall. I even topped it off with one of the King Cakes which did not disappoint. All of the above came out to just over 10 bucks.

text:
We met up with friends and scored a street-side table at Barbuzzo.  Our waitress did a fantastic job of "working the street."  We never once felt neglected, our glasses were always full, and the entire experience was very enjoyable.  

Our food was hit or miss, in my opinion, but there was definitely something for everyone!  

We split a few plates.  The standout was the Whipped Ricotta, which we all really enjoyed - the balance between the creamy Ricotta, the fig, and the salt made for a perfect bite on the grilled bread slices.  On the other hand, the chicken liver left a bit to be desired.  It oddly only came with three pieces of bread (vs. 4 with the whipped ricotta) - I would think four would be standard so that parties of two and four can be easily served, but whatever.  I felt that the chicken liver flavors didn't meld well together and it needed something more, but my other friend loved it, so it's all a matter of tastes! 

Lastly, we split the fennel sausage flat bread.  I like spice, I love hot sauce and peppers, but the spice in this wasn't my favorite.  The smokey flavor was delicious, but the seeds from the chilis could be overpowering.  

There were zero complaints about our beverages and the ability to sit outside and enjoy them with friends (haha).  All in all, a wonderful experience and we will surely be back to try many other items!
name: Barbuzzo

text:
If you're in Philly, the home of the best Italian hoagies, and you are eating at Campo's, then you probably also think that McDonald's has the best salads.

Truth is if I was in NH off 95 north, this would be a good hoagie. But I'm in Philly. A moments drive away from Chickies and Primos. But stuck on touristy Old City Market St, I suppose Campo's is okay. They have a good selection of hot and cold sandwiches, the service is digestible and I'm pretty sure they never wear gloves.


WARNING: Do not touch their brownies!! The sign that says "Do Not Touch Or You Buy" is not a joke, regardless of the fact that it is double-wrapped in Saran wrap.

Remembering Thoreau, I decided to live a little and touch the brownie. It was a small feat compared to Civil Rights' living of being thrown in jail for not paying taxes during the Spanish war, but it was a start.

And yes, I had to buy the brownie. Long live existentialism.
name: Campo's Philly Cheesesteaks

text:
This is my brunch review: 

1. I'm a Philly girl, I love soft pretzels.
2. I'm a Jewish girl, I love smoked salmon.
3. I'm a party girl, I love booze. 

So when you mix all three of them, put them on a plate together and then put that plate at a restaurant down the street from my house, it's a total deal maker. 

All I'm saying is that the toasted fennel soft pretzel with vodka cured salmon is amazing. And their brunch drinks (many of which contain my fave, st. germain) are amazing.

I just feel very blessed to have P&K brunch in my life.

I CAN'T BELIEVE THAT I FORGOT TO MENTION THAT ABBA WAS PLAYING. 

I'm upping the star count for Waterloo.

text:
Even though I stopped by around closing time, I felt very welcome. Unfortunately, in many places around the city it is almost like they want to kick you out. Not here. The girl who helped me was very nice. I felt very satisfied with the service.
Moving on to the donuts.. They had all flavors, except for 2 fancy donuts which I don't remember. So I got: cinnamon brown sugar, cookies and cream (classic) + eggnog, sugarplum, sticky toffee, frosty the donut (fancy).
First of all, the dough itself: yeah it is that good. The flavors?
I thought the cookies and cream donut was very similar to the cinnamon brown sugar, honestly. It is the same donut in a "cookies and cream" powder. I didn't get the cookies, just the sugar.  
The eggnog donut was the only one that ACTUALLY tasted different among the fancy ones. The sticky toffee and frosty (supposed to be vanilla and coconut) tasted similar. I mean, if you got a coconut piece in the frosty and a crunch on the sticky toffee you would notice the difference, but I think it is very subtle. The sugarplum donut was way too sweet for my taste, but it was so pretty (it is purple)!
Overall, I enjoyed the donuts. My favorite, hands down, was the cinnamon brown sugar, especially because it is made to order and you can have it warm, YUM! The dough is very good and it doesn't need much, honestly. 
I feel like the fact that the donuts are only coated, not filled, prevents them from having a unique flavor when it comes to the fancy ones. Does that make sense? I feel there are very subtle differences between them. But don't get me wrong, they are delicious! Federal donuts is worth the trip! Next time I'll try their fried chicken for sure!

text:
In terms of taste, this could be the best restaurant I've ever been to - ever. I mean, eating here was a sort of religious experience. I had better start from the beginning...

My wife and I went here for Valentine's Day this year. She really enjoys the Stephen Starr franchise, so I thought I would treat her to their flagship offering. While she absolutely loved it, I think that I enjoyed it as much as, if not more than, she did.

We went right after one of the huge snowstorms that hit Philadelphia this year, so we planned to valet park (so as to avoid snowbanking the car on the street or her ruining her shoes walking from a nearby garage). The valet parking was pretty steep at $24 (+tip), but it was worth it. Though, you should note that it is not in front of Barclay; it's down the block in front of Parc, so you will have to a walk a little.

Our waiter was extremely nice and knowledgeable. This was one of those time where the waiter actually adds to the overall experience of the restaurant. 

The food was nothing short of life-changing. We started with the chopped salad, which was a sort of enigma. All advertised ingredients - kalamata olives, hear of palm, tomato, etc. - along with the lettuce were chopped to homogeneous fractals. When consuming a forkful of said geometric shapes, you could taste each and every one of the ingredients - amazing. Also, I hate to admit this (don't judge me), but this was the first time I have ever had a dry-aged steak. I will not even attempt to describe the deliciousness of the 20oz ribeye. It was actually worth the $48 - seriously. (being extremely cheap, that is the highest praise coming from me).

My only minor quibble (see aforementioned note on my cheapness) was that the side dishes seemed to be unreasonably priced at $10 - for mashed potatoes or broccoli, etc.

Anyway, while the check was not slight, I will always remember the experience - which is really what you pay for, I think, at a restaurant like this.
name: Barclay Prime

text: El Rey has become my favorite Steven Starr restaurant! Prices are very reasonable and the portion sizes are perfect. The margaritas are delicious and very fresh. Tried the guava and traditional margaritas, both great! Could be a little larger for the price but otherwise no complaints. The menu can be a little confusing because of the language barrier, but the servers do a great job explaining everything. Every time I go the queso fundido is a must! Can never go wrong with a heaping plate of melted cheese and flour tortillas. YUMMM! Highly recommended.
name: El Rey

text:
I've been here twice in the last two weeks and it's so delicious. It's overpriced, but that's what you get in Center City.

I'm obsessed with the iceberg wedge which at $10 is ridiculously priced, but the blue cheese, walnuts and cranberries are worth it.

I also recently had the sweet potato chili which was *chef's kiss*.

And you can't go wrong with their burgers.

text:
Quick and clean Mexcian food with solid lunch specials.  I like the Speedy Gonzales.  $6 covers me well until Dinner. When they say a dish contains cheese, be ready for it to be cheesy. Full of cheese that is, not corny.

Given is proximity to work for me, I've found myself here on multiple occasions for lunch and enjoyed each trip.  I've only had one drink, a margarita (remember,  usually go for lunch and have to go back to work) and can say it was solid.  They have some awesome happy hours posted, especially for earlier in the week.  I've been looking for an excuse to go and hope to find one soon.  Until then, I'll be back for another lunch in a week or two!

text:
I should preface every review and comment with the fact that I have high expectations. That being said, I'll continue to impart my experience at this joint.
 
Service: A+
The only problem that I had with the service was that our server actually asked how everything was a little TOO much. Over-zealously attentive is the only way I can describe it. 

Atmosphere: A 
If it hadn't been for the paddy-wagon parked outside with the lights a-blazing the entire time we were inside, the setting would have been tops. (Naked chicks floating amorously above me... I'm in.)

Food: B 
Ok, here is where we have some problems. The mac-n-cheese that is often touted as such glorious fare was (in my humble opinion) boring as f--k. Honestly, the flavors were much too mild for me to really appreciate.  
I asked the server what to order and she said that the chicken breast, which my friend had ordered, was the best thing on the menu. Well, we can't have two of the same at one table, so I ordered the veggie burger which I was told (again, by the server) was very good and made in-house. Here's the thing:  if you are going to call something a burger, it really needs to be in patty form. Period. This "thing" was total mush. The whole jawn fell apart as soon as I looked at it. It really was held together by love alone. Love couldn't save it. The chicken, on the other hand, was pretty darn good. 
The rest of the menu was somewhat uninteresting to me - I try to maintain at least a somewhat healthy diet, so all of the ultra meaty, fried, heavy options really threw a wrench in the works. On the other hand, there were some tempting appetizers that I will return to try out in the future (crab cheese fries... what?!)
name: Varga Bar

text:
Even though I am usually not the biggest fan of meat, Chima Steakhouse really impressed me and made me really enjoy the chicken and steak I got to try. It was very tender and juicy and had a great grilled flavor. The sides and appetizers were light but flavorful. Service was great and all the staff was attentive. 

Really not a fan of the wine I had. Honestly I don't known of it was the wine or the glass I had. It smelled  heavily of plastic, like the glass wasn't thoroughly washed and the wine itself had basically no flavor. 

The atmosphere in the restaurant  is nice. It seems like it's trying to cater to high end but in reality is a lot more casual than you would think. The tables are spaces out really well so that you get enough privacy and are not constantly getting interrupted with over year ring other conversations.
name: Chima Steakhouse

text: Was with my girlfriend around the corner on Jeweler's Row and we were hungry.  We checked seating availability and stopped in.  It was my first time here but my girlfriend has been here a few times.  The blue lighting make it feel less like a Japanese restaurant to me.  The waitress was nice and if you're in the mood for iced tea, try their iced green tea.  It's from a can but it's not strong with green tea flavor to the point where it's overwhelming, just enough to leave you refreshed and your thirst quenched.  We couldn't decide what to order because we were both feeling unhealthy from all the Thanksgiving and seasonal snackings, so we ordered sashimi with 2, to leave out the rice.  The sashimi was really fresh and we had a nice variety of sashimi.  I'm not sure if they forgot or if they do things differently here, but our sashimi did not come with ginger or wasabi so we had to ask for some.  No biggie.  Overall, I was very satisfied.  It was a nice portion, probably enough for 3 if you ordered an appetizer.  The sashimi for 2, along with many of their other entrees, come with miso soup and salad.  There aren't many good sushi places in the area that I enjoy, so this will definitely be an option in the future.

text:
I definitely prefer the South Philly Green Eggs Cafe to the Washington Square West location. The service was SO much friendlier (& I didn't mind the tattooed Hottie McHotterson host who kept smiling at me one bit).

This may also be an upgrade because the Vegan French Toast SO much better than the Vegan Chicken Cheesesteak that I ordered at the other location. And the Hashbrowns w/ Rosemary, YUMMY!

The portion size was almost too much for me, but I ate it all anyway! My only gripe is that we paid $15 for a small carafe of orange juice. Yes, it was freshly squeezed, & yes, we can accept that that price might include a corking fee for our Prosecco, but it still seems a little excessive.

All in all, a great brunch. I'd go back!

text: Had a generally good time here a P&K for a friend's birthday party.  We rented out the entire second floor for this extravaganza, and the food and service were both good.  Only caveat: parking is simply hellacious, at least for a weekend night, and after driving around for half an hour I ended up parking about five blocks away.  If you are planning on dining here, be sure to allow extra time to park or take your corporate helicopter.  I'm sure the CEO won't mind.

text:
This place has been here for years. This shop is easy to get to but parking can be hectic. Due to the popularity of this place and it's location on busy Henry Ave, it can take a few minutes to get a parking space. 

The ordering system is pretty simple and staff is great. Dalessandro serves one of the best cheese steaks in the city! The servings are hearty, rich, and robust with flavors. The sandwiches are always fresh and the meat is delicious! The hoagies are equally great but the steaks are to die for! If you are looking for a great steak that is the essence of Philly steaks, you must try this place.
name: Dalessandro’s Steaks & Hoagies

text:
I've bahn mi-ning to tell you...that Q.T. Vietnamese Sandwich is *officially* delicious. At the insistance of a good friend, I stopped by this petite hole on in the wall during lunch a few months ago, and picked up a #9 - Lemongrass Tofu Bahn Mi.  I've been back once a week ever since.

I don't say this lightly...O.M. effing G. Crunchy veggies & the perfect amount of sauce sitting atop the most substantial tofu I've ever tasted in a sandwich. I would challenge anyone who is tofu-averse to tell me that it's not filling.  My officemate loves #2, the BBQ Pork, although I've never tried it.

This place is small, so a fun option would be to order the bahn mis to go and then walk over to Washington Square Park for a picnic. In the meantime, mosey on over to Q.T. ASAP!
name: QT Vietnamese Sandwich

text:
Had dinner here last night in a group of five for Restaurant Week. A few of us had been wanting to try Sampan for a while, and we figured RW was a good opportunity since they offer basically their regular tasting menu at a $10pp discount. What we did not realize is that all five of us would have to agree on plates for the entire table to share...oops!

After some deliberation, we landed on the following selections: edamame dumplings, General Tso soup dumplings, Korean BBQ beef satay, spicy mustard wings, Pekin duck, scallops, and duck fried rice. The clear standouts were the edamame dumplings and beef satay. Our group had mixed feelings on the soup dumplings; some really enjoyed tasting the General Tso flavor in a dumpling, but others wished the dumplings contained a little more soup. The Pekin duck was served with little bao buns, sliced veggies, and sauce so that we could make miniature sandwiches, which was fun. Dinner concluded with tiny ice cream cones - adorable and yummy!

I very much felt Sampan's vibe was best suited for a group or party - but the table next to ours was a couple celebrating their anniversary, so I suppose reasonable minds could differ. Bottles of wine and sake were pretty expensive, but individual glasses were reasonably priced (can never really understand why restaurants do that). I'd be curious to come back here at some point and eat at the bar; Sampan struck me as just the right mix of casual-yet-foodiefriendly that lends itself well to that.

(Quick note that although our group was initially four and made a reservation over two full weeks ahead of time, Sampan was happy to bump us up to a party of five on only two days' notice when an additional friend wanted to join us - thanks, Sampan!)

text:
Covid safety precautions? 10/10. Perfect. They are the excellence bar. Although I haven't been to a bar (inside) since March 2020, this joint makes me feel as though I can do it again in the coming weeks...of course after my 2nd dose. They check your temperature, all staff have masks and face shields, and lines are clearly marked for social distance. 

We ate outside in their backyard and ordered a breakfast sandwich and a few beers. Seats are far apart and the ordering system is quick and painless. 

Highly recommend if you want a safe night out with friends.

text:
It's famously hard to get a reservation here, but my boyfriend and I got a walk in on a Saturday. We arrived at 5, put in our names for the bar seating and were seated at 6:30. (Not too bad, we went to khyber pass to grab a drink while we waited.) The food is excellent and very inspired. We had:

+ fried cauliflower 
+ salatim
+ grilled duck hearts
+ hummus
+ roasted rhubarb
+ a lamb meatball dish (don't remember the exact name)
+ pomegranate sorbet 

The cauliflower, hummus and roasted rhubarb were my favorite starters. I liked most of the salatim dips except for two of them; I recall that I didn't care for the super tomato-y one. We were waffling over the duck hearts and ultimately didn't order them, but the bartender/server brought us one gratis because he wanted us to try them. My boyfriend loved them but they weren't quite my thing; still, I'm glad I tasted them! The lamb dish and dessert were also great. There was a Turkish cotton candy on the sorbet...so perfect. 

Definitely one of the best food experiences I've had in Philly. And they've just opened a Dizengoff near where I live in NYC, so I'll be checking that out soon.

text:
Awful service yet again.

We had to ask for water glasses three times, and finally asked the hostess who brought us some.

We sat at our table for at least ten minutes before she came to take our order. 

It took ten minutes to get our first cup of coffee and then we had to ask the hostess for more because our server never came back.

I was brought the wrong food, and shockingly - my waitress was no where in sight, so I had to ask someone else to fix it. (Wrong food isn't a problem, but lack of server is). She did apologize, though.

I really like it here, but one crappy server is going to bring this place down.

text:
I came here on a Saturday for brunch and was pleasantly surprised that there was not a wait. We sat outside which was a really cool area. The service was great and the food was great as well. 

I had the breakfast burrito and a Bloody Mary. The breakfast burrito was very good and big. I was definitely full after eating it. The Bloody Mary was very good. I love the mix that they use. It had the perfect amount of spice with very good flavor. My girlfriend had the mushroom omelet. She thought it was a bit heavy, but she really enjoyed it. 

Overall I loved this place, especially the outdoor seating area. I definitely want to come back here sometime.

text: Nothing like Reading Terminal to give you a unique experience of the Amish markets, fresh  farm grown produce, squeezed juice, and a plethora of cultural cuisines. My favorites are the crepe place, Olympia Gyro, 4th street famous cookies (woww), Termini Bros Bakery (Cheesecake!!), DiNic's roast pork, Bassetts Ice Cream. It's a struggle to find seats and maneuver through the crowds, so be prepared !

text:
Jewish Heaven. Just the way my dad use to make my sandwiches. Big and obnoxious! Growing up in an all Gentile neighborhood the kids in my elementary school just didn't get it. I remember one girl used to get a hard boiled egg, a slice of bread and an apple. So I'd always give her the other half. 

Well me and my stacked meat sandwiches were a revelation compared to the PB J's and 1 Slice of cheese sandwiches that I witnessed all around me in the cafeteria during lunchtime!
oh yeah, back to the review. I had the whitefish platter and finally tried out the Cel-Ray soda that my boyfriend had been raving about. The amount of food I received on my platter made 4 sandwiches. So there was plenty of take home. Which I tentatively hid in the back of the fridge so my bo wouldn't find it. (he's such a foodie)
This place is a little heaven and the service was great. Jill was my waitress and a real doll. She said the tips weren't great which i was hard pressed to believe but I still slipped her a 40% tip. I recommend this place highly. Food was fresh, mounds and mounds, even the Q-tips at the Early birds in Florida would be jealous!

* Q-Tips are Seniors with white hair.. get it :)

text:
Went here for lunch with 5 co-workers for my bosses birthday. 

Service was very quick. GET THE CHEESESTEAK ROLLS! Seriously. They are amazing. 

I ordered the burger. Nothing special. Was cooked properly and tasted fresh. 2 pieces of bacon will cost you an extra $2-$3. But its damn good bacon. 

Our server bought out a free piece of cake for the boss man too, which was very nice.

For the style of place and time of day, a lunch for 6 ran about $110. Not bad at all.

text:
Everyone kept buzzing about this place for brunch so I gave in and tried it yesterday.  Went with 3 other people and surprisingly, we only had to wait maybe 20 minutes (it was about 2:00 in the afternoon), though I can imagine that if we had gotten there at prime brunch hour, like noonish, it would have been a longer wait.

Service was on point, coffee was rich, OJ was fresh, place was sunny and cute and accommodated tons of hungover customers.  As for the food, it was everything I was hoping it would be, delicious and in large portions.  Ordered the steak and eggs and smothered it in tabasco sauce.  Steak was cooked perfectly but my only complaint is that it was a bit heavy on the peppers and onions.  Friend ordered the Kitchen Sink which was essentially every type of breakfast food stuffed into a giant skillet and smothered in cheese and some delicious sauce.  Very, very filling and heavy.  Tried the mac and cheese side and that was also very good.  You definitely get your money's worth here.  Everything's so hearty.

Menu was extensive so I'd love to come back and order my original gut choice, which was the  fried chicken and waffles benedict dish or perhaps try the breakfast burrito or some type of pancake variation.

Dropped it down a star for the lack of alcohol (it's BYOB).  When I'm hungover, all I crave is a bloody mary or a mimosa or an Irish coffee to accompany my meal.  Next time I'll do my research and come prepared with a bottle of something.

Will definitely be back here!
name: Green Eggs Café

text: I love the Dandelion.  I have been here a few times for drinks and a few times for cocktails/snacks.  Every time the food has been exception and the service has been wonderful.  The food is traditional British food and tends to be on the heavier side, so come hungry.  The fish and chips and hangers and mash are outstanding.  The Mac and Cheese side is also delicious.  On occasion they make the most incredible brussel spouts with dried cranberries.  The seating is a little tight on the first floor, but the tables on the second floor tend to have more room.
name: The Dandelion

text: This place is really great, but that's no surprise. I was surprised that when I walked in at 5:30, the place wasn't crowded, considering Vedge is always packed. There weren't entry of seats at the bar and a lot of open tables. The restaurant itself is really pretty, and heads up they don't take reservations. The menu seems smaller than the Vedge menu. The best thing I ate was the mushroom dan dan noodles and the potatoes. Their dessert was killer too. I would definitely go back.

text:
This place was a great brunch spot with some unique options! I disagree with other reviewers who say that the portions are small, we all left completely stuffed. We started with the salmon toast, which could easily be meal. I tried the fried green benny but didn't love the combo of the cold cheese with the warm dish, but am glad I tried it. The rib hash was scrumptious and the lattes were fun and yummy. They are very generous with refilling coffee or if you get a latte they'll give you coffee in the mug once your done. 

It was bizarrely cold inside and a vent was flowing directly on my friends' legs so they all were sitting funny. Our server was very nice and helpful but he did. not. stop. talking. We were interrupting him so he'd stop repeating himself. The decor is very nice and the building was a former bank building so it's cool. We made reservations for brunch and did not need them for an early time slot.

text:
Very disappointed in the flavorless, dry black quinoa salad that set me back $10 for lunch.  Also had an OK $3.00 Arnold Palmer.  The quinoa salad at Pure Fare (and even the frozen Quinoa Bowls I get at Whole Foods) are far superior and cheaper.

Not a fan of this place any more.
Over-priced and not that good.

I should have stuck with the green submarine (glad it's still on the menu).
Skip this place and go elsewhere for a better lunch for less money.

text:
In celebrating my friend and my 20 year friendiversary, we made reservations for a late Sunday brunch.  Since Front Street Cafe was a good half way meeting point. Our reservations were for 3:30pm but we quickly found out that the brunch menu was no longer being served at that time, and the kitchen closed at 4pm.  Wishful thinking on our part I guess.  We were told as we seated that there was also an automatic 20% gratuity and a 90 minute sitting time limit.  Which is fine, and understood due to the times we're in.

Although it was a misty day, we decided to eat in their tent covered outside area.  We ordered drinks from the vast beer menu.  And ordered sandwiches since those were the only options at the time.  I ordered the fried chicken sandwich which was really good and the fries were thick and also good.  All in all a great time and the food was pretty good although I look forward to trying their actual brunch menu.

text: Never disappointed in the products, just the rudeness of people.  So many places to shop for fresh veg and fruit, keep your eye out for the lowest prices.  Smoked meats and beef jerky are a must have!  Very fresh fish at John Yi, always super nice staff there!

text:
I really don't get the hype about Lorenzo Pizza...sure, the slice is HUGE and that is not an exaggeration! It will be served on two paper plates and be bigger than your head, no lie.

It will also cost you $3 plus $1 per topping. You are going to want toppings because there is absolutely nothing special about this pizza besides it size and convenient location to South Street bars. 

That being said, I would surely not turn down a *quick slice of Lorenzo's after a night of drinking. (*QUICK would be depending on the time you go. If there is a line down the street, run away and go somewhere else!! A line would normally not deter me...I'll wait in line forever for a Jim's cheesesteak, but no way in hell would I wait for Lorenzo's pizza!!)

This pizza is thin and very plain...there are too many amazing pizza places in Philly to go here any other time of the day. If you're around South Street and willing to spend more than $3, go to Nomad or Stella! It will be WELL WORTH spending a little more for MUCH better food.

text:
If i were to recommend a place to have a great sandwich in philadelphia this would be the place I would recommend. 

First off, come with an appetite, because the sandwiches are seriously huge! get the Zaftig if you're REALLY hungry. The meat is so fresh and tasty and the staff is really friendly. 
 
Get the smoked turkey Reuben you will not regret it.

text:
By the name of the place, I was thinking soul food. Then I read the menu and in thinking east coast, Jewish?

It's definitely comfort food meets Jewish and southern with some vegan/organic thrown in. 

Very very eclectic.

You walk in and see the hipsters and decor and know why. It suddenly clicked with me.

The food was excellent.

My family had pulled chicken tacos and chicken fingers.

I had biscuits and gravy with fried eggs, turkey sausage, and a latke.

All very very good.

Just know - it's cash only... And make sure to check the specials on the chalk board. I didn't even notice them and had already ordered.

The only negative - my chocolate chip cookie. It wasn't that good. Had it been better - this place would have been a 5.

text: I have been living above the SPTR for over a year and a half and have gone in more than a few times.  I have noticed that they have changed little things over that time that I like, one example is their housemade ketchup it used to be horrible but their new iteration is actually quite good.  The one thing that I am happy with is their burger, just awesome and get it medium rare.  They always have good spicy pickled vegetables and hot sauce.  I have had some good apps here like the tacos and the tripe tostada when they had it.  They always have a good selection of beers and liquors and the staff is definitely friendly.  My favorite thing though is the ricotta apple donuts, they are just awesome and I have to get them everytime we visit.  This place has become a major destination for people in and out of the neighborhood and that is cool and it's nice to be just a flight of stairs away from it all.
name: South Philadelphia Tap Room

text:
OMG. Pure food bliss. You can stop reading this review right now and go make a reservation (for a month out, since it takes that long to get a spot!).

I went with a party of 4 (girls' night out), and we made the fantastic decision to do the chef's tasting menu. This basically means you can stop ordering and just let the waiter bring you dish after amazing dish, culminating in the mouth-watering lamb. (More on the lamb in a minute.)

I don't remember too many specifics of all the dishes that we had, but they were all amazing. The thing I remember most clearly is how incredible the hummus was. I haven't had hummus that good since I was in Israel. You'll want more, I promise.

Now, the lamb. Some of the best lamb I have had ever. It is brined for a day, braised for two days, then roasted for another day in a molasses and pomegranate marinade. It was FANTASTIC. Simply falling off the bone, no knives necessary. Amazingly flavorful. (Side note: the waiter told us the meat is braised at their sister restaurant, Percy Street BBQ, and after tasting the lamb we made it a priority to head over and try the meat there. Check out my review on that page as well.)

I would highly recommend this place for a special night out. Plan ahead, because it can be hard to get reservations (in my experience). Go now!
name: Zahav

text:
Pietro's used to be my go-to spot for a nice meal at a decent price. I've always loved their salads and pasta. It had been a while since my last meal there and I threw it out as an option for a weeknight dinner. 

My fiance and I each ordered a glass of red wine. Wines by the glass are very limited with regards to selection and cost around $8-$11. My glass of cab was pretty bad... but not as bad as my fiance's sangiovese. We shared an arugula salad which was nice, but priced steeply at $11 for what was essentially a plate of arugula, sun dried tomatoes and some parmesan. 

Both of us ordered basic pasta entrees; cheese ravioli for him and pasta bolognese for me. I requested wheat fettuccine and the dish arrived with wheat penne. I sent it back and our server came over to tell me that the only wheat pasta available was the penne. I opted for plain fettuccine, instead. I know in the past the pasta was always made fresh but I think things have changed. The portion sizes are still pretty large, and I had plenty for lunch the following day. 

For sixty bucks plus tip, Pietro's just isn't cutting it. As we ate, we rattled off several other Italian restaurants with better food and pricing; places we'll likely end up next time.
name: Pietro's Coal Oven Pizzeria

text:
i consider myself to be a chicken finger connoisseur, and i have to say, the ones here are bangin! they are big and juicy but not fatty and have this wonderful spicy honey dipping sauce. drool. 

this is comfort food, dressed up *just* enough that you could bring a date here and they wouldn't think you were lame.

i'm not in love with the bar scene upstairs, but i'll definitely be back for dinner.

text: So a friend and I decided to go here for lunch during restaurant week the other day. I have lived in the neighborhood and always wanted to go here but just never got around to it, and wow, am I glad I did. The food was great for the most part. My only real complaint was that the red sauce on the enchiladas was a bit on the salty side. The server was excellent as well. I would definitely recommend this place!

text:
[This review was made in 10/2020 during the COVID-19 pandemic]

My friend and I had intentions on going to an Italian restaurant, but after a change of plans, we ended up here with an even larger group of friends! I had never heard of this place before nor had I tried German food before, but as my fine arts professor once said in college, "It's never bad to try everything at least once!"

Because I wanted to try so much of the menu, my friend and I split two dishes. We split the Wiener Schnitzel (chicken) and the Schweinshaxe! Coming here made me realize how similar cuisines can be between cultures. The Wiener Schnitzel is a breaded chicken cutlet that came with fries on the side and it really reminded my of the Japanese katsus that I've had in many ramen eateries. The Schweinshaxe, which is Brauhaus Schmitz' specialty, is a crispy pork shank with a dunkel lager jus and wow was this delicious. For those of you who have had Filipino food, this is very similar to crispy pata, but of course with German flavors. Of the two, the Schweinshaxe was my favorite.

I did see that they had rooftop seating, which I will try the next time I get the chance. We were seated on the extended sidewalk, which was very loud at times, but bearable. Regardless, it was good food with good company, and that's all that you can really ask for.
name: Brauhaus Schmitz

text:
A great dining experience!  This had been on my list of places to try for awhile and I finally made it over.  Upon walking up, you notice they have a large outdoor area creating a backyard patio feel among high rise buildings.  The decor on the inside gives off a very homey feeling.

Onto the food, we shared a cheese plate and were blown away by our servers vast knowledge of the 6 cheeses.  The cheeses were accompanied by different types of bread and fruits/meats.  For entrees we had the snapper and chicken and split a side of the mushrooms.  Both entrees were satisfying and the mushrooms were particularly fresh.  

Drinks were moderately priced and strong.

Can't wait to get back here once the weather warms up.

text:
Oysters and beer?  Yes please.

I have been coming to the Oyster House for a few years now.  I can remember when it used to be called the Sansom Street Oyster House and the design was completely different.  That first time sold me and I have been back many times since.

Most recently, I came here on a Friday evening for the tail end of happy hour.  The place was packed but we were able to get a seat at the bar.  We had 18 of the daily oysters and a few Love Stouts from Yards.  I don't think it gets much better than this.  Simple, fresh and delicious.

I love the design and layout of the restaurant.  This is one of the places where I would take out-of-towners to show them something great or meet up with an old friend for a place to hang out, have some drinks and awesome seafood.

text:
Great local place!  Ridiculous beer selection - if you can't find something here, you're being overly pretentious.  I don't even like beer and I still found one to order (raspberry, yum).

The mussels are crazy good, with lots of bread to soak up the delicious broth.  I've had the DeKoninck and Herge, both wonderful.  I've also tried the pork sandwich which was a special one afternoon - it was heavy by comparison but equally delicious. 

Really cute place, very laid back.  Very glad it's in my neighborhood.  Have been here with a friend and alone, and felt perfectly at home every time.
name: The Belgian Café

text:
My husband and I had a date night here last week. We loved the atmosphere and the experience. 
Appetizers:
We decided to order an order of escargot (my first time trying it) and the mushroom tart. The escargot reminded me of chewing into a mushroom soaked in garlic and butter. It was hard not to like, although it was too rich for me to eat more than two. The escargot came with some crostini as well. The mushroom tart was so flaky and delicious. I would order it again if I returned for another dinner. 
Entree:
I ordered the salmon Provençal which was a lovely piece of fish with a caramelized crust, lentils, and veggies. The flavors were well-balanced and I ate the whole dish happily. The portion was enough for one person to be full and satisfied.
My husband ordered the prime rib special. It came with horseradish and mashed potatoes. The prime rib was juicy, but we both liked the salmon better.

text:
Sweet potato fries are pretty awesome. Try them with the Sriracha aioli. Udon noodle salad is meh. Not enough black bean dressing, and the noodles are pretty bland. Arugula does not pair well. Very filling though. Their mock chicken is definitely some of the best tofu-based that I have had. Well seasoned and savory.

Much smaller than the one in University City. The place has around 10 seats. Cross your fingers that you can grab one during peak hours. Really friendly staff and you can definitely tell that management spends time hiring some great people.

text:
not once have i gone to honey's for a weekend brunch and not incurred a wait of at least 30 minutes to upwards of an hour. on occasion i have been so hungry [and/or hungover] that even a 5 minute wait seemed impossible, thereby leading me to nearby alternatives north 3rd or the abbaye. both are good...but neither hold a candle to the deliciousness that is honey's.

today was one of those days where we were willing to wait the 45 minutes while our stomachs rumbled in anticipation of the meal to come. we passed the time by people watching and contemplating whether to go breakfast or lunch (seeing as it was 2pm), all the while growing more & more eager as other 2-tops being called had tired of the wait and left, making us that much closer to Next.
 
within moments of sitting down, we were handed menus and asked if we wanted coffee - yes, please! since enjoying the enfrijoladas so much on my last visit, i was set on ordering them again. this time instead of getting it made with tofu, i went for the vegan sausage. equally as delish. as if that wasn't enough food, i added a latke + [homemade] applesauce on the side for a mere $2.50. 

my boyfriend went the lunch route and ordered the brisket sandwich, topped with melted cheese & sauteed spinach, served with a side of horseradish sauce & fries. this led to me eating fries for the 3rd time this week (that's typically how many times i eat them in a month!) as i simply could not resist dipping them in the tangy horseradish sauce.

there are so many veg-friendly options at honey's that i sorta kick myself for getting the same one twice, but i fully intend to eat here enough to try everything [meatless] on the menu.


[ random aside:  i had parked on 3rd street, just north of poplar, which as i later learned is a popular spot for birds to gather on the telephone poles. when we returned to the car, it looked like it had gone to war with the entire winged population of philadelphia....and lost. this required a quick detour to the nearest car wash (11th & spring garden - thanks, GPS!) where, $16 later, it was as if my car had never been the crap-magnet that it was. all in all, the meal was still well worth it! ]
name: Honey's Sit-N-Eat

text:

They are cash only so go prepared with some bills. I still like Jim's on South better!

text:
A special occasion calls for a ridiculously expensive meal. And I'd gladly fork over another $230 a person for the chef's tasting and wine pairings whether it was a special occasion or not. As soon as I get another $230, that is.
Staff members were so gracious I wished I could hug them.  I actually said out loud (after a few pre-dinner drinks and downing two glasses of the wine flight) that they knew us so well yet didn't know us at all - in reference to how they selected the courses for each of us. I really like whites over reds and my partner vice versa and every dish I secretly wished to eat was placed in front of me. Dreamy.
The sommelier then poured us a glass of Agricola Punica "Barrua" 2005 which he said is reserved for "friends." Love you, too, buddy. For someone like me, who lives to eat, it's nice to be served by people who know their shit and love it their shit.
The menu changes frequently so I'll just say that you should pray to whatever god you serve that you'll get to taste Vetri's foie gras pastrami, their fregola with octopus and the baby goat. 
Once all is (sadly) said and done you're waived "Arrivederci" with a fancy tote, biscotti and menu copies. Ciao, I'll miss you.
name: Vetri Cucina

text:
Love me some Honeygrow. Fresh ingredients & so many options (if you're an indecisive, semi-insane person such as myself, ordering could take a solid half an hour). 

The touchscreen order machines are super convenient, but it gets crazy crowded during peak hours so plan accordingly. I've probably tried 10 different combos of stir fry/ salad, and I've never been disappointed.

This about the only thing that I ever order here because it is awesome.  Watch out for the Hot Sauce Style Chicken because it can pack some heat.

text:
Delicious! 
The cheese curds were as good as people say they are. Light, crispy batter on the outside, not-too-chewy cheese on the inside, and two great sauces. 
The mussels and sausage appetizer ($14) was my entree, and I couldn't finish it! The mussels were small so they were tender, and the garlic bread was great!
My friends loved their cocktails and their dinners. They had the chicken (three big pieces) and the steak with potatoes, respectively. The snickers cake was huge (the three of us shared it) and so good!! Chewy caramel, marshmallow, dark chocolate...heaven.
We definitely enjoyed our dinner here.

text:
One of the best places for Greek in the city. The cold appetizer sampler is the whole reason I come here. 5 or 6 different dips - regular hummus, garlic hummus, caviar, feta, eggplant and others - are so good that I can't even say which is my favorite because it changes every single time. They also do a mixed grill for two which is really good, every meat on the platter is always cooked perfectly. Also, the potatoes are so delicious... I have no idea what they do to make potatoes taste so great but I am glad they do do it! If me and one other person go and split these two things the bill will be less than $50 and we'll have enough leftovers to make at least two more meals out of it. Really great value.

Ambience is pretty cool, you can sit outside if the weather is nice and it's right across from Eastern State Penitentiary so makes for a nice vibe.

Also, it's BYO as another added perk!

text:
First time here. Came for lunch on a Wednesday. Loved it! 

I really like the atmosphere. It is kind of dark which is always a bummer when it's a bright, beautiful day out but I still really liked the look of the inside. They have high tops and low tops. We sat at a high top. It was a little odd that the table and chairs were the height that they were. We felt like the chairs either needed to be higher or the table slightly lower. We managed, though. 

Our server was excellent. He was very friendly and answered all of our questions. He was seating people, taking orders, going up and down for the food and serving drinks from the bar. There were other staff members but he was the star of the show at this particular time. Kudos to him! I'm so sad I can't remember his name!

They have DELICIOUS fountain soda! 

I checked out the menu on Yelp and decided I was going to get the French Dip. We get the menu at the restaurant...no French Dip! I asked the server if they used to have one and he said yes, it was so good and he missed it too. Such a letdown! I hate when people don't update their menus online. 

They did have some specials, though which we both ultimately decided on. I got the fish taco special which was made with Halibut and my Dad got the Ahi Tuna special served with cous cous. He thought  the Ahi entree was excellent. My fish tacos were good. The fish was fried. I felt they could have used a bit of sauce so I asked for limes. He brought me one lime slice for each taco which I appreciated and they did the trick! The tacos were served alone...no rice or beans. They were $19 which was a bit steep in my opinion. Both of these specials were served with an accompanying beer. That's awesome...if you like beer. I don't like or drink beer. My Dad is not a huge beer fan, either. The server said it was part of the price and the price didn't change if you didn't get the beer. That doesn't seem right to me. What if you are under 21...or pregnant...or a recovering alcoholic...or you just don't like beer?!?! I mean, I'll pay the $19 but I would rather have rice and beans than beer! 

We did not get dessert. 

The bathrooms are STRANGE! You walk back to the restroom area and you can go left or right. They are all unisex stalls. The doors go from top to bottom. There is a sink inside each stall. The toilet wouldn't flush. Not a fan of these bathrooms. They didn't seem super clean, either. Especially since we were what appeared to be the first customers of the day. It's bad enough when bathrooms aren't clean at the end of a long shift but at the beginning?!?! Why weren't they cleaner? I did appreciate the fact that there's a sink at the entryway to the bathroom. So if you just wanted to wash your hands before or after dining, you could do that. 

They do not accept Open Table reservations which always annoys me! It's 2017...join Open Table! 

Despite some slight hiccups, I would definitely recommend this place and I will return.
name: 2nd Story Brewing

text:
Authentic Szechuan cuisine elevated.

The house Dan Dan Noodles are very good, if a bit too soft. For what it's worth, I am still partial to Han Dynasty's rendition of the dish. Still, it's Jane G's other dishes which truly set it apart.

The Beef Lover's Quarrel is served cold and comes with beef tendon, shank, and tripe marinated in chili oil with peanuts and cilantro. YUM! Chewy, salty, spicy, and oh-so-savory. We ordered at spiciness level 4 -- it packs a punch, but if you like spice then I highly recommend it! If this doesn't sound appealing to you, maybe try ordering a Wawa sandwich on the next block instead.

Jane G's "double cook fish", however, was the real star of the show. Thick, tender fish, marinated, battered, and crispy-fried with leeks and soybeans, then topped with savory chili oil. Asian-style comfort food at its finest, and the large portions are definitely enough to share.

If spicy is your thing, definitely give Jane G's a try!

text:
I will always choose Pats for "authentic cheese steak". However compared to the good old days (growing up in south philadelphia) I am disappointed with how unfriendly the service became and how expensive a small section of cheesesteak you get.

Unbelievably sad. Where does all the money go? I mean you make money from each customer but you don't really change or fix anything to the building nor the grill you cook on. Why make it so expensive for everyone?  Is it because of the competition across the street? At least I can see the changes that genos are making!

Make it cheaper!!! And smile when people order food, look people in the eye when they pay you an arm and leg for a small cheesesteak. It's just sad that for the fame and the past that such a place stays open. I am just disappointed.

Nonetheless I will still bring my first timer friends here because I stay loyal as a Pats fan.

text:
This update is for restaurant week:

So sooo worth it. I thought since it's a multi course thing for restaurant week the portions would be small but that couldn't be further from the truth. For $20 (came here for lunch) you get an app, an entree, and dessert and they really don't skimp out on the portions or give you "restaurant week sized" portions. I got the hot Nashville buns which were delicious (shout out to the pickled veggies on top of the bun adding a delicious crisp to the buns. I had some of my coworkers fried chicken sandwich which was good, but the curried chicken Cobb salad was an absolute stunner. Beautiful colors, really good vinaigrette dressing, and I appreciate that they give you the pesto dressing on the side to avoid over dressing the salad. The desserts (we got bread pudding and apple crisp) were massive and really topped off a great meal.

It also seems like a lot of restaurant week menus are pretty bland/simple but this place really had a big diversity of different courses to pick from. As always a cool vibe and very nice servers as well!

text:
Barcade is great if only to relive the childhood delights of Ms. PacMan (No, but seriously, whatever happened to just PacMan? I mean...really?), and Mario World in Arcade game format. 

Also, anyone remember when Donkey Kong was about climbing up ladders and avoiding fireballs? Me neither, but apparently in 1981, it was so.

It's also kind of fun that Barcade is super hidden from humanity and that from the outside it looks like another victim of urban decay. 

Alas, for all its treasures, Barcade lacks the one game that would have added those additional two stars - and somebody please correct me if I idiotically over looked this gem - but my dear Street Fighter was no where to be found. Sad. Face.

text:
Amazing food and great ambiance, what more could you ask for? Oh yeah, DRINKS! Those are great as well!

My favorite time to go to alma de cuba is for Happy Hour. The downstairs bar area is the perfect escape to go to after work. Until 6:30 they have drink specials and 1/2 off of all of their appetizers. Great to go with a few friends and split some food! It also works as a great spot for a romantic date and has additional seating for dining upstairs.

Must haves:
Smoked albacore tacos, tuna tartar tacos, truffle guacamole, ceviche SAMPLER (pick a few of the ones that sound best), dorado. For drinks I love their black cherry caiprinha and white sangria. 
For dessert I highly recommend the coconut tapioca pudding. I often order this for take out as well because it is so good. It comes in a young coconut and you can scrape the sides of it off with your fork/spoon as you eat the pudding. Delish!
name: Alma de Cuba

text:
Amidst the horror of my life as it currently stands, my bf and I had to celebrate our anniversary. Without reservations, we grabbed a bottle of white wine and made our way to Mercato, hoping against hope that they could seat us on a Sunday night. What luck! They had a table for two available right then and we eagerly sat down.

We were tempted by the 4 course tasting menu they offer for $48 pp, but we do love to share plates and instead opted to have an appetizer, pasta dish and entree. The waiter had nicely chilled our wine bottle on our table so we could pour for ourselves (which we did, quite liberally). We noted several patrons enjoying the calamari appetizer, so we chose that to begin with - and it was perfect! Seriously, I have never had more tender calamari - I keep saying that at new restaurants, but this time I REALLY MEAN IT. BEST CALAMARI EVER. Not even a hint of rubbery texture, and all the combined ingredients complemented each other amazingly. We went with our server's suggestion and ordered the shrimp and clams spaghetti, sauteed with pancetta, garlic and olive oil - AMAZING, delicious, they know the definition of al dente! We finished with their chicken stuffed with fontina, sweet italian sausage & apples, creamy sage polenta, and topped with arugula - except I don't know how we managed to finish it all! That entree was so filling - but more importantly it was the BEST chicken entree I've had at any restaurant, or even SEEN on any menu. This is the one chicken dish you don't want to miss! After a meal like that, though, we had to skip dessert - and walk around for an hour afterward to burn it off! So delicious, so perfect - we are SO GOING BACK THERE FOR MORE ITALIAN DELICACIES!!!
name: Mercato BYOB

text:
We accidentally entered through the exit, but this shouldn't have been a problem because the place was empty. A man came in the same door after us, but this appeared to be fine with the staff because they knew him. They began to have a conversation while we tried to order. There was one customer waiting for an order. However, we received dirty looks from the two women there, and they were rude to us. I asked about the long hots, but I only got a side of attitude. 

The meat on the sandwich was dry, there was minimal cheese (sharp provolone), and the roll didn't taste fresh.

This is the second time I've been here, and they were out of the "homemade Italian long hots," which are advertised as an option for your sandwich ($1.00). Spinach is the only topping (other than mild or sharp provolone) for the pork.
name: John's Roast Pork

text:
Honest Tom's is one of my fav places for Mexican food around Penn campus. 
I am a vegetarian and I have tried their rice and bean, sweet potato burritos and tacos! I love the sweet potato tacos - the sweet potato pieces were fried n crispy, together with other veggies plus sauces the tacos were delightful! I would recommend splashing a little lime over the tacos because it was missing during my recent take-out.
I like hot and spicy food and Honest Tom's has a good set of sauces to go with their food. I really like their spicy taco sauce and jalapeño sauces.
Food's a little pricey, $6.50 for 2 tacos and ~$8 burritos..however the portion sizes are a little bigger than those in food trucks.
I just have one complaint: they don't deliver anymore....sad because I would love to get their food delivered for meetings at work, oh well!
name: Honest Tom's Plant Based Taco Shop

text:
I went there two weeks ago for the first time. I went with two friends, and we were extremely happy with the value and quality. 

I whole-heartedly agree that the Roti Canai is a major highlight, and we also tried the Satay Tofu & Penang Poh Piah. I'm not a huge tofu fan, but I enjoyed the Satay, and we all agreed that the spring rolls had an excellent, complimentary sauce. 

I ordered the chicken curry as my main dish and made short work of it, as my friends did with their dishes (I don't recall for sure what they went with). I didn't try anything I didn't like, and we were very happy with portions & prices.
name: Penang
