text:
Kanella...you've been added to my super special list of top places to dine in Philadelphia.

We arrived on time for our reservations for my birthday and were seated immediately at the corner table by the window on Spruce. If you are seated along the wall, you will be sitting on a wooden bench flanked with embellished pillows.

Our server came over right away, and grabbed some wine glasses for our beer-you-drink-out-of-wine-glasses. He explained the specials with such presentation and and conviction that I was actually listening, and enticed by what he described!

We chose the Dips of the Day to start. Awesome! I ended up choosing one of the specials described by our waiter. It's like they read my mind with this entree! Lamb meatballs, delicious veggies, and greek yogurt! Mixing it all about on my plate served me so well. The portion was perfect - I cleaned my plate (a rarity)! The boyfriend had the quail and enjoyed it a lot.

Everything was perfect about Kanella, and I'll take any chance I can get to have another meal here soon! Particularly...brunch!

text: All I can say is, wait for the new one to open up. There was so much hype behind this dining experience, that I expected to have my socks knocked off, but they remained firmly in place. Not that it was bad. The DanDan Noodles delivered their peanut-y, slippery tastiness, but they're still just noodles. We split the Fiery Shrimp, and it was indeed fiery, but that requires adding lots of chili flakes, not culinary genius. The good news is, during this slow dining hour, the employees were cleaning fresh string beans, so the food was fresh. The bad news is, they did this in the dining room. Maybe wouldn't have normally bothered me if I didn't have to point out to our server that a mouse just scurried by. Like I said....wait for the one across the street to open up. I'll give it another shot with some fresh mojo.
name: Han Dynasty

text:
As excited as I am for Beddia's latest accolades I am also fearful of all the silly people who will now try to tarnish the reputation of this fine establishment because they are entitled babies. No, there's no phone. Yes, there is a chance you won't get pizza because people are lining up for pizza now. Yes, he only makes a certain amount each day. SHUT UP! Seriously, stop complaining. That's why it's good. If you read the article on Bon Appetit and all you understood from it was that you were entitled to eat the pizza, then I question your reading comprehension. 

The hours aren't bullshit. They open at 5:30. If twenty people line up before opening and 14 people buy two pizzas, crazy stoner Barry buys three, and the nine others get one each, that's forty pizzas. That is not bullshit. That's some standardized testing next level pizza math.
name: Pizzeria Beddia

text: Ahhhh El Vez.   It's been awhile since I have been to this establishment as I am typically jonesin' for Italian.  Anyway,  I started with the traditional guacamole and their queso fundido con carne.  I felt like the guacamole could have used a pinch more of salt  and the fundito was the second best in the city.  El Ray has the best fundito.  I had the steak tacos for my entree and my husband had the pork.  The steak was really good and the pork wasn't that great.  The reason I am giving them 3 stars is because of the service.  How many times did we have to call our waitress over to get more alcohol?  3.  That's 3 times too many in my book!  I know if was probably close to the end of her shift (10pm) but the one thing that makes me crazy is not having an alcoholic beverage in front of me at all times when I go out to dinner.  I can see if our waitress might have missed my very empty cocktail glass but my dinner companions had empty beer bottles as well.  No bueno El Vez.  No bueno.

text:
I had the pleasure of eating at Vetri when a parent treated me to a meal there a few weeks ago.

Perhaps it was because I'm a vegetarian, but we didn't get to partake in any amuses (although I noticed the table next to us had several). I was also surprised at how small the space was - cozy, perhaps a little too cozy, but very homey nonetheless.

The cauliflower flan attracted my attention for the rich egg yolk that spilled over the plate as soon as I cut into it, but it lacked seasoning and seemed slightly one-note.

I also had the sweet onion crepe, which was, as another review mentioned, reminiscent of french onion soup, except elevated by the taste of truffles - and the fact that it was delicious! Don't skip over this if you visit Vetri.

Continuing on the truffle theme, I loved the almond tortellini with truffles. More so, even, than the gnocchi. After reading so many Yelp reviews about how ethereal the spinach gnocchi was,  I felt it fell short in comparison to the tortellini, although it was delicious and incredibly light. The almond tortellini just offered another dimension of being more umami-rich, with the heavier application of truffle oil and cheeses.

I had the cheese plate for dessert. Going with the truffle theme, I enjoyed the truffle cheese the most. I would have appreciated more bread with the board. Overall, I don't think this justified the price point.

Vetri was a great experience, but after reading so many glowing review on Yelp, it fell a little short of my expectations. That said, the food was incredibly good - but not good enough to justify being an experience on my own budget and price points.
name: Vetri Cucina

text:
So, when my sister, who has been stalking the opening of this place for weeks, suggested we go here on opening day I thought she was crazy.  But it ended up being a nice experience. So much that we went there twice in the same evening!  Once for dinner and once for a post auto show beverage.

We got there early, at 5, and the place was surprisingly low key. Of course there were some opening day festivities going on, but I'll skip all that and move on to the good stuff..

Staff: the staff was really nice and friendly!  They were totally awesome. All of them. Yay to you all for being so cheery and excited!  

Drink:  They have booze!  Wine, beer - however I didn't notice if they had the hard stuff?  But the beer and wine was reasonably priced. My only complaint was that none of the beers were local. Oh, and the tap system wasn't working yet..woops! 

Food:  Great menu.  With the only exception being a chicken hot dog, everyone had a burger and there wasn't a single complaint!  I can't say I'm a fan of hot dogs, but the chicken dog Chicago style was delish!  Try the urban fries, you won't regret it. And the onion rings were massive and delicious too.  Oh, and they have pretty decadent looking milkshakes.  There is an abundance of burger toppings and there is a Veg Burger patty as well.

Atmosphere:  Super cute interior. Lots of wood, metal and polished concrete done in an urban but warm way. Oh, and the light fixtures are cool, especially the ones over the communal table.


Bonus: although I do not consider myself to be the greatest speller, there is a spelling error on their menu!
name: BurgerFi

text:
NommingNomad Approved!

Sabrina's is one of my go to spots for Brunch and I take all my friends and family who visit me, because it is one of the classics where I know what I want without even looking at the menu. The Stuffed Challah French Toast is life changing and everyone needs to try it atleast once. For me that's a definite everytime  I go here. But I'd suggest getting one for the table and splitting it, because it is humongous. Oh man I want it even as I'm writing this review. 

Philly gem with great food "tummy hug" food and you have to experience it!

text:
**THIS REVIEW IS SPECIFICALLY IN REFERENCE TO MY PHILLY CHEESESTEAK TASTING ADVENTURE -Please refer to my review of Cosmi's Deli for background & stipulations of the quest**

Although Tony Luke's cheesesteak performed quite well overall, it received significantly lower ratings on two categories: aroma and visual appeal. The sandwich, although claiming one of the thickest cuts of meat, lost points due to the "grayish" shade of its fillings. Comments also point to its small size and overly tough roll.

Scoring a solid 7.0, Tony Luke's comes in at fifth overall - he just doesn't look good doing it.

(Full result details can be found at: http://22ndandphilly.blogspot.com/2011/06/reader-contribution-operation-whiz-wit.html)

text:
Went in for a late night dinner yesterday and got the sizzling short ribs in pepper sauce along with some Chinese greens.....ummm ummm good !! How can it get any better than thin tender slices or succulent short ribs in a peppered sauce. 

Of course I had to get the roast pork noodle soup and shrimp wontons to go.

Next time I want to try the lobster dinner for 2 (or 4 or 6) ... all for myself ;-)

text:
I have been to Prohibition many times and always like it. I hadn't been in ages so we made a trip over on Friday. They were nice and accommodating to our last minute party of 7 even though 1 person was about 45 minutes late. That didn't stop us from ordering apps and drinks while we waited for her. However the waitress had multiple mood swings about this. 1 minute it was fine the next she asked multiple times if we wanted to order food/drink. This is while we are eating 3 apps and everyone has a beverage. Happens to the best of us I guess. To clarify, the restaurant was barely 50% occupied. She was nice in that she split up the bill for us by whoever was sharing what which made or an easy paying experience. Love that! 

The food is always really well done we ordered a variety of things, fried pickles - so good, fish and chips - my friend enjoyed them, chicken pot pie was on special but didn't excite my friend too much, the meatless philly cheesesteak was enjoyable (I had a taste and was pleasantly surprised, you can also order sans bread if you like the waitress pointed out!) lastly we got the pickled veggies which were really interestingly done.

Always a great, relaxed spot. If I was closer I would go way more!

text:
This place is gorgeous with an amazing view.  I asked if we could sit outside for dinner and although the dining outdoor area was full, they accommodated us and arranged for us to sit in the outdoor cafe area.  I'm not sure if the dining area would have been nicer but it wasn't too shabby where we were.  

The food was nicely presented and well done.  I order the Alaskan Halibut and my friend had the Club Steak.  Both dishes were good but it's still Fish and Steak.  Their menu isn't very vast or impressive but I think like Water Works, they're selling the experience, not just the food.  All in all though, the bill came out to only about $90 for the two of us, and that included 2 glass of wine, 2 glasses of IPA, a shared appetizer and two entrees.  I still think their was a mistake on the bill but I didn't question it at the time.  

Good date place to go if you want to impress, but for food....there's a 5 Guys Burger down the street.

text:
Good food (at least some of it), terrible service. 

I came last week with my SO, and my sister and her boyfriend. We wanted Mexican food and I don't eat animal products, and while most Mexican restaurants can make food vegan by just giving you rice and beans, we chose Cantina because it has dedicated vegan/vegetarian dishes. 

The Food: 
Overall the food was good, with some misses.
-Chip & Guacamole: good and very standard in flavor ($8) 
-Tofu & seitan fajitas which my SO and I shared: w/wild mushrooms, peppers, onions, black beans, white rice, pico de gallo, guacamole, and flour tortillas. The fajitas were GREAT and we were both really happy with our order, however it comes with too much guacamole and too little rice/beans/pico de gallo. It's also a decently sized portion so it was the perfect sharing size (just order more tortillas, rice, and beans). 
-Mushroom empanadas and esquites (corn): my sister is a big fan of taking the multiple appetizers as an entree route, and she said she was happy with her choices here. 
-Enchiladas suizas (chicken): This came out lukewarm, and my sister's boyfriend had to ask someone to heat it up. They took it without apologizing or asking further. When they did bring it back and he got to eat it warm, he wasn't into it. 

The Service:
Slow and at times nonexistent. 
-When out waitress first came to our table to ask about drinks and food everything seemed fine. She brought water and said she'd be back in a bit to ask about food. 
-When she came back to ask about food she forgot to ask about the specials, so none of us realized that there were specials until after we had placed out orders (we happened to spot the specials board). 
-Water was rarely refilled and when we made a request it would often take upwards of 15 minutes for anything to happen. As an example, my SO and I ordered more tortillas, rice, and beans. It took 20 minutes, by which point our dining partners had finished eating. 
-When we asked for dessert and the check, it took 20+ minutes for the dessert to come out, and when it did, the check was nowhere to be found. We again asked for the check, which was not brought out until I went up to someone in the kitchen and asked again. 

If they didn't have tons of vegan options (very clearly labeled with **) I wouldn't even consider returning given the service. That being said, if you are vegan I would still recommend coming if you want Mexican food (just don't expect much from the service).
name: Cantina Dos Segundos

text:
3 star aspects, and 5 star aspects so I settled for 4

My BF and I were craving Pizza the other night and we started to head towards Zavino. Barbuzzo is right next door and we wondered if we should try something new. So we inquired at Barbuzzo. It was very busy when I walked in but I saw two tables available outside so I went to ask the Hostess if we could sit there. I waited nearly 10 minutes for the hostess to come back to her station (that was a three star moment) no servers bothered to stop and say hi or help me or tell me the hostess would be back. When she finally arrived back she was very polite and nice. I asked if we could sit outside, she said absolutely, grabbed two menus and led us out there.

The Server:
After we were seated outside our server (Cassandra) was right behind us. Greeted us got us water and then explained menu impeccably. She was very friendly and had this super smile (I formed a teeny girl crush on her instantly and wanted to be her friend, she just seemed like one of those awesome people you want be friends with). She took our order we got the pototo pizza, and the margarhita, and a beer (which she recommended based on the pizza we  got) Server def. 5 stars!

The Food:
The potato pizza was amazing!!! 5 stars! The margherita was 3 stars. The amount of mozzerella was good. Perfect large melted circles. But barely any sauce, it had dried up or evaporated when they baked it or something. So I asked the food runner for a side of sauce and I dipped my pizza.

I would come back and try the pizza again and maybe just ask for more sauce.

text: Came for brunch one Friday morning and was delighted by the friendly service, great food, and pleasant ambience. We sat by the window overlooking the outdoor greenhouse section. The interior decors were so pretty which made the brunch experience even better. We got the Smoked Salmon Eggs Benedict and the Cornmeal Dutch Baby Pancake. The potato hash that came with the Smoked Salmon Eggs Benedict was very tasty but the highlight of the brunch was the Cornmeal Dutch Baby Pancake. The pancake came in a cute cast iron skillet and was bursting with flavors. Highly recommend this place for brunch!

text: This place is great! My only qualm is that their lemongrass soup broth tasted pretty beefy...as a pescetarian it's always tricky eating Asian food, and if you're stricter than me about accidentally eating meat-based products you might want to avoid this place. Otherwise, the portions were large, served piping hot, and our waiter was friendly and more than willing to make a substitution for my meal so that I could have shrimp (not beef) in lemongrass broth. Both my lemongrass and my boyfriend's beef broth soup definitely had a kick which we enjoyed. And the bean sprouts, lime, jalapeno, basil, and dandelion (I think?) to mix in were fresh. This place was even hopping on a Sunday night, so that's always a good sign!

text:
Got a chance to take my wife to the museum this Sunday and this place never ceases to amaze. I haven't been here in over  15 years and coming back was a treat. It's always amazing to see such a broad scape of art. My wife was particularly impressed with the armory and as the Asian arts area will be closing for renovation we made sure to catch that as well. 

We had lunch in the cafeteria and it was fantastic. The burritos made to order are huge and very fresh. I was surprised to see beer was available! The fresh cookies, muffins and cakes were also really good! 

We just need more time and I think we will be becoming members this year as well!
name: Philadelphia Museum of Art

text:
We had not been to Rangoon for a few years, but it is one place which brings back nice memories.  The staff had been exceptional, and the sticky rice with mango is memorable.  This visit was no different.

We were greeted by one of the owners of the restaurant.  She introduced herself and asked us each our name.  She was attentive the entire meal and ensured that we got just what we wanted.

All of us in our group of five had different meals, but none of us was disappointed.  The kids had a crab appetizer that seemed to go over very well. They also devoured the pumpkin soup.  My husband had the 1000 layer bread, and he was happy with it, despite Erica C.'s review (which I can see from the corner of my eye).  I had a nice eggplant/basil dish, one of my favorite combinations.  

All of us agreed that the portions were small but the price was in line with the quantity.  

All of us agreed that the sticky rice with mango is one of the best desserts in town.
name: Rangoon Burmese Restaurant

text: For one of the better known steakhouses in the city I was expecting better. I had the porcini rubbed Delmonico served in a 15 year aged balsamic sauce. It was good but the balsamic dominated the taste of the steak. When I am at a steakhouse I want to taste the steak, not the additives. I love aged balsamic but not for it to be the main event. There was also quite a bit of fat in my cut. For the price of the steak, I was hoping for a better overall product.

text:
I've come here for dinner and happy hour, though not brunch which is supposedly pretty decent. The food here is fine - it neither disappoints nor exhilarates. I think it's what you might expect from a pub. The menu does however have variety, including sushi rolls. So your party is certain to find something for everyone.

The best part about Manayunk Brewery is the outdoor space in the back. Have a seat or just hang out with a great view along the river. It's perfect in the spring, summer, and fall.

text:
I love good vegetarian food.  It is satisfying, and makes me feel good inside.  Additionally, I get full, but not so full I want to burst.  Lastly, if done right, vegetarian food can carry a wonderful flavor.  As a life long vegetarian, I have had food of all range of quality in my experiences. Hip City Veg is one of the great vegetarian meals available in Philly. I am smitten, and can't wait to work my way through the menu.  

First of all, the place is small. So don't plan on eating here during peak hours, unless you are willing to wait for a table.  The service was quick despite the number of people there.  I tried the udon noodle salad (which was DELICIOUS), and the sweet potato fries (which I loved hands down).  My friends tried one of the burgers and found it delicious as well.  

I can't wait to go back and try more of their menu! I wish their space was larger!!!
name: HipCityVeg

text:
I came here tonight for a work holiday dinner type of thing. A party of 5 arriving just after 5pm had no trouble getting a table. By the time we left around 7:30, it was crazy packed - but I think a lot of that was due to company holiday parties and probably is not normal. 

The hostess was nice enough to seat us way upstairs by the wine vault because there were a lot of large parties making the downstairs very crowded and noisy. All of the staff seemed very helpful and considerate, actually. The hostesses always checked to make sure you were following them, people came to clear away dishes even though you weren't their table... overall a nice friendly feel from everyone.

This particular location is housed in an old bank, so if you go downstairs when you first come in, you can see the huge vault door. Kind of cool for ambience. But at the same time - all of the marbled surfaces and high ceilings make for tons of echos - even at our table away from the parties I found myself shouting instead of talking by 6pm.

I ordered the Blackberry Ginger bourbon cocktail - quiiite delicious. I've had similar drinks elsewhere before though. My table decided to get a bunch of appetizers and "sides" and just go in family style. That worked out because I don't eat steak, but the appetizers and side choices all sounded great. I think my favorites were the cheesesteak dumplings and the lobster macaroni and cheese.

It is very expensive. It's a chain, and first and foremost a steakhouse, but it felt like we *and I mean, my boss* paid mostly for the scenery. The food was pretty good although I felt like the food that I ate was comparable to any other chain restaurant, just at twice the price.

Overall, a nice place if you like having fancy wine choices and I assume a good place to eat steak. I would probably come back to do some drinks/apps again if I was feeling like I had money burning a hole in my pocket. But I would highly recommend going to a local restaurant over this big chain if you want to go all out and spend $30/entree.
name: Del Frisco's Double Eagle Steakhouse

text:
Order the Good Dog burger, cut it in half, and there will be a surprise for you. That surprise is melted cheesy goodness right in the middle of your juicy, thick, and perfectly grilled beef patty. Oh. My. Gooodnesssssss. Then, complement it with BOTH, yes I said BOTH, the sweet potato fries and regular fries that come with the burger.  And then, top it off with a nice sip of one of the craft beers they have for decent prices. 

And the kicker for me? They carry Strongbow AND Original Sin hard cider.

text:
Dim Sum Garden is my go-to place for a hearty comfort meal, especially on a cold or rainy day. You can't make reservations, so I recommend avoiding peak dinner hours or getting there early, especially on Friday or the weekend. The line can get pretty long but usually moves relatively quickly.

The pork soup dumplings are the main and the star of the menu. There is a generous amount of broth, which makes the dumplings just perfect! Best in the city, and some of the best I've ever had! My other favorite side dishes are the spicy beef and tripe, and the scallion pancakes, which are a great complement to the dumplings. I'm usually a huge fan of noodles with peanut sauce, but I found the ones here to be underwhelming and bland, without enough of a peanut/sesame kick.

Don't forget, cash only!

text:
I absolutely loved El Vez! Please note this review is only for their brunch. 

A group of 6, including myself, met up for brunch at El Vez on a Sunday afternoon. I had never been to El Vez before, and was incredibly curious as I read mixed reviews. The decor is simply awesome, and the couches along the back wall are great for group meetups. 

We ordered some guacamole as a starter, which we all thought was delicious. For my main, I ordered the DIY tacos (or something like that - it's been a while). I remember I was very happy with my choice, and my friend, who ordered the same, agreed. The other girls also thought the food was tasty and a pretty good deal for the price. I also had a limeade which was refreshing on this hot summer day. 

The staff was friendly enough, though it wasn't anything special there. El Vez is 4,5 stars for me, so I will definitely come back here.
name: El Vez

text:
I have been to the northern liberties location several times and always enjoyed my meal. They have opened a 2nd spot on south street closer to the bustle of center city. 

Although I think the original is better, Honey's on south is still very good. They have a lot of classics, but really focus on comfort food, think sausage, gravy and biscuits. 

This is one of my favorite breakfast places in the city. I definitely recommend it, but get there early or be prepared to wait.

text:
great place for beer and just to chill.
shared a few entrees paired with yummy beer
-good dog burger-on soft brioche with caramelized onions.  served with a mix of regular and sweet potato fries
-wings-nice and spicy.  not as crispy as i hoped for
-truffled cheesesteak empanadas-lots of truffle flavor; did not like the sauce it comes with
-vegan sloppy joe-served on wheat foccocia; lentils were the "chunks of meat" in the sloppy joe.  

first and second floor were for dining and 3rd floor was for drinks, pools, wait for table type deal.

text: They have a wide variety of cakes but I only tried one so far and it was good. We warmed it up and ate it with vanilla ice cream and it was really good! The lady did not seem to know all of their products in their store. You can be overwhelmed with the number of varieties of cakes, bread, cookies etc that they have. Nevertheless, they are still a must try!! Beside their bakery is also the donut store  if not interested in their baked goods.

text:
I had heard that this place was pretentious, and I did kind of get that vibe there, although I went at brunch-time, not prime, Friday night craziness in Olde City time.  The place was pretty much empty on a Sunday afternoon, even though they were about to turn on the Eagles game (on a projection screen on the wall... thumbs down.. the place isn't set up right for that).  I don't know.. when a place like that says that they'll have the Eagles game on, it kind of seems like a trick.  Like they're trying to draw in people who would never go in there and then -BAM- present them with an over-the-top bill, when all they got was a few beers.  Maybe it's just me that feels this way, but the name and gimmick of National Mechanics seems sort of low-brow, but they present the bar and the staff and the menu as high-brow.  Tricky.

The bottom line is:  I don't care for $6 half-pint bloody mary's, but the bathroom was clean.
name: National Mechanics

text:
Let's make this simple - what shouldn't you get here? CRAZY! What should you get here? EVERYTHING! Amazing food + refreshing mojitos + expedient and friendly service + cool ambiance = make your reservation and go ASAP.

Here's some help if my "everything" recommendation is overwhelming:

Appetizer: empanadas, empanadas, empanadas. All four varieties (traditional beef, chicken/corn, pulled pork, shrimp). The chicken and pork are probably my favorite. Don't overlook the spinach salad and the tomatillo relish - the relish is one of the best accoutrements I've ever had on any dish. It compliments the empanadas so well.

Mains: Vaca Frita, Churrasco a la Cubano. Don't even ask questions. Just do it. Hint for the Vaca Frita - order a side of Maduros (fried sweet plantains), cut some up and throw them in the dish with the black beans.

Drink: mojito anniversario

Dessert: any of the Tres Leches they have at the time. By far my favorite type of dessert when done right, and Cuba Libre does it leaps and bounds beyond right.

And I lied - if there's anything you shouldn't get, it would be the gaucho platter for two. Not worth it. 

Go and let your taste buds enjoy a night of their own brand of salsa dancing; the kind that can only happen in your mouth, courtesy of Cuba Libre.
name: Cuba Libre Restaurant & Rum Bar - Philadelphia

text: One of my favorite places for everything. They have aperol, make a decent negroni, have the best gelato in the U.S., the small plates are excellent, the wine list looks extensive, and the service was good too. It did feel like the closest thing to Italy that I've experienced in CC. I wanted the waiter to be a little more knowledgable of the options (or Italian) but I guess you can't have it all ways.  Very nice meal, will definitely be back soon. I may ask if they can reserve the outdoor table for me every Wednesday...

text:
The more I go to this place, the more I love it. Last night, my husband and I had a hankering for a cheese platter. After studying the menus for Talula's Garden and GTC, GTC won (not that we have anything against Talula's Garden; it's on our list of must-try places). 

Having been here multiple times before, we opted for a cheese platter, the chef's selection of charcuterie meats, potted duck, vichyssoise, and gazpacho.

We made our own cheese platter with the following:
- Fontina val d'acosta with lemon honey
- Piave vecchio with truffle lavender honey (this cheese reminded me of manchego almost...I got the same warm fuzzies in my belly after eating the first piece)
- Kunik with chocolate hazelnut sauce (our waiter also recommended the roasted garlic dulce de leche, which made me want to cry because I wanted both of them)

Since we're one step above cheese n00bz, we asked our waiter for accompaniment suggestions. He gave us a choice of two for each cheese, and all three pairings hit the spot. The fontina with the lemon honey was so good that we bought a 1/2 lb block and a jar of the honey after dinner (can't wait to snack on that later, hehe).

I didn't have too much of the meat plate. My husband concentrated on that while I tore into the potted duck-- foie gras mousse, duck rillette, and elderflower caramel, all smeared on toast. Holy what the, this stuff was incredibly delicious! 

We ended our meal with the vichyssoise, which we both love. I decided to try the gazpacho this time and sadly, I wasn't a fan. It had good flavor but there was something about it that I didn't quite like. Perhaps it was a bit too tart?

Nonetheless, it was one of the best meals we've ever had. Lots of flavor, our waiter was incredibly helpful and attentive, and it's definitely worthy of the 5 stars!

Bonus tip: if you happen to be there on a Sunday, try the oxtail and short rib lasagna plat du jour. Ahhhh-mazing!

text:
My husband and I love sushi a lot - perhaps too much, or at least our bank account might say so. But we had been so good over the last two months that I finally caved and just HAD to eat sushi for dinner last weekend. I had noticed Bleu pop up on Yelp, so after a quick trip to Reading Terminal we headed over to their new little location.

We made it just in time to snag their lunch special (which they offer on the weekends!!), but the regular prices for sushi rolls are so cheap that it only makes sense if you want either soup or salad with your sushi (hehe, they gave us both!). We were the only ones there, so our order was quickly made and then came home and went in the fridge until later. That evening, warm miso soup filled my stomach and my husband munched on edamame. The sushi we ordered was tasty - eel avocado, spicy salmon, spicy tuna, and their special hot girls roll (Spicy tuna, spicy salmon, spicy yellowtail inside w. avocado, caviar on top), and an order of the tuna dumplings (King crab, avocado, wasabi, tobiko, crunch fillings wrapped with thin tuna as skin with spicy citrus soy sauce). The tuna dumplings are tasty, but 1) are hard to eat with chopsticks and in one bite and 2) I thought that there was too much crunch in the filling (not spicy whatsoever, too). The regular rolls have 6 pieces of sushi, but a good amount of fish and not too much rice. The special roll was delicious, and definitely a favorite. Next time, I'm ordering pieces of sushi/sashimi because those prices are ridiculous! $1 for most, only a few cuts are $2+!!
name: Bleu Sushi

text:
It completely depends on the time of day you go. The patrons are 99% of the time cool. However the game selection does not change. 

And there is always the super douchey power tripping bouncer here. Not the old guy, he is nothing but awesome. However, the other bouncers will go out of the way to try to seem smart but take two second to respond. Real meatheads who can't tell heads from tails. Unfortunately they police like it's their job. Either that or they took offense to being told that the racks were too full to handle drinks. 

In addition, the bartenders are horribly overworked. Shouldn't take more than 5 minutes to get an overpriced michigan stout 


If it's busy expect busy lines and a few power hungry bouncers. If it's clear, have fun for an hour. 

This place won't get my business until they get different games and a few more hands on staff.
name: Barcade

text:
On weekends be prepared to wait for about 30 minutes while you stand above other diners.

This is a small NoLibs joint with a small bar, but tons of regulars and patrons who know this littles spot. When I went here with my boyfriend the other day, we shared a chicken breast and avocado sandwich that was decent. Everyone around us ordered the special chili with chips that looked perfect for a winters day. 

The food is good, the atmosphere is kinda cool. Nothing too special. But then again, I didn't partake in libations.

text:
I went to brunch with my girlfriend, Lana, on Sunday. Neither of us had been to the S. Philly Sabrina's, so we headed down there, ready for a wait. This cafe has a surprisingly long wait on Saturday and Sunday, be we arrived around 10:10, and were seated by 10:40. If you arrived between 10:30 and 11:30, however, you're likely to stand around an hour before you're ordering.

Looking at the menu, I was kind of baffled that there was this kind of wait. I go out to brunch often, and I couldn't understand why so many people keep showing up here. Because it was so busy, the service wasn't the best, but it was more than acceptable.

Lana custom made an omelet, and I ordered the barking chihuahua burrito. The coffee kept flowing while we waited for our food, and once it was delivered I knew why this spot was so popular. The food looked great, and between the two of us we had enough to feed a small family. Most of the dishes come with Sabrina's homefries, which are not to be missed. The food, overall, was excellent, and was definitely worth the wait. The menu at Sabrina's allows you to stick with what you know and love, or go all out and get something that is truly a one of a kind creation.

At Sabrina's, you'll leave full, happy, and probably with some left overs for later.
name: Sabrina's Café

text:
We dined here after the Philly Flower Show.  The place was PACKED.  However, the bar was open, so we decided to sit there to eat.  The bartender served us.  He was great!  Efficient and friendly.  He offered us bread (which not all places serve at lunch, and not always with EVOO...it's a feature becoming more popular at restaurants.  Not everyone likes it, but I do)  
We each had an alcoholic beverage, and then had some lunch.  Maggiano's food is very good for Italian chain food.  They use quality ingredients, serve generous portions and it's plated in an attractive, homestyle fashion.  We weren't rushed, and were able to enjoy a cup of cofffee after eating our lunches.  The place was still packed as we left, but we were full and had a great time.
name: Maggiano's Little Italy

text:
The cheesesteaks are really good. I've had most of the beef options, and the quality is pretty consistent. 

I tried to get a beer from "the Bar at Cleavers," and was met with a very rude response from the bartender. Upon finding out I wanted to take it upstairs with our order, she got annoyed and told me, "I'm busy right now" because she wanted to serve the guys staying at the bar who will give her better tips instead of me. It appears the bar is treated as a separate entity from the sandwich part of the restaurant. I am a customer at Cleavers, so I should be able to walk up to the bar, purchase a beer, and bring it upstairs without issue. Next time I'll just get my sandwich and sides (we got fried pickles and onion rings) without getting anything from the bar.

It would be cool if they did oast pork sandwiches, too.
name: Cleavers

text:
I can't tell you how many times I've been here, and it is always great.  It gets a little crowded when the theater crowd ascends, but other than that it's usually the normal bar crowd. 

I agree with the other reviews and highly recommend the wings.  They're huge and just the right amount of heat.  Actually as I'm writing this my mouth is watering at the thought of eating them.  And don't worry about asking for extra napkins for your messy hands- they know, and bring them throughout your wing eating experience.
name: Moriarty's Restaurant and Irish Pub

text: The only reason I'm giving this place 3 stars instead of 4 is because none of the options really blew me away. I came here with a big group for a birthday dinner. The service was great, we got our drinks and food (and we ordered a lot of food) relatively quickly. Plus, bonus, they have the fun graffiti bar attached at the back of this place, so we waited there before being seated. The food was enjoyable all around, but I like to save four and five start ratings for a dish or meal that is really memorable. The food here was tasty, and I would recommend it to someone looking for Asian-fusion/Chinese spot in the city with a twist if you aren't looking for a straight up Chinatown recommendation.
name: Sampan

text:
Um....well its different and I had very, very high hopes for their bagels. That being said I ask you, "Do you prefer a soft doughy bagel or a oven baked "Montreal Bagel"?

I got a bagel sandwich and it did not compare with Manhattan Bagels. I will be back to get a fresh bagel not toasted and give them another shot as there bagels look spectucular...just look at that poppy bagel pic in all its glory. The store has a very nice ambiance but is quite small. They have another location on chestnut that looks much bigger that is within a mile of this store...I guess there is a very large market for bagels in the Rittenhouse area. 

I will update after trying more of there bagels but must mention I gave one to my dad who tried the bagel the next day and he said they taste "different". More of a crispy harder tasting bagel then what we are used to in the states. All a matter of preference I guess but I will be back to give them another try.
name: Spread Bagelry

text:
I've been to Han Dynasty a bunch of times and while some of their food is a hit or miss, you'll still be happy with it. Their food is family style so they give large servings that are meant to be shared. 

I always order the fish dry pot with level 10 spicyness and it is delicious!! They bring the dish out in a pot with a candle underneath so your food will remain warm. The only downside to this is that the serving size is pretty small. 

The fish is cooked perfectly and it's so soft it basically melts in your mouth. They used to include a larger variation of vegetables with the fish but now it's mostly bamboo and mushroom that's edible. If you want to get the whole experience, I highly recommend getting the level 10 spicyness because you may tear up but the flavors are worth it. 

I have also tried the garlic sauce style tofu and chicken. It is just as good as it looks and they give a huge plate. It's basically bamboo, tofu/chicken, and mushrooms cooked in a thick reddish sauce. 

The chicken fried rice is better than most places and once again, it's a huge serving. It does have plenty of veggies and chicken. 

I would not recommend getting the cold sesame noodles though. They lack flavor and taste like American Chinese food rather than authentic Chinese food.
name: Han Dynasty

text:
I came here with very high expectations because everyone who went here had really good things to say about the restaurant so I was super excited and hyped it up to a few other friends who hadn't tried it. I must say the brunch was delicious but it didn't stand out to me. I felt like the originality was just not there. I ordered the spinach frittatta which was very good but a little too cheesy ( if you're a cheese lover you'd like this place for sure). The homefries were good but were enhanced by their awesome home made ketchup. The best part of the meal for me was the home made biscuit which blew my mind away. 

That is the main reason for giving this place 3 stars. The meal was great but the best part about it was the biscuit. I will be back, but I won't have the same high expectations.
name: Sam's Morning Glory Diner

text:
PHO PHO PHO PHO PHO... at this restaurant it's PHOking awesome!!! 

It's your typical Asian mom and pop shop, located in "little Saigon" of Philly. 

Pros: 
-Cheap! $7 
-Fast and friendly service
-All the condiments you want or need to dress up your Pho
-spring rolls here were fresh and oh so tasty
-the broth and the actual Pho was so good, I could have shed tears of happiness
-free tea 

Cons: 
-cash only
-other than that, there are NO other cons!
name: Pho Ha

text:
Visited Devon Seafood for Restaurant Week 2016 for lunch. This place is really nice. It has the classic steakhouse ambiance. We were seated in a wide booth. I decided to go with the lunch menu for restaurant week (with a side of lobster man n cheese) while my partner ordered the crab cakes for his entree. The lobster bisque was great. I also enjoyed the blackened Mahi Mahi. My partner enjoyed his crab cakes, but neither of us were impressed with the lobster mac n cheese. We also ordered the chocolate cake to go, but i can't comment on it since it's still in my fridge. 

Overall, I would return to Devon for dinner and to sit outside and catch the scenery.
name: Devon Seafood Grill

text:
Craft cocktails, huge whiskey/bourbon list and some really interesting food choices.

Thoroughly enjoyed the grilled corn, grilled asparagus, shishito peppers, and the fried chicken.

Tried several of the cocktails, Summer Solstice was the perfect blend of sweet and heat and a must try drink.

text: I was able to try Nomad Pizza while at Night Market on South Street recently.  We went early enough and the line was fairly short.  They sport a food truck with a built-in wood burning brick oven.  The ingredients were fresh and mouth water even before it took a trip to the oven.  We went with a half marg / half pepperoni.  Both were of equal parts amazing.  Having been to Southern/Central/Northern Italy, I've been able to sample a lot of pizza stylings.  Their Neapolitan style crust and flavors were reminiscent of some of the great pizzas I've had while in Naples.  It is by far the best pizza of that style I've had in Philly...ever.  I know they have a storefront on South and I'm eager to make that my go-to pizza stop while in the area.
name: Nomad Pizza Company

text: This is a pretty fun market, especially if it is your first or second time coming. There are a lot of different vendors all under one roof, with lots of gourmet options. Some of the produce is the same and a little more expensive than some Chinese supermarkets just down the street in Chinatown. However, the convenience of one stop shopping under the guise of being "down town at the markets" is very fun. Be sure to bring plenty of money and an empty stomach to snack as you shop!
name: Reading Terminal Market

text: Finally made it to Lucha Cartel for brunch and it did not disappoint. For $25 you get a bottle of champagne and 3 mixers to share with the table. I ordered the chilaquiles con huevos with chicken which were basically nachos topped with 2 over easy eggs and served with rice and beans. My friends raved about their choices- the huevos rancheros and bistec con huevos. I highly recommend making Lucha your next brunch spot!

text: Awesome noodles and great prices. The ambiance is not so great, and if you go at a peak time, they'll seat different parties at the same table to seat more people, so if that bothers you, you might want to go at an off time. The shaved noodles have a bit more beefy taste to them and are chewy while the hand drawn noodles taste like super amazing ramen. I usually get the beef with shaved noodle soup or the pork with hand drawn noodles dry (it looks kinda like ground beef with noodles and soy sauce) which are both delicious. Also, the marinated eggs are really good as well.
name: Nan Zhou Hand Drawn Noodle House

text:
Ok...I said I would edit my review after returning, and here I am eating my humble pie. 

It must have been an isolated incident with our previous waitress, or she was let go- but the waitress we had this time was awesome. She was accommodating and gave us recommendations. Even allowed us to order happy hour a little early (7 min before 5:00, but still we were grateful). 

The food was great, and artfully presented to us. I will be back for sure and I'm happy I gave it a second try.

text:
THREE CUP CHICKEN! Let me say it one more time for the people in the back... THE THREE CUP CHICKEN!!!! This dish was a highlight from my recent takeout order and I can't wait to order it again. The perfect amount of sweet and savory flavors, tenderness, and garlic.

I was in the mood for soup so I ordered a beef noodle soup from Han Dynasty for pickup. While looking through the other menu options online, I noticed the Three Cup Chicken in the specials section. I decided to try it. Based on the way the menu describes the items, I could not tell if this was going to come with rice or not. I assumed (and hoped) it would, and it did. You just never know with takeout these days!

I scheduled it for a later pickup time, ran my errands, and stopped by a few minutes earlier than expected for my food. While it wasn't ready when I got there (100% my fault) they did get it wrapped up quickly and I did not have to wait long. By the time I got home everything was still hot and VERY delicious.
name: Han Dynasty

text:
Finally a delicious veggie outpost in Center City to feed the waiting, throbbing masses that seem to have enveloped the little former Pad Thai enclave.  This place has been packed since its doors opened, and for good reason.  Seems like this area of town has been aching, begging for a place like Hip City Veg.  With its cute, modern interiors and with a menu that's sure to sate with all the comforting salad and sandwich options, all "plant-based" (aka vegan, why is that such a bad word anyhow?), what's not to love?  Yay. 

Options have been hit or miss, which I'm hoping (praying, is more like it) is due to the fact that the place is simply overwhelmed by the demand and the pace, and they simply have not been able to keep up or properly anticipate the challenges of getting the food made well, quickly and out the door.  I loved their Buffalo Bella, but found the Fajita wrap dry and bland, their salads lacking enough ingredients considering their conservative sizes - but on the whole, what they offer is good (which is why I'm torn here, three or four stars? argh! only time will tell!), I just think they need to get their place in order.  Speaking of order, the must order here, I must say is their Groothie (apple, leafy greens, banana)-- so yummy, I would down a gallon of the stuff if I could.  

So, yeah, if you're planning on taking a quick work lunch, this place will have you waiting, so avoid the lunch rush (at this place, it's pretty much 11:30 until 2, I would say) if you want to try it out,  wait with the hungry lots and order with abandon.  

As for myself, I will be waiting a couple weeks until the crowds die down and until the Hip City Veg team gets into their groove.  Unless I get a groothie craving.  Like, now.  Damn.
name: HipCityVeg

text:
On what seemed like the one millionth snow day of this oh so lovely winter season, I trudged, climbed, swam and skated over to Bistro Romano to meet some friends for happy hour after seeing their "cheap drinks and free food" #OpeninPHL post.  Now normally I would consider a restaurant within a half mile of my apartment close.  But not on this day. By the time I got there I was soaked in snow, sweat and icicles. In short, I had earned as many $5 wines/cocktails/martinis or $2.50 drafts that my heart desired.

Now when I hear "free food" and "happy hour" in the same breath, I generally think of some sort of bacteria-laden peanut, crunchy bar snack situation.  But not at Bistro Romano.  It was like a never ending Italian appetizer fest (okay so it ended after 5 of them, but who's counting when you're drinking $5 wines) brought out on individual plates, so that I didn't have to worry about my ravenous husband getting to all the good stuff before I did.  Calamari! Bruschetta! Mussels! And more!  And the best news is is that I was told this wasn't just a snow day thing and that I could literally do this EVERY happy hour and spare myself the agony of walking through the city in snowpocalypse!  Hooray!

Bistro Romano, I think you are now my second favorite happy hour in the city (Sampan/Graffiti Bar, you will always be my number one watering hole after work.  Do not be threatened.).
name: Bistro Romano

text: I am over Monk's and will not return. Over the years, I have visited this place hoping that service and food would improve.  If anything, Monk's has gotten progressively worse over the years.  Upon arrival, you are greeted by the hostess, that appears confused, and as always, offers a seat at the bar to eat your meal, as opposed to the MANY open tables around.  The wait staff is inexperienced, and could care less about service.  I cannot tell you how many of them ran by while my water glass remained empty.  Not one offered to refill it, nor did any of them ask if everything was okay after the food was delivered.  The fries are NOT what they used to be.  Small, soggy, heavily salted and inconsistent. In this day and age, there are too many restaurants in this city that appreciate the business, and make you feel welcomed.  This place makes you feel as if they are doing you a favor simply by seating you at one of their tables (that need to be scrubbed down, and thoroughly cleaned).  My friend and I left disgusted.  I hope this place either cleans up their act, or closes it's doors.  There are too many other places to go to these days.. Monk's is not the one.  Don't waste your money or your time.
name: Monk's Cafe

text:
Really this place does not need additional positive publicity but I can't help it. This is the cheapest and best quick meal to get in Philly period! Unlike other falafel joints you are not eating lettuce and tomatoes when you get to the end of the sandwich, there are these fresh crunchy balls of falafel throughout the sandwich which makes every bite as enjoyable as the last. Its like a really good novel that starts out amazing and never ceases to have a boring moment and when you're done you kind of want to read it all over again. 

Seriously the hummus is really fresh, the hot sauce is perfectly spiced and did I mention its only 6 bucks, unheard of when considering you can't get a really good meal for under 10! I wish this place was open late night!
name: Mama's Vegetarian

text:
I heard so much good things about Han Dynasty and couldn't wait to try. 
Got bunch of dishes include spicy cucumber salad, dan Dan noodle, dumpling in hot oil, scallion pancakes, fried rice, fish in clay pot, dry chicken, garlic eggplants and mapo tofu. 

Dumpling in hot oil was big hit, it was simple but had so much flavor in it. Scallion pancake was fried well and chewy, dipping sauce wasn't salty. Everyone seems excited about their dan Dan noodle but it didn't so much for me. Maybe I am not a big fan of noodle. 
I did enjoy mapo tofu, wasn't too greasy and enough spicy for me. Dry chicken was delicious but was too salty for me. I had few bite then couldn't touch more. 
Fish in clay pot had full of flavor but a bit greasy for me. Since most main dishes we ordered had powerful flavor, the fried rice was most popular dish on our table. 

Dinner was enjoyable and liked the fun ambiance. Like old Chinese restaurant in movie. I will definitely go back soon but I will order more appetitive and be easy on strong flavored main dishes next time.
name: Han Dynasty

text:
My beloved Penang
This is the place where you want to to hang
The ambience is cool and hip
This isn't like other Chinatown restaurants - get a grip!
Grab yourself some roti canai 
I swear it'll make you cry
Tears of joy 
That plate, you'll definitely destroy
It's that good - with its crispy roti 
And a curry that will bring you down to your knee
If you're looking for comfort, try the Hainanese chicken 
It'll bring you to a place of zen
Don't forget to use to red sauce 
Or else the chicken will be a loss 
If you're worried about the spice, the waiters will refill your water in a flash
So fast, you'll probably get whiplash
Penang, you are so great
I'm glad I've met you
It was fate

text:
Bud & Marilyn's brings out the best in the nostalgia of your Grandma's cooking. 

PSA: They take OpenTable reservations but only for parties under 6. It's actually pretty tough to get a res for 6 (they limited me to certain times) so you might need to cut some friends out of your life (or maybe just out of your dinner plans).

Service was awesome.  Our waiter (Benjamin) had great recommendations for everything from drink pairings to how many dishes to order and what not to skip and was not shy about telling us when he thought we made a bad choice.  

Drinks- didn't love the blinker (too sweet) and as my friend said they need to step up their ice game with big cubes if they're going to offer fancy cocktails like that. 

4 ladies with healthy appetites shared:
The Fried Cheese Curds.($8) Get them.  They're delicious and great to share and the dipping sauces don't hurt either. 

The Nashville buns: ($10) 2 per order.  Bite sized. Reminded me of Nashville in an awesome way (lil bit of a kick). Would come back just for these at happy hour ($3.50 instead of $5 each- pro tip: they also have a late night happy hour). Get them. 

The PuPu Platter. ($26) I'm a sucker for an appetizer sampler and this one had a lot of things: tuna poke, beef skewers, pork toast, shishito peppers, ribs, and wings. Large portions (more than 1 each), and everything was good, but nothing was mindblowing, and the wings were pretty ordinary.  I'd probably skip this. 

Short Rib Stroganoff. ($18) Maybe my favorite dish of the night. English peas, fresh pasta, tender meat. Get this. 

Sea scallops ($22) 3 large scallops layered with corn cakes and veggies.  Good but not great. Skip.

Local greens. We ordered a lot of unhealthy foods.  These were good to balance that out. Pleasant surprise and made us feel healthy. 

Funfetti cake. Massive and the fluffiest cake you will ever eat. Oddly topped with a fortuneless fortune cookie and surrounded by some strawberry thing that tasted like the inside of a pop tart. 

Apple donuts with chai cream cheese.  So good.  Must get these.

We were very full by the end and packed up half the desserts.  Prices were reasonable for how much food we got (with about 1 drink each it was $50).

I don't know about you guys but my Grandma did not cook like this. Recommend for a dinner date,  drinks and apps with friends, catch up dinner with mom, etc. Great atmosphere, food,  and service.
name: Bud & Marilyn's

text:
I'm down with the Barcade. It's a really decent spot with 25c games, a great taplist (though it could stand to be updated more frequently/offer descriptions/pour size sometimes), and solid food offerings if you happen to stop by for a meal. Like the other establishments popping up within a stone's throw of Frankford and Girard, its location has automatically garnered a lot of teeny-boppish attention and thus rendered it deafening and sweltering at peak times. (Recently overheard at a tap takeover event: "OMG, there are, like, no IPAs? What the hell. I only drink IPAs. How am I supposed to know what these other frickin beers when they don't say IPA next to them, man? I'm not going to drink it unless I know it's specifically an IPA.") 

...But Barcade can't be faulted for that. This place would survive even in a less hip area, because we don't have anything else like it. It's not my go-to destination for regular drinking, but it's a novelty spot to play a few games and then tip over into into a trolley track on the bike ride home. The outdoor area is also really pleasant for warm weather boozing. Basically: 3 stars +1 for the fact that we don't really have anywhere else to play pac-man 'round these parts.
name: Barcade

text: After roaming around Chinatown wondering what restaurant I was "feeling" at the moment, I finally turned to yelp and settled on Rangoon. The restaurant was pretty empty that night. For food, I ordered basic dishes that people were raving. Honestly, I was not very impressed with the Thousand Layer Bread. I like the NJ's Penang roti canai much much more. This was particularly greasy. The spicy curry chicken was okay. It had a nice blend of spices to it, but it definitely was not spicy. I didn't like it much just because the portion was small. My boyfriend ordered the calamari ala burma which is a nice south asian-style salad. That was my favorite dish. I really like the flavoring and zest. The calamari was cooked well. If I go back, I'll try more of their salads for sure.
name: Rangoon Burmese Restaurant

text:
"I want to take this serrano home and have sex with it." 

Restaurant Week meal (each person chooses two first courses and two second courses each) went like this: 

1st courses:
Me: Jamon Serrano - see opening quote.
BF: Chorizo Pamplona - delicious.
Me: Chicken Brochette - very nicely seasoned.
BF: Arugula: decent portion, the fried goat cheese was awesome.

2nd courses:
Me: Pulpo - paired very nicely with the lemon powder, cooked perfectly.
BF: Merluza en Salsa Verde (sea bass with cockles) - this was my fave.
Me: Asparagus - cooked wonderfully but not second course-worthy.
BF: Duck Montadito - amazing, no wonder it's a signature dish.

We tried both of the RW desserts offered (Chocolate and Torrijas). Both were quite good. I'm not usually a fan of chocolate cake but I'd gladly make an exception for Tinto's flourless version. 

Our server, Jason, was wonderful - friendly, knowledgeable, and attentive.
name: Tinto

text:
We came here for happy hour and it was a nice experience. The bar was slammed, but the waiter allowed us to sit at a table (if we were getting food), so that worked out. 

We started out with a margarita and a beer. Margarita was a tad on the sweet side, the beer was... well it was beer. 

For food we got the vegetarian empanadas which were nice and filling. The happy hour version had 4 pieces, and was mushroom filled. It was presented very nicely. 

We also got the chips and guacamole which was good! 

We would come back for sure as the ambiance, the service, and the food was worth it.

text:
I LOVED my dining experience here. I chose this restaurant for my birthday dinner with a group of friends. The atmosphere is great and it was fun that there just so happened to be a few other parties celebrating a birthday too. We arrived a few minutes late, but they were great about holding our table for our reservation. After ordering, they gave us two free salads for the table as a "gift" for my birthday (how sweet!). 

I got the special of the day, which was a squid ink fettuccine with calamari, mussels, clams, and shrimp. OH MY was it just delicious. I had the opportunity to try the gnocchi special that night and it was like little pillows of potato heaven in my mouth. Honestly, everything we had that night was truly amazing! I would recommend for a date night, girls' night, or a group dinner! Definitely a great option for any kind of gathering.
name: Giorgio On Pine

text:
There's not much else I can write in this review that hasn't been already said in the thousands of other reviews on this page, but I will provide some personal insight.

Years ago, there existed a very small little shop also named Dim Sum Garden in what is now known as Tom's Dim Sum, in the previously-decrepit Chinatown tunnel. I was a child when I went there, and was delighted by all the small eats they had - it brought me back to Shanghai and its delicious dim sum.

Imagine by dismay when I came back years later and it was closed, and my elation when I realized a new spot with the same name opened up next to what was once the Chinatown Bazaar and it's oddities, now Chinatown Square. Going there, I was brought back to the same delectable dim sum dishes that I once knew, and I lived joyously knowing I had a source of good dim sum in Philadelphia.

Over the years, I've continued going here, enjoying their Xiao Long Bao, Pan Fried Soup Dumplings, and Shao Mai, among other things. The quality has waned a bit and become more expensive - after all, it has become a must-see tourist spot, but I will not say I wouldn't continue to enjoy dim sum here from time to time.

There's a reason Dim Sum Garden is as revered as it is in Philadelphia's Chinatown, and why the line extends until out the door at peak hours, and if you're looking for a place to enjoy the authentic Shanghainese taste of dim sum, this is the place to be.
name: Dim Sum Garden

text: I have been to Spice 28 a couple times for Happy Hour. Their Ginger Cosmopolitan is nice and full of ginger and I also got the Angry Orchard Ginger Cider. I like that their Happy Hour lasts until 7pm because sometimes people can't meet exactly at 5. The drinks are strong and flavorful. Also, the HappyTizers are very delicious. I have tried the Peking Duck Crepe and the Wontons. My only down side to this place is that maybe I eat a lot but the happytizers are not super filling (for me), so i would have to order 4 plates to be full or I would just stay for dinner next time. Lastly, I will be returning to try the lunch or dinner.

text: Food was excellent and service was friendly.  Dessert, which I don't always do but we we're there for a couple birthdays,  was not so good.  My main issue was that the coffee was not ready when the desserts were brought out.  It probably took another ten minutes or so until the coffee finally arrived,  never a good thing.  Note to restaurant people,  Never serve desserts before the coffee,  coffee always first.    Also the music was a bit loud for my liking,  it's a restaurant,  not a nightclub.  Other then that the great  food and friendly service are enough to make me want to return.
name: Buddakan

text:
Fantastic spot for brunch. It was a 50 min wait on a recent Saturday, but they text you so you can leave and come back. 

My boyfriend and I sat outside in the converted shipping container, very clever! We ordered:

+ Caramel spiced apple cider - could have been hotter but it was delicious, loved the caramel foam stuff on top 
+ Pumpkin Cannoli French Toast - wow, so good
+ Breakfast burrito - awesome 

Definitely recommend!

text:
Good 10$ lunch deal but past the good price... very inconsistent and not a great bang for the buck.

I've come on several occasions to try and see if I like El Rey or not. 
Some of the things I find is the portions seem to be all over the chart.  Sometimes they are huge... sometimes I'm wondering if it's a free sample of what I actually ordered. 

The interior (although this is the theme and the look they are going for) is just plain dingy and tacky.  I know I know write me all you want and tell me that that's the look. I get it... but I don't want it.

The service (for having a 10$ lunch special) is slow.  When offering a 10$ lunch special (and also given your location) El Rey is catering to the working lunch.  Service is friendly and slow. 

The food itself is good. 

Chayote Salad (corn, pickled onion, avocado, lime vinaigrette) is small
Sopa de Tortilla (tomato broth, chicharron, crisp tortilla) very tasty and filling.

Short rib enchiladas are very flavorful.  
Tacos are small portioned and a let down.

All in all, I don't believe this is a homerun. Check it out if you want...
name: El Rey

text:
Fogo de Chao is a lot more than a restaurant, it's an experience.

For those of you who are unfamiliar with Brazilian steakhouses, you pay a flat fee ($51.50 for dinner, $34.50 for lunch) and you get unlimited trips to a salad bar, unlimited starchy sides (polenta, potatoes, and fried bananas), AND the main reason people come.... unlimited steak (and lamb and sausage and pork and chicken).

Because I work in a male-dominated industry, I have visited Fogo about a half a dozen times for various work functions.  So I have some tips:

-  if you aren't that into steak and are paying for the meal yourself, consider doing just the salad bar.  It is amazing- with tons of options like smoked salmon, various cheeses and salumi, potatoes, big pieces of asparagus, prepared salads like tuna/chicken salad.  And at $24.50, it's a bargain.

- Wait out the better pieces of meat.  They will bring you a lot of meats that are lower quality to start (because they want to fill you up).  If there is a particular cut you like, wait for it to come to you.  Or better yet, let the waiter know and they will send them over to you.

- if you want to experience the fogo-ness but are on a budget, try the lunch option. For $34.50 you get the same meal, but just between the hours of 11:30 and 2:30, Monday through Friday

So why 4 stars rather than 5?  I feel like the meat isn't the greatest quality and a bit too salty.  In the end, I'd rather just get a good steak elsewhere and pay a few more bucks.  But its a fun place and you get a damn good meal, so check it out.
name: Fogo de Chao

text:
Perfect beef pho, at a perfect price, and in a perfect restaurant space. 

Pho 75's beef pho is extremely flavorful, with a refreshingly clean and pure taste to it. It's also less than $10. I even added the extremely delicious (and potent) Vietnamese coffee with condensed milk, and my bill was only $11. 

Moreover, I love how un-fancy this place is. It shows authenticity and a down-to-earth commitment to the product. 

I love Pho 75 and will be back very soon, and often!
name: Pho 75

text:
As with most Starr establishments, Parc is style over substance.  Many of the "French Bistro" touches are spot on - like the $10 French Onion Soup - which is EXCELLENT, down to the fixtures in the W.C.

Service was odd.  Great at first when we arrived at 6:15 and once we hit 8 PM it was spotty - we were sometimes ignored (like when the soup arrived with no spoons) and then at times hovered over.

In our party of 3 only one of us ordered a "true" entree - Branzino - which was delicious.

My friend and I decided to share the duck liver mousse (delicious and light - but small amount of mousse and HUGE amount of grain mustard - I mean, who needs THAT much mustard.)  It was also served sans cornichons - a sacrilege - but 3 small french pickles were brought right away (thankfully for no charge) upon request.

The seafood cocktails - shrimp, crab (2 legs for $18 - ouch) and lobster all were effortless to eat.  ($16 for 4 shrimp - eeek!)  My friend and I were still hungry so she got the French onion soup (and I helped!) which quickly killed our appetites.  (Heavy - but sweet and not to salty and delicious.)

Profiteroles for dessert were very good but not orgasmic.  (And I had been eye-ing them all evening.)

So would I return?  Hell, yes!  But will I run right back?  Heck, no!
name: Parc

text:
The Starrborgs* in this restaurant are dressed in identical stripey shirts.  They look a little bit like gay sailors.  The food is pretty good-- I really liked the Tuna Tartare and the Pad Thai, but it's really nothing that special.  As usual in Starr restaurants, the visual aspect of the dining experience has more gravitasse than the menu which is chic fusion cuisine that really has nothing to do with the diner theme.  TK and I sat in these swingy chair things which were very weird--novelty value sans practicality.

I was disappointed in their paltry beer selection.  I understand that they're going for the whole martini thing but I was really in the mood for a beer.

* See my review on Buddakan.
name: The Continental Mid-town

text:
It's changed, and not for the better.

I haven't been to Marathon for almost 2 years. I went with a couple friends recently and was disappointed with the changes. The food isn't nearly as good as it used to be. My dish (meatloaf) was less flavorful than in the past and left you with a greasy taste. My friend's dish arrived with a long hair mixed in with the toppings. They quickly got her a fresh plate/dish and made it complementary, but overall the food just wasn't what it used to be. The service was great, however, so that made the trip worthwhile. I don't think I'll return to this Marathon.
name: Marathon

text:
I love this place.  It is super delicious and i love watching Solomonov team doing all sorts of cool new stuff. 
I went once during restaurant week which was a totally different show than other times ik've gone.  I felt like the regular restaurant staff got a break and the B team had their time in the light.  It was chaotic, loud, crazy music, some things went a miss, but over all still a ton of food and all very delicious. 
Was very sad when i was turned away once when i tried to pick up some hummus to go for my sister, who had just come back from Tel Aviv and craving some good stuff, and we weren't heading into center city, so we couldn't get any at Dizzengoff or Goldie snacks but ah well. bummer.
Haven't been able to have my spontaneous eats here once they blew up on James Beard, but whattaya gonna do.  Also now it's pandemic time so whole other issue with eating out these days.
name: Zahav

text:
White Dog Cafe is a really cool place with a super interesting ambience so I'll definitely be back. We went for dinner one night and we walked in to a cozy and crowded place that is really broken into many different small rooms rather than one big dining area. 

The best part is that every inch is covered in somewhat upscale dog decor (is that a thing?!) The room we sat in was beautiful and had portraits of old military/royalty style portraits but with lil doggy heads!!

I think the biggest let down was that the service was somewhat sub par and the food was just ok!! Which is fine but stinks when most entrees are about $30. I had the Locust Point Chicken and my boyfriend had the Petite Filets.

Overall, I really do want to come back for brunch or their Happy Hour because I've heard great things and the place itself is awesome!

text: Amis is the stripped down, more casual incarnation of Osteria.   If you are looking for a 5 star experience, go to Osteria or Vetri.  If 4 stars will do, Amis is a solid choice.  The service is 3 stars.   The food is very solid.  If I could, I would have given. 3.5 stars.  Very good, but not great.

text: Welp I've found my new favorite breakfast joint. HOLY MOLY was this place good. We went around 12:40 on a Saturday and had to wait about 20 minutes for a table. The 3 of us each ordered frittatas, one plum tomato w/ pesto, one mushroom, and one brie and andouille sausage. The mushroom was the best of them all, followed by the brie/sausage, and lastly the plum tomato. But they were all good! The potatoes and toast were delicious, too. Oh, and the coffee was amazing. I don't know how they made that La Colombe taste even better than usual, but they must've sprinkled some type of magic in it. Only complaints? $2 upcharge for egg whites (but the waitress actually told me when I ordered, so many thanks to her) and the long hots in my frittata were bitter for some reason. I will definitely be back...maybe even tomorrow!
name: Cafe Lift

text:
D&B is a lot of fun, I have been there for food before but not on my most recent visit.  The food is on par with Applebees or other similar places (which is to say it is fine, but nothing that I would ever seek out).  They used to have a deal where you could upgrade your meal with tickets to play games.  I am not sure if this is still available but we all thought it was worth it. 

If you are going with a few people and plan on playing the games together, I'd recommend chipping in together and putting your game money on one card.  It is really annoying when everyone has cards with a little bit of money on them but not enough to play any of the games.

I enjoyed the trivia game, eight people can play at once.  My other favorite game is the six person racing game, which was not working the night I was there.  

$11 to park, with voucher for $5 discount on your drinks.
name: Dave & Buster's

text:
Tattooed Mom is the collage of paint, magazine pages, graphics, and eccentric furniture you could only vaguely envision for your too-cool-to-care college haunt. 

It's okay; you weren't worthy. 

That is the energy you'll get from an occasional early-2000s hipster here who hasn't realized their superiority complex has gone out of style. Largely, though, the vibe at Tattooed Mom is relaxed and accepting--a comfortable den of dim lighting and wild wall distractions. 

Nearly everyone you encounter will be pleasant: from the bartenders to the stranger at the bar whose decision to talk to you is surprisingly unoffensive, to the casual angel who hears you asking an oblivious friend to pour you some water and hands you a cup of salvation, to your own friends who are also enjoying the ease of this place with its ornate fixtures, silly tchotchkes, danceable music, and space to roam. There's even a decent cocktail list to boot.
name: Tattooed Mom

text:
Ha.  La Columbe now has a menu.....no longer one to confuse the newbies like I once was last year (though, no pricings).

I tried the regular coffee recently 'cuz I was feeling cheap, and can admit, I am a fan.  Smooth with low acidity and bitterness.  (And to be honest, I'm not much of a coffee drinker)
Still the same popular, busy coffee shop as I remember.  Not the type you want to hang out in, unless you love it loud and crowded.

But hey, at least there's reason to back it up.

text: A must for happy hour for all vegetarians and non vegetarians in the area! Almost everything is under $5, so it's perfect to go with a group and split as many things as as possible. My favorite was definitely the crab cake sliders, they were perfect. I think the potato croquettes were just OK, a bit too mushy on the inside for me. The ricotta dip is super rich and creamy. The atmosphere is nice and dark, and feels like an upscale British pub. Would definitely come back and try the rest of the menu!

text:
Went here with a few other yelpers for sunday brunch and there was no wait plus amazing food! Its honestly so hard to find a decent brunch place that doesnt have a wait so close to center city but this one lives up to all the other ratings.
I got the parisian Za and it was to die for. The potato cutlet was amazing, the touch of avocado was butterly, perfect portions of the salad and the croissant.

text:
Enjoyed yet another fantastic meal at Audrey Claire last night! Around 8pm I called and the friendly hostess was able to squeeze my mom and I in for dinner. Although it can sometimes be a bit loud in the restaurant, once you settle in with your table and engage in conversation, the noise quickly subsides. 

Everything we ordered was fantastic. We started the meal off with a braised short rib flatbread that had melted fontina, truffle oil and portobellos- full of flavor! I love flatbreads because they aren't so doughty - this was almost like matzo.  Then we tried the roasted brussel sprouts which were tasty, but had a lot of shaved cheese which we felt was unnecessary. The sprouts themselves were good enough without the added dairy. Next came the grilled octopus atop a romaine salad with tomatoes -- this was FANTASTIC! I love grilled octopus and have said before in other reviews that it's not the easiest to cook perfectly where it's moist vs. chewy. Well let me tell ya - the chefs nailed it! I have to come back soon just for that! Woweee. Finally, we ordered the chicken Milanese with arugula and tomatoes. This finished the meal perfectly. The chicken had a thin layer of breading that was friend to perfection and covered in a fresh arugula salad with tomatoes and lemon. Since the 2 of us were unable to finish every dish last night, I look forward to reliving the delicious meal again tonight!
name: Audrey Claire
