text:
Haven't been here in years. Didn't care for it. Wouldn't return. Wouldn't recommend. 

We had a large group of people. For some reason they put us in a room where we had to be separated into all different groups with the birthday girl winding up at a two top across from other tables. It kind of defeated the purpose of dining out as a group. We were all sitting on top of each other and completely jammed in like sardines. It wasn't comfortable. They decided to treat us all as separate tables since that's how we were seated...but for some reason they still struggled with taking our order and delivering the food and drinks efficiently. There were disputes amongst the two servers taking care of us which wasn't very professional. If we are separated into two tops and four tops, etc. then it's the same as just having a full station so why such a struggle?! 

I didn't love anything on the menu and my stomach was bothering me so I tried to go as plain as possible. Their only salmon option was farmed. Why would you serve farmed fish at a restaurant? Nice restaurants don't serve farmed fish and they definitely don't charge $35 for it!!! I wouldn't eat anything else on the menu so I asked her if I could do it as a plain grilled fish versus the preparation stated on the menu. She said yes. I asked if I could do rice. She told me there was no rice and that I could do plain potatoes. I said ok. We continued to wait another 45 minutes before placing our order so I had time to look at the menu more. I noticed jasmine rice listed under another menu item. When our server returned, I asked her if I could have that rice. She said yes. Soooo, you didn't realize you had that rice? You were trying to get away with not offering it? I don't know. Weird. The farmed salmon was disgusting and I didn't eat it. I got charged the same price as the fancy preparation of the salmon so I paid about $35 for a disgusting piece of farmed salmon that I didn't eat and plain rice. I was grateful for the rice. 

I asked for a Kir Royale. She said ok. I asked if she knew what it was. She said yes. I said I wanted it with chambord (because sometimes people serve it to me with cassis) she said ok. She returned and asked me if I wanted it on the rocks or straight up. I now had confirmation that she doesn't know what a Kir royale is despite saying she did. I restate the fact that it is champagne and chambord and that it is served in a champagne glass. She said ok. What felt like a half hour later, she returned with a martini glass and something that was a very wrong color. I tasted it. I had no idea what it was but it wasn't a Kir Royale. It was going to be too much trouble to try to fix the situation so I just drank it. 

The decor seems very dated and it looks like they could use a good cleaning...or a total remodel. The bathrooms in the back are tiny and you always have to wait and while you are waiting you are able to observe some very unhygienic practices going on at their server station which I'm glad I didn't see until the end of the experience. 

The service was so slow that despite having plenty of time between our reservation and the show we were going to afterwards, we were late for the show which was then sold out and some of us didn't get in. 

Parking was easy. The place is large so there's lots of seating available. There are lots of different rooms that are all decorated differently. There are multiple floors. 

Overall, the service, food, drinks, decor and atmosphere were all disappointing (at best). I wouldn't return or recommend going here unless they do a big overhaul. Pass!!!!
name: White Dog Cafe

text: Barcelona wine bar is a very elegant yet smooth place to be. Barcelona was one of the first places to actually provide outside dining during the Covid pandemic. I must say that the service is impeccable the food is amazing and I would definitely revisit once the pandemic is over. The wine is great and the seafood is very fresh. Our waiter was very nice and very helpful. He was very informative about the menu and how to walk us through the new way of ordering through the barcode.

text:
With their four year anniversary right around the corner, Bistrot La Minette, definitely has something to celebrate:  that besides Bibou, this is the only destination in Philadelphia for an authentic cuisine française experience, with a menu that is supremely delicieux.

J'adore the interior, always have, along with the songbook to boot (I mean, I might be in the minority here, considering my heritage, but I can't get enough of Joe Dassin, Jacques Brel, and yes, the Amelie soundtrack - it never gets old). 

From the elegant restrooms, traditional decor, marble-topped bar and the high vaulted ceilings, even the gorgeous Laguiole knives, it's the attention to detail that puts me over the moon.  Service is always pleasant, accurate, present and knowledgeable (even though their pronunciation isn't on point, and their insistence of saying pree fee for 'prix fixe' when it's actually pree feexe - but bah! small potatoes).  Along with Talula's Garden, this place is perfect for a nice dinner out with the folks or for a date destination set for romance.

Summer brings about a menu that is all-Provençal and that embraces those vegetables of summer, tomatoes, eggplant and zucchini:  an end result that was wonderfully executed in a delicious ratatouille.  A zippy tapenade amuse bouche starts off any meal right -- and of course,  I  still love their amazing crunchy, buttery baguette bread (can I buy to take home?) and their escargots (this time finished with anchovy, bone marrow and garlic) - which is always utter perfection.  Their wine selections also reflected the Provence focus, with some great Rosés and a Languenoc red (Domaine Magellan) that will blow your socks off (not available at state stores, we were told, but Moore Brothers carries it).  Chef Woolsey and his team do not dissappoint.   Meat is always cooked on point (duck, lamb, beef, even frogs' legs, although the large ones aren't always as tender as the smaller ones), every item is flavored perfectly, delicately and meal progression is so well-timed, no rush, no fuss -- and you know what?  Desserts are bangin', too.

All in all, why go to Parc or Le Bec Fin, when Bistrot La Minette and Bibou do it so much better and so effortlessly?  In my book, it's no contest, no question.
name: Bistrot La Minette

text:
I am in fact a fan of Fat Salmon. I work down the street and frequent it with my colleagues. We have eaten there and gotten take-out and both are just as delicious and fresh. The restaurant is small so getting a table is sometimes hard without reservations. They do have a sushi bar you can sit at. 

You can't beat the lunch specials. I get a spicy tuna roll (6 pieces), two pieces of nigiri and two of sashimi + miso soup for $10.50.  There are other delicious specials as well.

text:
For the GF's bday last year, I decided to take her to Vetri. Frankly, I get more excited about food than her ... so it was easily more of a present for myself.

We walked through the dor and the rest was magic.

Service was superb - but that's to be expected when dinner runs over 600 for 2 grand tastings with accompanying wine tasting (we chose the lesser of the wine tasting options). 

Highlights were the spinach gnocchi and almond tortellini .... divine. Wish Vetri still offered an a la carte option because I would be there nightly. So great. Those two dishes alone were almost worth the splurge. 

Will be back - when I have a larger bankroll =)
name: Vetri Cucina

text:
Day By Day is a magical place for brunch! Yes the wait is ridiculous....and you you need to be smart about your timing. However, once you're in it's well worth the wait. Not to mention that it is so affordable! You really are getting your money's worth and beyond.

I love the simple but creative menu. For example: the chorizo, sweet potato hash with eggs on top. The flavor combos are perfect.

This time around I went with the potato pancakes benedict (poached eggs and smoked salmon over the potato and topped with hollandaise). My P.I.C. got the ham steak and eggs special* which was also amazing. The service was great....coffee and OJ never went dry.

I also was sure to grab several baked goods on the way out. The cinnamon buns are outrageously good. The glaze is super thick. Definitely some of the best I've ever had.


 
*Be sure to check out the special board!
name: Day By Day

text: I went here for brunch on Mother's Day and enjoyed my food quite a food. This time I got a Bloody Marias (Bloody Mary with tequila), Oberon, and a Headwater Pale Ale and ordered the eggs benedict with chorizo and pork belly. Excellent work, by the staff. Hospitable staff, attentive and generous bar tender. Lovely establishment, really. Just as good for dinner and brunch.

text:
yesterday i came in here looking for 3 items. THREE measly items, man!!! i wanted some sun-dried or roasted tomatoes, one of the ready-made quiches, and some smoked gouda......

i left 45 minutes, a full cart, and a watering mouth later.

tomorrow night's dinner? quiche, baby, quiche. the next? pasta with the aforementioned tomaters & smoked cheese. revel in my awesomeness.

text: Dining at the Royal Tavern is slightly above munching on bar food but far from impressing a dinner date (e.g., dark cluttered bar, overwhelming ceiling fans, History Channel on the television?).  The menu boasts some rich comfort foods, such as tater tots dressed up as nachos, but don't expect a gastronomic experience.  The bland grilled sweet potato "banh mi" is a Westernized bastardization of the Vietnamese original.  The service was pleasant and very accommodating, but it was still a disappointing meal (e.g., overcooked burgers, greasy sandwiches, cardboard salads).  Overall, there are much more misses than hits at this gastropub.
name: Royal Tavern

text:
(3.5 stars) Solid but not amazing food, except for the roti canai which is just irresistibly good. It is served with chicken on the bone in the gravy though so just be prepared. Also in terms of byob, it only applies to wine. If you bring your own beer, they will charge you for bringing it. 

As for the main dishes, the mango shrimp was my favorite, really sweet and the bell peppers provided some counter-texture to the soft mangos. The Penang spicy chicken though was disappointing. The sweet and sour vegetable slaw was really tasty, but it was prepared on the side, so the fried chicken was just served plain. As a result, the dish felt very disjoint and hard to enjoy.
name: Penang

text:
I go here for sweet - not savory.

I'm not sure why but even though I can purchase my own fresh fruit, granola, and coconut shavings then pour honey all over it, it still won't ever be as good as a honeygrow honey bowl. By the way, I recommend the whipped cream whether it defeats the purpose or not.

I'm not a big fan of the salads or noodles. If I want good noodles I opt for Dan Dan. If I want a good salad I head to Sweet Green or even the Stephen Starr cafeteria in United Plaza.

text: Gets really crowded for lunch!  If you have lunch plans, make sure you get there around 11:14-12 otherwise there won't be any seating.  I actually went here on Cinco de Mayo and had the chicken enchiladas, chips/guac, and house margaritas.  Everything was great!  I also did not know that it was connected to Ranstead Room which is a huge selling point.  Definitely a bit small but worth it for some authentic, inexpensive Mexican food.  I would definitely go back!

text:
Food is spectacular! Love the attentive service and cozy vibe this place offers.

SECRET: The bar is just as cozy and draws an electic mix from the academic and neighborhood crowd. This should be helpful as the rest of the bars on that block, LT, New Wave and Mad Mex can be packed!! Next time that happens, please give White Dog a try!

text:
One of the best restaurant I've dined at in Philly!

I went based off a recommendation from a friend (Roopa S. - always has spot on recs, btw) and I was not disappointed. 

Ambiance: Small, cute, romantic. Tons of candles, diml lighting and an intimate space. The restaurant was very small, so it's likely you'll get seated very close to another table (can be bothersome if it's a loud party, but not a game changer). However, the restaurant was extremely cozy and felt perfect for a date night or for a night out with a close friend. 

Service: Amazing service. The waiter was so friendly and helpful in giving us recs, it was just what we need to navigate through the huge menu. 

Food: 
1) Arancini - my first time trying arancini! I was a huge fan. I absolutely loved the soft risotto and cheese textures with each bite, and the pesto sauce that accompanied the dish was a perfect balance to make a dish a little more moist. I can't wait to keep trying this dish at other restaurants! 
2) Mushroom pizza - the size was the best part. It didn't stand out in terms of flavors but the mushrooms were plentiful and the crust was thin and crispy, like I love crusts to be. 
3) BUDINO : Too many reviews bragging about this dish so I'll just leave it at don't forget to save some room for this deliciousness, ESP if you're a salted caramel fan! 

Tips:
+Reservations are pretty hard to get - we made a reservation for a party of 2 a month in advance and still only got a 9:30 reservation time. They have walk ins but it's pretty rare to get a table like that (We saw a couple walk in around 10pm and the attendant at the front said that the next table would be available at 11:30 pm...?). 
+The small plates seem to be their highlights - I would recommend trying a few of those! (I really want to try the sheep's milk ricotta next time)
name: Barbuzzo

text:
Let me start by saying that the ambiance and the service left nothing to be desired. It's the food that was disappointing.

Let me put a few qualifiers to my review. We had a 8 PM show at the Academy of Music and we didn't make it to the restaurant until 6.50 (Fri night traffic!) So we couldn't order any of the fish entrees. The server recommended doing tapas style appetizers which included spanakopita, the fried cheese, their eggplant chips, octopus, and moussaka. Nothing wowed me...the moussaka in fact was quite disappointing.

Kanella at 11 and Spruce is head and shoulders above Estia when it comes to the quality offood. May be the fish wuda changed my review...but nonetheless we tried a broad variety of things and nothing was impressive.
name: Estia

text: This is your 'upscale' Mexican restaurant after you had your fill of El Vez outings. It has a great gothic Mexican feel, where it's cool and authentic but not too trendy. Great for large groups. The margaritas are strong, and definitely get the little tap for a group (sucks they only do the original flavor, not the specialty flavors in the tap). All the food was great, would recommend splitting the monster shrimps that look like lobster tails, as well as getting an order of the queso which is basically melted cheese in a dish that you scoop onto tortillas with anything else you want. Also the 'lava' dish is a large rock with hot stuff inside...and it is good! I love the chicken mole there as well. Finally, for dessert we tried almost all of them, and the favorite was definitely the tres leches cake and also the crepe...which unfortunately looks like soup because everything melts on top of it. I would recommend for them to include more than one crepe, or at least pre cut it into shareable pieces. They also have some tables on the street for those nice summer nights!
name: Tequilas Restaurant

text: This became my favorite barbecue place ever since Zeke's closed down in Overbrook some years ago.  My credo when it comes to good barbecue is that it shouldn't need the sauce to be good. text:
PREFACE: This one's going to be long, so if you just don't have the time, scroll to bottom. Xo, Isabelle 

I've eaten in justtttt about 80% of the best restaurants in Philly. And I'm talking about restaurants renowned for their AMAZING food, whether they were budget corner spots or $50+ a plate. Zahav took me a while to get to (not sure why, but it did) BUT it was worth the wait and made it to my top 5.

I LOVE their slightly secret location. I've frequented Old City/Society Hill for years and eat regularly at their neighbor, Positano Coast. So I'm not sure why I never noticed Zahav. On a whim, I decided that it would be where I would take my boyfriend for his birthday, just because it had SUCH good reviews on OpenTable and one lucky little reservation. I adore their simple, open decor that reminds me of a market in Tel Aviv. It was clean and sophisticated but comfortable and unique, with that private feel that you get from an elevated restaurant in a dark corner of a quiet side street, surrounded by bushes and landscaping.  It's dressy casual so it's perfect for date night or post-happy hour dinner with your best friend. 

Now that we have all the extras out of the way, let's talk about what really matters: SERVICE and FOOD!!!

I've been a server for many years. It's not rocket science, but not everyone can deliver rockstar service. It's a bit of an art, and the best service requires teamwork. This place had possibly THE BEST SERVICE I've received in the city. Our server was knowledgable and volunteered advice and explanations about the fairly exotic Israeli food. She never steered us wrong...all of her suggestions were amazing....but we'll get to that in a minute. The drinks took a little while but the bar was full and that's totally forgivable. Otherwise, our water glasses were always full, and an empty plate never sat for more than a minute before it was removed. It was perfectly synchronized service between the server, food runner, busser, and any other staff that walked by. Everyone chipped in to make the experience flawless!! 

Now, for the good part: their unbelievable, delectable food!! 
Zahav offers both ala carte and prix fixe options. The two prix fixe option are $39 and $48, with the main difference being that the higher priced option offered a chef's selection of mezze and the entree was their signature lamb shoulder. My boyfriend wasn't feeling the lamb (although after seeing it come out of the kitchen a few times, he definitely wanted to come back and try it...I second the idea), so we decided on the $39 menu which included salatim and hummus (a mix of salads and spreads), a choice of 2 mezze per person, one entree, and a desert. My boyfriend wanted to try an extra entree so he ordered an extra kebab (that we really didn't need).  Given that each item is at least $8, it's a no-brainer to go for the prix fixe! 

Let me tell you, it was one of the best meals I've had since I can remember. The hummus and laffa were delicious, as well all of the salatim! They reminded me a lot of food I'd eat as a child (Russian cuisine has a lot of similarities with Isreali cuisine). 
 
For our mezze, we ordered the brussel sprouts, sea bass crudo, grilled duck hearts, and the house smoked sable. All were delicious, but the duck hearts were an instant favorite....don't ewwww. They were amazing, and if you can get past the mental image of Aaliyah in Queen of the Damned sucking the blood out of a beating heart, they might be your new favorite too! 

I'm not sure what our entrees were...but they were equally fantastic! I definitely want to come back for the lamb shoulder!! That just looked like a giant hunk of incredible!!  

Our deserts were the perfect end to a perfect meal and weren't too sweet (I'm sweet enough as it is, I don't need the extra sugar!). And their coffee was STRONG as coffee should me. Speaking of strong, we put back a couple cocktails while we were there. My boyfriend loved his!! I liked mine but because I had a cold, I went for the whiskey and bourbon drinks (Irish cough syrup!!), which were delicious but the strong flavor didn't match the light flavorful food. 

ANNYYYWAYYYYY......To sum up this epicly long visual of my phenom experience, I would definitely recommend this as an authentic, incredible alternative to your typical date night or family dinner or whatever. The prix fixe menu is THE way to go. You will not be disappointed! The amount of food will leave you full but not in a food coma (a sacred art). The service rivals that of any other 4 star restaurant in the city. Don't be afraid to go out of your comfort zone, duck hearts might become your new fave!!

I recommend it.

text:
This place came highly recommended to me by a trusted friend so I was eager to stop by for happy hour. The happy hour deals are pretty bomb- the first five items on the menu were $7 so we ordered all five.
The chicken liver mousse was the star of the show, so creamy and tasty! We used up the house made rye bread right away and our waitress brought us more bread so we could sop up the rest of the liver mousse. We also ordered the latkes, and there happened to be a special for the 2nd day of chanukkah topped with lobster salad and roe that was delicious. 
The pickled mackerel dip was far too fishy for my taste, I couldn't even force myself to scoop up another bite with the lettuce. I love brussel sprouts so the brussel sprouts caesar was right up my alley. The borscht tartare has good flavor and the sour cream onion chips were perfectly crispy. Romanesco was good but not particularly memorable. The chef also sent us a complimentary dish which was much appreciated. 
I can see why this place is so loved. It was a different experience for my Asian food loving palate but definitely worth the try.

text:
Brace yourself for brain freezes & some fan-freakin-tastic hummus!

Dizengoff does wonders with a limited menu of rich, creamy hummus, topping each dish with a rotating selection of meats and veggies.  The pita is the fluffiest, softest, and chewiest I've ever had.  And the lemonnana is a deliciously tart, herbaceous (mint & basil?) frozen treat.  Everything was phenomenal!

Word to the wise -- let the kitchen know if you have any food allergies.  I ordered the beet hummus, which to my surprise came with raisins, pistachios, and other delicious spices along with the shredded beets.  Go ahead and get selfish -- order an extra pita for $1 so you can split your dish into two meals.

Pro tip: it's been several weeks since Dizengoff opened and they still sell out of pita/ platters.  Get there before 2pm to satisfy your craving.  When we got in line (1pm or so) there were no seats available, but by the time we ordered there were several seats open.  

My parting thoughts?  Don't overlook tipping at this "fast" food concept.  On a busy weekday lunch there was only one woman serving the dishes as they came up to the pass and clearing tables.  She did an awesome job keeping the place tidy & flipping tables.

text: It turns out having a reservation and arriving on time for that reservation will not prevent them from sitting you in the worst table in the restaurant (perhaps the worst table I've ever been seated in). That one little annoyance aside, dinner was spectacular. The food was everything you would hope a modern take on southern cooking would be. We started off with the crispy curried squash blossoms and the warm buttermilk pretzel rolls. Both were excellent. For dinner my wife had Marilyn's Fried Chicken and I had the Seared Sea Scallops. Both dishes were perfect, but the fried chicken was definitely the winner. Feeling gluttonous, I had the Brownie Sundae and my wife had the Chocolate Peanut Butter cake. Mistake. The dessert portions were huge. I would definitely go back.

text:
For brunch: 
Buffet style isn't usually my thing but so many people recommended it I had to check it out. And I'm glad I did!! Everything was delicious and there's something for everyone. Everything is replaced quickly and kept super fresh. 

The highlights for my were the quiche, biscuits and gravy, and the potatoes but everything was good. 

This is a great spot if you have a big group going, just make sure to make a reservation. It's $28 for the buffet and they have a drink deal idr exactly what it is but it's a discounted price for 4-5 drinks.

text:
Vibes: candle-lit, lofty with high ceilings, designer, cozy-home feels with the colors, cushions, drapes, long family-friendly tables, wooden chairs; hospitable to the post-work bar crowd, date nights, and group dinners; can get pretty loud

Chef's tasting menu: one pick from each category besides the sharing for two + dessert bite; a very satisfying meal 

Tasting notes:
-mushroom farro: nutty and savory, a healthy blend of shaved greens and chewy farro, with crunchy chips and a soft-boiled egg on top
-lamb meatballs: very tender and juicy, not crumbly, served in a cast-iron pan drenched in a rich tomato-y sauce with sweet dates and yogurt drizzled in, with crusty, toasted french bread slices perfect for sopping up leftover sauce
-big eye tuna poke: refreshing mix of avocado and tuna chunks with a great crunch from the toasted macadamia nut halves
-spinach pizza: puffy, airy crust with just enough flavor from the cheese, covered with large, oven-roasted leaves of spinach
-brussel sprouts: soft, a few burnt edges; thick slivers of almost hammy, smoked bacon; mustard seeds added an interesting texture and flavor
-ricotta gnocchi: small pieces in a chunky tomato sauce; forgettable but also was getting super full by the time it got to the table! 
-flat iron steak, medium rare: gently caramelized exterior with a soft chew, served sliced with whole peppers and a few mushroom caps 
-key lime whoopie pie: cakey cookies, flavor enhanced by lime syrup drops; torched marshmallow fluff was a nice touch

Will be back for: the downstairs bar next to the two bowling lanes, which seemed way more chill and laid-back!
name: Harp & Crown

text: Love love love Winnie's for brunch! I've been there so many times, you'd think I would get sick of it.  They have a pretty small brunch menu, but it is quality!  Their mimosas are really good - the best is their elderberry mimosa. It's a little bit bitter from the grapefruit, but has a light elderberry taste that makes it very refreshing.  My friends and I have tried all of their mimosas at this point - the sunrise mimosa is also very popular - a nice spin on the classic.  As for best brunch meal - the Eggs Benedict are just right.  The hollandaise sauce isn't too heavy, but has all the flavor you're looking for.   My new favorite is their breakfast frittata - the one on their specials menu this summer is fresh and has a lot of delicious veggies in the mix.  My friends have tried their oatmeal, the french toast, different omelettes.  Everything has been really really good!  Also, make sure you get their bread - it is always hot and goes very well with the jam they serve in a jar.  My friends and I love the cute ambiance, tasty drinks and good service!

text:
Despite having lived in the neighborhood for quite some time, I never managed to generate any interest for a potential trip to Varga Bar. A recent dinner confirmed the fact that I've been missing out. The beer list, as expected for any respectable Philly gastropub, offered numerous choices for any palette conveniently divided between "strong" and "session" brews. Though other reviewers find this system of classification irksome, it makes deciding on one of the twenty-two taps simpler than usual. The beer prices do run a bit high, but certainly aren't unaffordable.

We began the meal pleasantly with an order of Varga's famous crab and cheese fries. The cheese sauce ladled on top of the crisp, thin spuds provided a pleasant, milky tang with a creamy texture. Even when it inevitably congealed from sitting at room temperature too long, the combination of the aforementioned cheese sauce and ample chunks of lump crab complimented each other well, and this fry creation subsequently was as good as advertised.

Our main dishes similarly hit the spot. A friend ordered the pork belly cubano (a special that day) which brought crunchy yet soft pressed bread and decidedly porcine meat in a compact sandwich vehicle. His sandwich ranked among the better Cubans I've tried in the city, yet my fried oyster po-boy tasted even better. Though not a po-boy in the authentic sense, it brought a fantastic combination of flavors and textures. Namely, the shatteringly crisp yet pillowy soft french bread, oceanic oysters, light cole slaw, and house pickles struck a harmonious, gustatory chord. The sandwich actually outclasses my previous favorite at Khyber Pass. Old-bay fries served alongside maintained a pleasant crisp even after a bit of time on the table.

Other perks of Varga include a 4-6 happy hour with half-off drafts and buck-a-shuck oysters all day, making for some potentially economical drinking and munching. Even without specials, the food didn't cost too much given the ample portions and ingredient quality. I certainly will return to sample the menu further.

text: My husband and I have been coming here for years and rarely have we had a disappointing experience.   The empanada verde and oysters Rodriquez are favorite appetizers.  You really cannot go wrong with any of the fish sections and the Lechon Asado is wonderful.  We have tried a few cervices' and enjoyed them all.  The desserts are a treat and if you have room definite try one.  We love the atmosphere albeit sometimes the music can be way too loud, and the place can get really noisy.  The décor is white on white on red and somehow it works beautifully.  It is a great place for drinks and appetizers or a romantic meal.  The service has always been accommodating, friendly and well informed on menu options.  The chef is very accommodating to special needs.

text:
Best Thai that I've had in Philly, though there is a lot of Malay influence.

Roti canal is one of the best I've ever had - better than most Malaysian restaurants. Super flaky but moist at the same time. And delicious curry to dip.

Tofu baker is like tofu satay - flavorful peanut sauce but still not too heavy.

Papaya salad - good but probably not my favorite.

Thai fried rice - surprisingly flavorful in itself, a bit of sweetness and spice. 

Pad see ew - great flavor - I asked for it spicy and it definitely was. The egg adds nice flavor and texture.

Great service with the 2 that were helping us

text:
I recently had to plan a large group dinner and a couple of my friends suggested Rangoon. I had heard of the place but never had the chance to try it out. And I'm really glad I did!

I originally had a group of 23, but due to scheduling errors, only 10 of us showed up. They were very accommodating and the servers were all very nice. Right from when we sat down, they starting serving us. Our first course was a spring ginger salad minus the shrimp. I absolutely love Burmese salads and this was no disappointment. The ginger was so strong but oh so good. And there were many other add-ins that gave it a nice crunch too.

We were next served the thousand layer bread with potato curry. It reminded me a lot of Malaysian roti canai. The bread was nice and flaky and the curry had just the right spice level. Not too filling but a great tasting appetizer. Next came all the main dishes. I don't remember all the names, but we had chili shrimp, coconut curry chicken, vegetarian delight, and vegetarian Northern Burma fried noodle.

The chili shrimp was fantastic. It was slightly overcooked, but the breading on the outside was just right and didn't drown out the meat. The seasoning and sauces was spot on. Loved every crunch. The coconut curry chicken was nothing special. I've had curry at multiple places and this one didn't really stand out. Vegetarian delight was same old, same old. Just your standard stir fried veggies with tofu in a mixture of sauces. Unfortunately, the Northern Burma fried noodles were awful. There was almost no flavor. I wasn't sure if they just didn't add enough seasoning, or if the chili sauce they used overpowered what little flavor it had. Either way, the noodles were a little painful to eat, with nothing but the "spicy" flavor greeting your mouth. And the add-ins weren't exciting either.

The food wasn't that great, but the good dishes were pretty solid and there's a lot on the menu I'd love to go back and try. And the service was awesome and speedy.

Pros: Service, variety of menu (so many options!)
Cons: some bland flavors, a little pricey for portions

Dishes to try: any of their salads, Chili Shrimp
Dishes to skip: Northern Burma Fried Noodles, Vegetarian Delight
name: Rangoon Burmese Restaurant

text:
Incredible! That's all of it, in one word. But of course I will elaborate. 

My and wife and I celebrated our 1st anniversary here and it was amazing! Our names with congratulations were on the menu, all service staff all sent their well wishes, and we were offered a complimentary champagne toast! 
This was truly a great anniversary!

Oh, the food.. 
The food is as outstanding as the service. We did the warm Turkish hummus with pita. For the next portion we got 4 small plates to share.

1) Fried Cauliflower - this had labneh, mint, lemon, and aleppo accompanied with it. It was made perfectly! We loved this dish. 

2) Mushroom Schnitzel - this dish came with celery, tehina, mustard greens, and fresno. Another fabulous dish. Really enjoyed this as well! My wife said she would easily get this again. 

3) Haloumi in brik- Accompanied with passion fruit, walnut, and pickled onions. This was absolutely delicious. 
It was definitely a dish I would want again. 

4) Brussels Sprouts - this came with pickled apples, schug, and Brussels baba! We both went nuts over this dish! It was by far our favorite. An "A+" amongst "A". 

Finally to wrap things up we got the hazelnut cake that had whipped labneh and Asian pears. Loved this dessert! Glad we went with this!

Overall, with no surprise, this was an amazing place to come for our anniversary. We had high expectations and they were EXCEEDED! There is no doubt that we will be back, it's a matter of getting a reservation! 

Also, the service can not be talked about enough. Alicia was on top of her water game. Constantly filled it up, and even protected us and the table from splashes by holding a napkin to guard. Our waitress was also amazing (forgot her name), but she was very bubbly and informative with the menu. Also, she was very attentive. Everyone was amazing here! 

Can't wait to come back soon!

text: This place deserves every accolade in the books. It was a cold November day and the only thing I wanted was some noodle bowl. We got the pancake to share and it was delicious - crispy, oily, and incredibly inexpensive. I did not realize that they had both hand drawn noodles as well as shaved noodles. As I learned, hand drawn noodles are more of a spaghetti shape, whereas shaved noodles are cut from a block of dough into the boiling pot. The result is chewier, cuts of noodles that is mouth watering and I swear gets bigger as it soaks in more broth from the noodle bowl. This place is fantastic as is cheap. You have to have some cash on hand though - but there's an ATM inside if you want to use it.

text:
I'm sorry, but I just don't get the hype. It's a cute cafe and the staff is friendly, but for me the food and experience was not worth enduring a 45 minute wait in a cramped hallway. The cafe is really really small and, if you're not sitting in the patio area, it can get quite loud.

The iced coffee and the sweet potato hash were good, but the rest of the food was just mediocre. Maybe I'm getting a little particular, but I strongly dislike when eggs are served on the same plate as fruit - I don't want warm fruit that's sitting in egg-flavored liquid.

I'd stop back to grab coffee to go, but other than that I'd probably only come back for a sit-down meal if invited.

text:
I have been here once for restaurant week and once with the regular menu. Even though the restaurant week menu is limited, it's the best bang for your buck. $35pp during restaurant week or $60-$70pp regular menu? The choice is easy. Honestly the food is good but for what it costs on the regular menu, not worth it. For restaurant week prices, it's great value. Ive never had a bad dish here but it's also not anything that has blown me away.

On the bright side with tapas, you get to try so many different dishes and get a taste for everything. Reservations are a must here and book in advance.

text:
I love brunch!! My boyfriend and I went to Sabrina's on a Thursday and there was no wait and no line! Our waiter also sat us in a booth! We both ordered coffees and they were extra strong! I had to take two stars off because I found a bug or a spec of dirt in my coffee! I was extremely disappointed because coffee gets me through the day! 

I loved that we could make our own combo for our pancakes! We added chocolate chips and m&ms to ours since I have a sweet tooth! The portion was perfect and not overbearing like green eggs! They were a tad bit dry but they were fun to eat! 

LOVED the Parmesan fries! Could definitely taste the parm on them and they helped with the sweetness of the pancakes.

We also got a bagel with cream cheese...the cream cheese on the bagel tasted very fresh.

Overall, we had a great experience and the food was delicious and filling. The only downside was the coffee! 

Definitely fulfilled our once a month cravings for brunch!!

text:
Thank you Philadelphia for making me well-versed enough in pho to speak on the greatness of this establishment. Pho Xe Lua Viet Thai is my new favorite place to get pho.

A friend of a friend swears by this place, so after trying many others, I tried to come here a couple weeks ago, but it was too packed to get a table. I returned a bit after 5 on a Friday, and had no trouble getting a table for two. First of all, Pho Xe Lua has the best dining atmosphere - over all other places to get pho in Philadelphia. Their menu is bigger than a lot of the other spots as well. You can also order alcoholic beverages or a bubble tea to suit your tastes.

Service is super quick and pretty friendly. The pho...great meat quality, tasty noodles, cheap, and decent size. Perfect.

This spot deserves to be my default pho restaurant!

text:
North Third has all the trappings of a future hot spot of mine; super awesome beer list, decent wine list for when the mood strikes, and a good balance of bar vs. real food.  The decor is also super cool...kind of a mix of pirates, skulls, & eagles.  I'm down.  
They also have an adorable outside area to eat.  The salad I ordered (chile glazed chicken salad) was right on.  I will be back my friends!

text:
I tend to agree with the knowledgeable Michelle C on most of her thoughts. I went in around 1:15 on a weekday thinking I would have missed a good amount of the lunch crowd. Perhaps I did, but I was still flustered and confused walking in as to where to order. 

My machine also kept forgetting my orders when I clicked back which was frustrating. The options were plentiful and unique and very specific (light dressing, on the side, etc).

I got mixed greens with whole wheat noodles with baked tofu, mushrooms, tomatoes, onions, and cilantro ranch dressing. The wheat noodles definitely had a coat of oil on them which I didn't like. OD on the onions. Dressing was really good. Total $8.75. Granted I was very full after. 

Happy I tried this place that people RAVE about, but I wouldn't put this necessarily in my favorite lunch places in the Rittenhouse area. I do want to go back to try the stir frys though.

text:
Super sweet service, super salty dishes.

Must get: toast (fromage + kumquats), warm lentils, non-alcoholic ginger drink, fettuccine, daily specials
Meh: squid salad, pork sausage
Missed out: main courses


Vernick is one of the more coveted Philadelphia eateries in downtown Center City that requires at least 2-3 weeks of planning and reservation in advance. We came here for an early dinner, celebrating our wedding anniversary and were immediately seated next to the window aisle with beautiful potted plants hanging overhead and a nice view of the Walnut street. The highlight of Vernick, however, is the staff. While there were other reviews that mentioned less attentive staff, I will say that Ethan, our server extraordinaire, was amazing. He was very honest about specific dishes, mentioned foods that were safe for my pregnant wife, and even took back a dish that was too salty and removed it from the bill all together. That being said, the overall service was fantastic, with attention to details, multiple table cleaning and well-timed water refills.

I'm not going to lie, Vernick was not cheap, the two of us ordered only tapas-dishes (fairly sizable) and easily racked a $130+ bill with just one non-alcoholic beverage (totally worth it). My must gets are the toast, the lentils and the fish. The other meat dishes were incredibly salty to a point where I had to stop or else I'll drown myself in water. I had high hopes for the squid salad, but it failed to appeal to me artistically, and I wished the squid tentacles had a greater mouth feel and brinier taste.

At the end of the day, if you have the time and the money, Vernick is an excellent spot for business, casual or dating. My one recommendation is to lay low on the salt.

Food: 4 stars
Service: 5 stars
Ambiance: 4-5 stars
Price: 3-4 stars

text: This menu at this place is a hit or a miss. The buffalo cauliflower is amazing! Anything on their brunch menu is delicious. However, I had the black bean burger for dinner a different time, and tried he jackfruit sandwich and I was not thrilled. The black bean burger was very bland and dry. The portion was large but I wouldn't recommend that item. The jackfruit sandwich was decent, tasty but didn't taste as unique as I had expected it to. I will definitely come back- but only for brunch and happy hour.

text:
Food: 4.25
My partner and I ordered the chorizo (Mexican sausage) tacos de la casa and costilla de res (short rib) tacos de la plancha, respectively. No complaints about the tacos! My goodness we loved the seasoning, texture, and the salsa verde/salsa roja. We also loved the horchata. The only product that fell flat was the choco-flan. I bought it on impulse, texture was fine; however, the flavor was flat. I was disappointed the flan was bland and so was the chocolate cake. With that said I'll give their regular flan a chance next time. 

Service: 5 Out of 5
Obviously due to COVID-19 we're only allowed to do take out only. Regardless, the service was wonderful. While the the cashier was on the phone with another customer the man assisting her took the time to acknowledge me and take my order so I wouldn't be waiting too long. 

Overall: 4.5 Out of 5
This taqueria aficionada votes a definite yes for the savory food!
name: Los Gallos Mexican Taqueria

text: La Calaca Feliz (Navidad!) That's what it felt like - a Mexican Christmas fiesta! The only complaint here is that the wait was a bit long, but it was a weekend night and I didn't even make a rezzy! What should I expect?! La Calaca has a great bar right when you walk in, and they were serving up primo margaritas (of which Stevie obviously consumed a few)! The dining area is past the bar in a back room, which makes for a more a modern and intimate dinner experience. Definitely a casual and original spot that you should be sure to checkout if you're in Fairmount!

text: I've lived within a 2 block radius of this place for 2 years now and how I never managed to stumble into this gem is a mystery and a crime! There is no beating their dollar tacos and 3-5 dollar margaritas during happy hour! They offer chicken, steak, fish, and veggie tacos in soft corn tortillas, and their nachos are the best I've ever had. Tip: the deal ends at 6:30, so make sure to get all your orders in before then! The place is a bit loud, but worth it for the food and the prices!

The sweet potato fries are hit or miss, but I would risk it because when they are good, they are GOOD.

text: This review comes after visiting Butcher Bar twice.  Me and the missus visited Butcher Bar a few months ago when we were looking to grab a bite before heading to a comedy show.  That first experience was great all around: food, drinks, and service.  We couldn't wait to return so we made our way back downtown on a nice Sunday afternoon for our second visit.  We lucked up and found a parking spot across the street from the restaurant.  We observed that Butcher Bar offered curbside seating but we opted to sit inside.  We were seated at a nice table for two on the second level.  I didn't realize how beautiful the outside courtyard is until we finished our meal.  I will ask to sit there next visit.  Butcher Bar has a bar located at the front of the venue and a second is located in the courtyard.  The glass enclosed kitchen allows patrons to get a look at the chefs and the delicious food being prepared.  Shortly after being seated our waiter came to the table with water.  He told us about the specials and took our drink order.  I opted for the Citywide a 1 oz. shot of house made rock and rye with a can of 2SP Delco Lager.  My lovely dining companion ordered the Peach Blossom which consisted of crystal head vodka, peach liqueur, peach puree, orange juice, and lime juice.  We enjoyed our libations while perusing the menu.  We started with Mexican meatballs as an appetizer. Carne asada, crispy tortilla, guacamole, and pico de gallo.  The meatballs came out and looked amazing. They tasted great and were quickly finished off.  We also had the BOSC PEAR, BABY KALE & QUINOA SALAD.  Made with goat cheese, red onion, candied pecans, spiced cider vinaigrette.  It was yummy also.  It was Sunday and I was tempted to get the prime rib.  I had it on my first visit and it was delicious but I landed on the PEANUT BUTTER BACON BISON BURGER with cheddar cheese, candied bacon, bibb lettuce, tomato, side of house-cut fries.  I don't know who is responsible for this combination but Thank You.  That burger was a great experience.  The delicious bison meat and the candied bacon alongside the peanut butter and side of sweet sauce. Two thumbs up!  The missus ordered the RIGATONI W/ BROCCOLI RABE, ITALIAN SAUSAGE, OLIVE OIL, GARLIC-PARMESAN BROTH.  She enjoyed the dish and allowed me to taste a piece of sausage which was so good. Thank you Butcher Bar for another great dining experience.  We can't wait to come back with friends.

text:
Supermarket sushi.  Vic sushi's claim to fame, tuna dumplings is a unique presentation but it's not enough to overcome shortcomings in other aspects.  

The greatest shortcoming is that the sushi here is not the freshest.  This was disappointing as I stood waiting in anticipation for those sitting down to finish and leave.  With no shortage of customers, you'd think the food was undeniably fresh/good if not great.  This was one of very few instances when I've sat down in a sushi restaurant and left sushi behind.  I can't figure out why there is this great following but I can only assume that a lower price point relative to other sushi joints in the area may be the reason why.

I'm not sure if the folks behind the counter are certified at their profession.  I didn't find precision in the rolls that were made for me.  Sure the tuna dumplings look good and I did finish my order of them but the remaining rolls I was served was presented/created sloppy.  

The restaurant is really small and I mean really small.  Check the pictures.  This isn't a place for a large group.  Order, eat and run.  

Parking is difficult.

text: One of the nicest and largest coffee shops ive ever seen located in the heart of one of the fastest growing neighborhoods of Philadelphia.  I came here with a small group for some pastries and coffee. We tried the different hand poured coffees and it was unbelievable but expensive.  The biggest downside is that the few times ive been here and ordered the hand poured coffee it took 30 minutes to be ready and it was very frustrating yet delicious. The atmosphere is incredible with high ceilings, really cool decorations including copper barrels display in the back where they make the rum.  It has a little of a museum feel if there is such thing. The pastries are all very good and between all my friends and I we have tried mostly all of them.  They also serve sandwiches which I havent tried yet but they look appetizing.  If they can improve the speed of their service they would be perfect. I will definitely come back here again.

text:
I'm not going to say I don't get the appeal. The decor totally feels like a cafe in Paris, it's very spacious, and who doesn't like looking out over Rittenhouse while enjoying good company and food. Unfortunately the food has never done it for me, and especially not at these prices. Went here for brunch with the girls and the food was good, but not fantastic. Was taken here for lunch by my boss, so yay for comped food, but again it just didn't wow me. My boss really loves their beet salad though, so if I ever go back maybe I'll give one more try with that. 

Any by the way, I get it, it's a place to be seen. Oo, look at me eating at the posh french bistro in my 6 inch heels with my tiny purse dog. Doesn't it lose the effect to be sitting at a table that's practically in the street? Would it hurt their business so much to do away with those extra tables and give pedestrians some actual space to walk by? 'Cause seriously, I don't know how much longer I can resist snatching some bread off the sidewalk tables as I crab-walk past trying to get up 18th Street.

I'd be willing to try this spot again, but only during their evening HH (no regular HH, sadly)/

text:
I thought this place was pretty darn good.

I stopped in here with a friend recently and I very much enjoyed both the service and the food.  I arrived early so I sat at the bar.  The bartender let me sample all 3 of their cask ales and I ended up going wit his original recommendation.  While I waited, I asked him what his favorite thing on the menu was.  Without delay, he said "the chicken and duck liver parfait."  Fortunately, when my friend arrived, she agreed to try that.

We ordered oysters, deviled eggs, the parfait, the pint of prawns and the beet cured salmon.  The oysters were delicious and fresh, not very briny.  The deviled eggs were just right and had a hint of curry and cayenne in them.  The pint of prawns was closer to a shrimp cocktail but the shrimp were done perfectly.  I really enjoyed the salmon, along with the dill and crème fraiche that it was served with.  I really enjoyed the flavor of the parfait, but the portion was very large.  They give you three slices of brioche which is clearly not enough.  We even ordered a second batch of brioche and it still wasn't enough for all the parfait.  It's very rich and I recommend having it, but maybe splitting it among 3 or 4 people.

The layout and decor of this place is really cool and I can see myself stopping back in here for drinks and a bite to eat.  The bartenders are nice, knowledgeable and will go out of their way to make sure you have a good time.

Cheers!

text:
The Pho here is pretty good/standard, and our overall experience wasn't terrible but the service was pretty slow and they almost forgot my friend's ice tea order until after the food arrived even though we ordered it as soon as we sat down. 

6 hours later...I had some pretty bad food poisoning/side effects. I don't totally want to blame or discredit this place but that is the exact window/time period for food poisoning...and nothing I ate was with my hands :/

Not a terrible place but I probably will not return due to this incident.

text:
I was over here for lunch a week or so ago and decided I'd see what the fuss was all about. I had a tough choice between either a pork sandwich or the beef brisket. I ended up deciding on the beef brisket.

Service was very prompt and fast. They cranked through a long line of people in front of me in a very short time span. I made my order, got my drink, paid for the sandwich and drink and presto! My sandwich was ready.

The sandwich came out a steaming pile of beef with dripping juices that smelled pretty good. The meat was tender and moist and had a lot of flavor to it. The juices also had a lot of flavor in it and really helped make the sandwich. I wasn't as impressed with the roll/bread that the meat was in. It wasn't stale, but it wasn't tasty or particularly noteworthy as well.


Next time I"m coming back for the pork sandwich. I'm curious to see how it matches up against Tony Luke's/my favorite.

text: This is definitely on the pricier end, but I feel like at this point if you make reservations a restaurant with no research on about how much you might be spending that meal, that is no one's fault by your own. Me and three other friends went for a birthday celebration so we got four meals, three apps and drinks. Oysters were very fresh and tasty, never disappointed by their escargot either. Salmon tartine is delish, and beautiful to look at. Carpaccio, also delicious, whenever they have a tart on the menu order that they've all been great. Outdoor and indoor seating, make a reservation.

text:
I met a friend for eats and drinks here last week.  We got there early so were placed at a prime window-side seat. The server was friendly and helpful, and the food was pretty damn good.  I liked the ambiance and the retro/cool fixtures and seating.

I had the steak frites and I just about cleaned my plate.  The garlic/lemon aioli served on the side was to die for.

text:
After reading so many glowing reviews of Dalessandro's Steaks, I had to try one. I was sorely disappointed. The place was clean, and the people were nice, but the sandwich didn't live up to the hype. 
I ordered the special, or something with a similar name. It was a cheesesteak with green peppers, onions, mushrooms, and tomato sauce. That would normally be an excellent sandwich. While there was plenty of steak on the sandwich, the flavor just wasn't there. It needed seasoning, and was, frankly, bland. Also, the steak was too finely chopped. I prefer the steak on my cheesesteak to be chopped, but this was overkill. 

Maybe I just caught them on a bad day, or it was a new, inexperienced grill man. I don't know. But the sandwich wasn't worth a trip to Roxborough.
name: Dalessandro’s Steaks & Hoagies

text:
It's a little expensive, but I enjoyed Amada.  The food was very good.  We got the chef's selection tasting menu.  We had no idea what was coming next, or even if there was more food coming.  That meant I didn't pace myself and could barely find room to taste the last few dishes.  Just when we thought we were done, more food arrived.  The first course (or round) of dishes was overwhelming.  Six dishes at once was a bit much.  I would have preferred to stagger them a bit.  We could barely fit it all on our table.  But I did enjoy everything, especially the goat cheese with a cherry-fig something or other.  

The service was good.  Our waiter was enthusiastic and knowledgeable but not overbearing.  He answered questions and chatted about the dishes.

To drink, we ordered a pitcher of sangria.  It was good but would probably be better suited to a hot day.  Next time I'd opt for some regular wine that might pair better with the food.

The negative: it was LOUD.  Tables are close together, and we got caught in the middle of a conversation between people on either side of us (they'd struck up a discussion before we arrived).  Worse yet, the ambient noise was so loud we couldn't hear each other across the table.  We couldn't lean in because there was too much food in front of us.  I'd return to Amada, but I'd rather sit at the bar.
name: Amada

text:
Harp & Crown is like two different restaurants. The weekend brunch buffet (offered Saturdays & Sundays) has a whole different vibe than the "other" (same place) sit -down restaurant. If you're wondering (and I was) the weekend brunch options are basically the same on both Saturdays and Sundays (I asked). But from what I understand, the flavors of the scones and quiches change periodically and I imagine some of the seasonal offerings may change as well. There wasn't that much that was seasonal so it's probably fairly consistent.

Food/drink cont'd.
I really enjoyed the all you can eat brunch as a whole and though I didn't try every single item, I certainly enjoyed what I tried. My favorite items were the roast prime rib and the fried potatoes. If there had been a roasted vegetable and a popover, it would have been a classic "Sunday Roast." I was hoping they'd have a Caesar salad option, but not all wishes come true. None the less, the offerings were still very, very good- in fact it was one of the best brunch buffets I've ever attended, including the one at Lacroix! 
The pot de creme chocolate was delicious, especially with the fresh berries. I also enjoyed the smoked salmon/bagel option. 

We also ordered a bottle of sparkling wine to mix with the OJ and GFJ options included with the brunch which also included iced or hot coffee or iced or hot tea(unlimited). All of this was $28/person. The bottle of sparkling wine was $44. For Center City, these prices are great!

And unlike a lot of the all you can eat places, the quality of the food was excellent. I usually know afterward by how thirsty I am. And since I'm not thirsty at all, I think that means the food wasn't full of preservatives and other cheap flavor enhancers to make up for quality. I thought the smoked salmon was not at all over the top salty which made it extra yummy. I took lots of photos. There was something for everyone on that brunch buffet and I recommend it to everyone who likes to eat. 

Re. Photos, I didn't capture everything served on the brunch menu. So there will be a few fun surprises when it's your turn to experience H&C weekend brunch!

Service:
One of the highlights of the day was the gentleman who served the prime rib and also made the waffles. I should have asked him his name! He was outstanding! With a great personality, he hand sliced with perfection! He was also very nice and professional and I could tell he took pride in his work! He really enjoyed it and when you feel that, it makes the whole experience that much better! He's a keeper!!! I see great things for his future!

Adam our server was terrific and there was plenty of support staff to grab our empty plates. I noticed they got pretty aggressive near the end and not as attentive at the beginning which felt not so great; especially since we still had half of a bottle of wine to drink when they started hanging about us. So it felt a bit presumptive. If they really wanted us to go, perhaps they should have refilled our glasses with the wine instead of attempting to snatch our plates away before we were finished. That would have been a more diplomatic approach and its not easy for everyone to pour their own wine. 

In spite of that one not so fun issue, it was a great  experience and again I highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys brunch or just enjoys food.
name: Harp & Crown

text:
I'm really torn over this review. I want to say lots of positive things, but most of that goes towards the ambiance. You really can't beat this view. Everyone is so hyped up that George Sabatino is here, and I don't mean to be hard on the guy, but it's not just food that I'm droooling over. 

I ordered the cheeseburger and my friend ordered the bacon sandwich. The cheeseburger was fine, but if I'm going to pay that much, I'd rather go to Shake Shack. And it's still a pet peeve of mine when they don't come with fries and you have to pay extra. Though I am a fan of pickled veggies, which all the sandwiches here come with. My friend's bacon sandwich was very dry. The bread definitely needed more than some residual fat and swipe of mustard. It needs a sauce. I tried to use the aioli from the fries but it still didn't quite do the trick. The Really Good Fries are not as good as advertised. They're overly salty and the aioli is not spicy. 

To drink, I got a Dark and Stormy which was fine (but it's not a complicated drink). My friend stuck to beer. On warmer days, I want to try a Watermelon Ricky to see if it's all the rave. I do quite enjoy the 21st Amendment beer on its own. 

I'm not opposed to trying other things on the menu. I know I'll be back because I love the patio so much. I think I'll splurge on the Dining Menu because someone ordered the whole fish and it looked delicious as it passed us.
name: Morgan's Pier

text:
Went here for dinner. Pretty nice to sit outside, and it's a part of the city I really like. It offers a lot of good beers, and actually the mussels are good. I had the jalapeno mussels which had a really nice flavor to the them. I feel like this is so close to being four stars, but something keeps holding me back from saying I really like it.

Maybe it's the service, it hasn't been bad exactly, but it's noticeably... off... or slightly unprofessional. That said I'll probably be back, it does have some nice things going for it.

text:

text: Got the sweet potato benny and shared it with a friend. The tater cake was really crispy, but the salad was a bit plain (looks like there isn't much to it but I could taste some olive oil and lemon). The poached egg wasn't runny, which I prefer (but did not request, FYI), and the hollandaise was pretty light compared to sauces I've had with other eggs benedicts. I think the sweet potato patty and avocado work quite well with this dish. Don't really care for the salad and not sure how they could make it better...but I really enjoyed the rest of the dish. The place is super cute with a rustic feel. If I lived closer, I think I'd like reading upstairs or getting a drink with a friend if I wasn't coming for a meal.

text:
The servers at Banana Leaf are short-bordering-on-rude, but I think it's just because they mean business. Service itself is great: food comes promptly, water is refilled, check comes quickly. I don't feel rushed through any of it. If something is worth mentioning about a dish, they'll mention it. I was told once flat out not to order something because there was a similar dish that was better. I ordered the ginger duck another time and was informed that the duck included skin and bones. Yes, they're doing themselves a favor by letting people know these things, but it helps me too.

Despite a small exterior that doesn't seem like much except for a huge sign, the restaurant is spacious inside. It's a good place for large parties looking for a reservation, and to sweeten the deal it's a BYOB. Plus, the decor is a conversation piece. And it's cheap!

As so many others have mentioned, the roti canai is a delicious app to start the meal. I've had a number of things off of the menu and gravitate towards the noodle dishes which are all good. I have not tried the sushi, nor have I tried the really adventurous-to-me stuff like chicken feet or fish head.

All in all, this is one of my favorite spots in Chinatown, and I will be back again and again.
name: Banana Leaf

text:
I was craving tacos and was automatically captivated to this place because of their reasonable menu price.

Upon arrival, I was sat immediately. I decided to order the Michelada. I did not like the drink at all. I told my server and she was very nice and understanding about it. I then ordered the tofu taco and a side of rice. The food came out very fast and it was delicious! The taco had this amazing brown sauce that finished the taste and the rice was cooked very well. 

Great atmosphere, cheap happy hour prices and wonderful staff

text:
Price: 
$-$$; not too pricey, featuring apps from $5 and up, to pitchers of beer up to ~$30. 

Food:
Hot & fresh; we received our two appetizers (beer battered onion rings & rosemary gravy fries) within 5 minutes. Pretty average bar food, nothing too special. 

Atmosphere:
Very relaxing, and especially nice on a night with good weather. The kitchen and part of the dining area is covered, so it would still hold up on a rainy day. The only qualm I have is that the only area serving food is pretty loud and crowded, whereas the quieter parts only serve alcohol. 

Overall:
Definitely would return. Especially for a Day 3-post opening, the IBG ran pretty quickly & efficiently with hot/fresh food. 

Tip: 
-One side only serves alcohol, while the other side serves both food & alcohol.
-Seating is first come, first serve - so grab the first empty table you find!

text:
This was freaking fantastic. They can accommodate huge groups, had great gluten free choices for a few people in our group and every dish was brilliant. The $30 tasting menu was a boat-load of food. 

This is not just some decent American-style Chinese place. The real deal. Go. Now.

text:
My friend and I were in Chinatown for dinner and she recommended that we go to this place for dessert. I'm not the biggest fan of matcha, so I ordered the Sizzling Ice Cream because I was under the impression that the brownie was chocolate. When the brownie arrived, I realized that it was actually matcha. You get to chose your flavor of ice cream and they had a few different ones, such as salted caramel, watermelon,and green tea, and I chose the green tea. When the dish comes out, the matcha brownie and ice cream are on the hot skillet and the server pours cream on it, which results in sizzling. Considering that I don't care for matcha, I was pleasantly surprised by the Sizzling Ice Cream, but I don't know if I would get it again. My friend ordered the Chocolate Lava Cake and she really liked it. It also came with a side of green tea ice cream. What I liked the most about hers is that the matcha for her Chocolate Lava Cake came in a dropper and she could choose how much to put on her cake. Overall, I would love to come back and try other things. The green tea ice cream on both of our dishes were amazing! 

Word of advice: the desserts are big enough for two people, especially if you just ate!

text:
Still, Buddakan gets rated not just as one of their favorite Starr Restaurants, but favorite restaurants in Philly!...I don't get it.  First off, the NYC location does a much better job with the food.  Second, there are so many better fusion or fine dining options in Philly.

Food Review
Crispy calamari salad.  Salad was ok, dressing is nice and light. Calamari is fried and batter was too thick and oily with a slight burnt oil aftertaste.  Continental does a better job at the same salad.

Edamame raviolli: house speciality, it's really good with a very creamy and smooth filling, my only complaint is there's not enough on the plate and you need to order at least 2 dishes if you plan on sharing the appetizers with the table.

Lobster fried rice: wouldn't know, it never made it to our table.  It was ordered, it was on our bill.  Chalk this one up to mediocre service.

Szechuan braised short rib:  Rich and filling.  It is served ontop of a long roasted bone, making the meat portion look small, however you'll have a hard time finishing the whole dish,  Nice crispy outside with a fatty and moist interior that falls apart on your fork.  I can't imagine anyone not liking this dish.

Pan seared sea bass: Average, personally I think it had a slight fishy note to it, but the rest of the table liked it.

Service Review
Hostesses at the front are warm and greeting and quick to take and later return your checked coat.

Waitress was scarce and didn't check back with us after the food was delivered...otherwise she might have been told we didn't get our lobster fried rice.  Bus boys seem to be the hardest working in the restaurant as 2 minutes after finishing something, the plate was being removed from the table, and my glass of water never got below the halfway mark.  Starr should give the busboys and water boys all a raise because they're carrying the slack for the lazy waitresses.

Restaurant Review
The decor is getting a little dated, might be time for a slight refresh.  My date asked for a black napkin so she didn't get lint on her black dress and no one could find one.  Seriously?  I expect a higher end restaurant known for it's nightlife and scene where more than half the room is wearing black, to have black napkins onhand for these requests.  Also, the bathrooms still use the cheap papertowels you'd expect to find at a bus depot.

Overall, it's a solid 3 star night out.  It won't be your best experience in Philadelphia, but you won't be disappointed if you are just going in for a nice dinner.  I woudn't go for a special occasion or to impress anyone, but the ravioli dish will keep us coming back every month or two.

text:
This review is only for drinks.

In Riva is adorable and in a prime location to attract all the people on Kelly Drive.  It worked.  They are bike and dog friendly aka tons of bike parking and a huge outdoor patio seating area that overlooks the river.  The only bummer? Happy hour prices are only inside.  But, I can live with that.

We got a specialty cocktail- something with vodka, wine and orange soda.  It was delicious and refreshing.  They also had a cheap beer special.  The total bill for 3 people at 2 drinks each was under $20!!!

The service here was great.  Everyone was extremely friendly, welcoming and attentive.  

Rumor on the street is they're going to start doing zumba and salsa classes on the deck in the summer.  Stay tuned.

Excited to revisit In Riva and try out their brunch this summer.

text:
Went to XIX for drinks and a quick bite. You can reach XIX via the shops at Bellevue or the Hyatt. You've probably guessed, its located on the 19th floor. Once off the elevator it seems you've gotten off on an abandoned floor. Wonder around a bit and you'll eventually find the restaurant, the bar is just a little farther in. The bar has tall ceilings, paintings on the wall, seats by a window or the fireplace, very nice ambiance.  

The food at the bar is pretty good. Had the flatbread, which was very good and the oysters which were fresh. Great selection of speciality drinks available and decent wines by the glass. The prices are a little on the high side but worth it for the quality.

text:
This place has the best vegetarian sandwich I think I've ever had.  No joke!  If you're a vegetarian, or even if you're not, Honey's Veggie Patty Melt is a perfect melding of spicy and sweet with jalapeno's melted into the cheese and a sweet honey mustard sauce to dip the sandwich it in.  I don't know what the patty is made of, but it is quite tasty.  The whole wheat toast makes it even better.  I get it with a side of hand-cut fries, and I love the little salad that comes with it with vinegary cabbage and a slice of a pickled green tomato.  I have a habit of ordering this every time because it is so good, and I'm afraid everything else wouldn't live up to its standard.  
  
       Last night, I decided to venture out and try something new.  I got the home-made turkey burger with fries.  The turkey was well seasoned and moist.  The portions here are quite generous, so I got full and gave my boyfriend the last of my sandwich.  He isn't a huge fan of turkey burgers, but doesn't dislike them.  He bit into it, and was like, "Oh wow, this is good."  I don't know what the seasoning was, but we both liked it.  The fries were crispy, fresh cut, and delicious as usual.  The little salad was different and was a purple coleslaw that wasn't a vinegar base instead of the green vinegary cabbage.  That was the only disappointment.  It wasn't bad.  I'm just all about the vinegar.  My boyfriend ordered the vegetarian chicken fried steak with mac and cheese and a biscuit which he seemed to enjoy.   It was a huge portion and the "chicken" came smothered in gravy which pleased him.   I ordered a slice of chocolate cake with mocha frosting to go.  The icing tasted like my mom's, which is a good thing because she makes everything from scratch.  The cake was good, but dense and rice and more like a brownie.  

     Honey's recently changed their hours, so I hadn't been there in a while until last night.  Other than the hours changing, I noticed that their specials page seemed smaller, as it used to be double sided.  The one change I noticed that I really liked was that the service was excellent last night.  Usually it takes forever to get the waiter to take your order, the food comes out fast, but it's impossible to flag down a waiter.  In contrast, our waiter last night was fast, polite, helpful, and friendly, although my boyfriend thought he didn't refill his coffee often enough.  I think I'll be back more often because of last night's experience, as we hadn't come here in a while no only due to the hours change, but also the memories of terrible service.
name: Honey's Sit-N-Eat

text: La Viola was... Ok. Came here because Monk's had a long wait. They served decent Italian food, and guess what? Mussels too! Price was ok, food was ok. Basically, it's an ok place. There are two locations on the same street, on the same block. So, if one is full, try the other. It's good for large parties b/c it can accommodate, and there's mostly always space between the two restaurants!

text: Lucha Cartel is one of my fave spots in Old City. I think it tends to get forgotten but it has a lot to offer. It's a great spot for big groups especially on a Friday night- their late night specials are such a great way to start the night ($5 margs! $3 coronas.) The flavored tequilas definitely make the drink choices more interesting! Although they aren't my fave Mexican cuisine in the city, they do make some amazing fresh guac! As a vegetarian I love that they have 3 different Taco options! The sweet potato was my fave.
name: Lucha Cartel

text: I ordered from here via Uber eats. Although UBER messed up my order twice (horrible experience) the restaurant was very kind and accommodating and helpful. They provide outstanding phone service (covid and Uber eats) at least. The tarakawa signature ramen was good. It wasn't my favorite. I didn't think it had much flavor. But with chili oil it's good. the shoyu ramen is far better. The broth is a million times better. And the noodles in the shoyu are much better too..... the wavy noodle is for sure better than the thin straight noodles here. The thin straight were stiff and felt less noodly. But still tasted good. I read a previous review to select wavy noodles instead for the signature tarakawa and I wish I had listened. The chili oil is 10/10. Ive never had better chili oil. It's nice and spicy so go light when pouring it into your ramen bowl. It's fantastic. I wouldn't say this is the BEST ramen ever but I'd order again probably.
name: Terakawa Ramen

text: Hot donuts are the best here. I got one of each flavor and enjoyed all of them (bites of them, not 3 full donuts!). I also tried the buttermilk ranch chicken which was very good. The fried outside is wonderfully crunchy and the seasoning is very tasty. The only thing that makes it not perfect is that I feel like the chicken itself has a strange...saltiness to it. It could just be me. Ok, time to log some hours at the gym now!

text:
This place is right around Rittenhouse and very classy. Our waiter was very polite and friendly which put us in a great mood. 

I started with a frozen rose, which was DELICIOUS. It was hot so this really hit the spot! Wasn't too sweet and was a perfect drink. For my meal I got a salmon tartine sandwich and a side of french fries. I took some things off the sandwich that I didn't like, but after that it was yummy. The fries were perfect and thin and crunchy. 

It was all a little pricey, but I wouldn't expect anything less around Rittenhouse. Great experience.

text: If you've been wanting to try Vedge, happy hour is the best time to go without spending a lot! Their happy hour is fantastic (all under $5). I absolute loved the 'cheeseteak', I could definitely eat 10 of them. Also, the cabbage toast was light and crispy. Beware the 'taco' is super spicy but really really good. You do have the sit at the bar to get the specials, but if you get there around 5 or earlier there should be a spot. After trying the happy hour I am ready to jump into the dinner scene, can't wait!

text:
Mixto is one of my favorite places in the city for any occasion - they're great for both brunch and dinner, big groups or dates!  I love the interior decor/overall vibe, the staff is always very friendly, and the food is delicious!

For brunch, you really can't go wrong with any of their selections!  I've tried almost the entire brunch menu and my favorite has been the French Toast.  However, the Cuban Breakfast is another great choice - the pulled pork is tender and well-seasoned, and the dish comes with maduros (THE BEST!).  But really, you can't go wrong with anything you choose!

For dinner, my personal favorite is the Ropa Vieja - I can't recommend this enough.  Ropa Vieja is a signature Cuban dish and Mixto has, by far, the best in Philly!  The paella also does not disappoint.

For drinks, I love the fresh-squeezed orange juice to complement brunch.  They also have some really tasty mojitos that go great with dinner.
name: Mixto

text:
Three words: HAPPY HOUR NACHOS

Just go during happy hour, 5-7 M-F or 1-3 Sat/ Sun, and order yourself the nachos (splurge the extra $1 for a huge scoop of guac). For $6, you'll get a beautiful mound of melty , gooey, crunchy, salty, satisfying chips with no skimping on the toppings. Best paired with 1-2 friends and a draft IPA. My vegetarian friend and I had no qualms about splitting this meat-free dish, and we hardly made a dent before my stomach finally screamed at me to stop binge eating. I probably looked like an animal, shoveling food with my hands - NO SHAME. Best nachos I may have ever eaten.

I also ordered a Chilorio taco (a spicy pulled pork) and a Chorizo & potato taco - both banging, but the Chorizo definitely won. The tacos were small, like smaller than the palm of my hand, and I have little hands (I'm Donald Trump LOL). I was a little disappointed that they cost $2+ each. I'd definitely come back on $1 taco night though.

Beer selection is alright, about 6 on draft and a variety of bottles/ cans, and the bar is full of any liquor you could want. The vibe is very chill - a little dim, a little tight at the bar. Hipster, but not overly; divey but clean.

Bartender was a little harsh. I arrived a little before 5 and I wasn't about to buy a beer when it wasn't on happy hour. When I stated I'd sip on water until 5, she rolled her eyes and kind of gave me 'tude. She was fine otherwise, average bartendery service. 

I'll definitely be back. This is the perfect weekday happy hour.
name: Loco Pez

text:
Had a great dinner here. Easily made a reservation for a Friday night and tried:

+ Sage derby smash
